PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President, and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10(c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10(c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 15 citizens), Boswell (from 12,586 citizens) and Peter Rae (from 24 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirms the principle of the inadmissibility of discrimination and proclaims that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind including distinction based on sex.

However extensive discrimination against women continues to exist. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men, in the political , social, economic and cultural life of this country. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of this country and of humanity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will act to ratify the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Coleman (from 21 citizens), Macklin (from 14 citizens) and Robertson (from 58 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That Australia support the Ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your House urge all politicians to unite nationally to do all within their power to ratify this important Convention.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South West Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the members of the Senate. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania respectfully urge that the enabling legislation to protect the Franklin River in South West Tasmania be passed at the earliest opportunity.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Enrichment Plant
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners do not want a Uranium Enrichment Plant constructed in South-East Queensland because:
(a) there is no known way of safely storing uranium waste products;
(b) there has not been an environment impact study conducted into the effects of such a Uranium Enrichment Plant;
(c) Australia has adequate coal supplies to provide energy for industry;
(d) the risks to local inhabitants from the operation of such a plant have not been established;
(e) the products of such a plant will contribute to the prospect of nuclear war ;
(f) the local area would become a target in the event of such a nuclear war;
(g) the investment in such a Uranium Enrichment Plant would be better spent in research into clean, renewable energy sources such as solar energy.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
(a) legislate to give power to the Commonwealth Parliament to make decisions on the export of products from Uranium Enrichment Plants;
(b) reject all applications for the export of products from Uranium Enrichment Plants;
(c) legislate to give power to the Commonwealth Parliament to make decisions on foreign investment in Uranium Enrichment Plants;
(d) reject all applications for foreign investment in Uranium Enrichment Plants ;
(e) do all in the Senate's power to prevent the construction of a Uranium Enrichment Plant in South-East Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIA NEW ZEALAND CLOSER ECONOMIC RELATIONS TRADE AGREEMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some remarks on the Australia New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement which has been tabled in the Senate today. Closer economic relations between Australia and New Zealand are, of course, but the latest feature of that relationship between our two nations which is symbolised by Anzac Day and which is featured in the free flow of peoples between our two nations. It is, I think, undoubtedly the case that there are close political, social and even personal ties of an historic kind which have evolved over the years which give a social and personal dimension to the close geographical relationship that exists between our nations. It is not surprising, therefore, that there ought to be evolving a closer trading relationship such as is embodied in the Trade Agreement which was tabled in the Senate this morning. Indeed it was in order to create a free trade market embracing Australia and New Zealand that negotiations took place over the last several years.

SPEECH.PARA: The importance of the agricultural sector to both economies is well known to honourable senators. Indeed, it proved to be a sensitive part of the negotiations between our two governments and between the industries involved. But I wish to make a special point about Tasmania. Because we have such a similar geographical location to New Zealand, many of our agricultural, timber and fishing pursuits are much the same as those undertaken by our New Zealand counterparts. Therefore, it is a matter of great concern to Tasmania that this Agreement should not operate in a way which would have a detrimental impact on our agricultural, fishing and timber-based industries. Several meetings have been convened over the last year or so by me, and by Senator Brian Archer, whose interest in this matter I acknowledge. These meetings have occurred with those involved in dairying, vegetable products, fishing and timber. I mention here in particular the very able assistance of Mr Laurie Kelly of the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association in helping to convene many of these meetings.

Consultations have taken place on a government to government level which I believe have modified and, to some extent, helped more adequately to reflect the concerns expressed on both sides of the Tasman about the impact of this Agreement on our agricultural and primary producers. For example, in the dairy industry in particular, where it was thought that much difficulty would be found in coming to common accords, people got together and evolved a consensus in a spirit of such co-operation and compromise that the industry on both sides of the Tasman is to be congratulated in setting forth a model that could well be followed by the vegetable and other industries.

In the few minutes allowed to me I just wish to sound a note of caution in regard to Tasmania's continuing worry, particularly in relation to timber and the dumping of some vegetables on Australian markets. Imports of forest products have become a very sensitive issue. Some dumping and countervailing duty actions have been pursued by the Australian industry and by Tasmanians in particular. One must realise that many Tasmanian townships and smaller settlements depend on timber based industries for their viability-for their very existence. For that reason, it is not surprising that in relation to the importation of sawn softwood timber, pulp and newsprint from New Zealand, considerable concern has been expressed and some negotiations have had to be undertaken to try to provide for a level of understanding between the common producers of these products in both countries. This level of understanding was sought to avoid a devastating impact. There would have been such a severe and detrimental economic impact that the industries would have crumbled under the strain.

Agreements have been achieved in relation to forestry products, in addition to the decision to devalue which had some marginal benefit in helping to protect us against imports of timber products from New Zealand. For example, agreement has been reached in relation to the level and price of sawn softwood timber exports to Australia. We have some cause for a reasonable degree of optimism that the industries themselves, as happened in the dairy industry, may come to a reasonable agreement.

I noticed that several pages in the Trade Agreement were devoted to dealing with anti-dumping action. Indeed, it is the case that action can be taken when certain goods are imported into Australia at less than their normal value, when such importing causes material injury or materially retards the establishment of some Australian and, in my concern, Tasmanian industry. It is the case that in recent weeks those who produce onions in Tasmania, who have shown great enterprise, flair and initiative in setting up a multi-million dollar onion export industry, have been vociferous in their complaints. Of course, this industry is based, in particular in the beautiful hills around Devonport. I hope that the Government will take note of their particular concerns. Mr President, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave not granted.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEFENCE FORCE RETIREMENT AND DEATH BENEFITS AUTHORITY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I will make a few remarks with regard to this matter. This report is presented in the Senate at a most significant time. Of course, it comes against the background of the Government's recent announcements in regard to superannuation and the way in which lump sum payments are to be taxed. I draw the Senate's attention to a few facts set out in the report which I think will lead to further questions. The report indicates significantly that 3,930 commutation payments have been made to former members of the defence forces who have retired during the last financial year. A total of $62,139,977 was paid out to those persons. That works out at an average commutation payment to former members of the services of $38,620. We would all agree that that is a relatively small sum of money.

However, that sum of money, in the circumstances of virtually involuntary retirement on the part of ex-servicemen, will, of course, put them within the net cast by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, last Thursday night during his economic statement. Superannuation payments of the order of $38,000 will, of course, be subject to a tax of 30 per cent; in other words, some $11,000 would be stripped from ex-servicemen in those circumstances, without taking into account the situation that might arise should people seek to invest that $38,000 in an annuity.

Let me take the case of a person who is the age of, say, 40 years and who is a retiring major in the Army. Information that I have from the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Fund indicates that his sum would be of the order of $35,000 in those circumstances-something akin to the average, as evidenced in my earlier statement. He could invest that $35,000, bearing in mind that he would have a life expectancy of something like 75 years. In other words, he would need to have an income for another 35 years or so. If he bought an annuity from an insurance fund he would find that he would get the princely sum of about $400 a month to live off. I think that would be a relatively low sum of money compared with the amount he might look forward to in his future career. One has to take into account the fact that a retiring serviceman would perhaps not have his own home, especially at the age of 40 or 45 years. Therefore, he may seek to buy a house to live in during his retirement. I put it to the Government that it would be worth while to consider a lump sum payment made in that situation being exempt of tax in order for people to buy their own houses.

There is a further consideration that there could well be people at relatively young ages who, having left the services, find it difficult to get paid employment but who many choose to commence their own businesses. A lump sum of $ 30,000 or $40,000 would be useful in helping to establish such a business. A person may like to buy a newsagency, a milk round or something of that kind that would produce further revenue and employment in due course for people in the community. Why should he not be given some consideration when tax is to be applied in this fashion? I put it to the Government that this is typical of a rash of circumstances in the community generally where people would receive relatively modest lump sum payments through voluntary or involuntary retirement. But I indicate to the Government that a number of involuntary circumstances ought to be taken into account, particularly when people will suffer very significantly because of the Government's taxation of lump sum payments.

I draw that matter to the Senate's attention because I think many people have it fixed in their minds that many retirees somehow will be demi-millionaires or something of that order. But we are talking about people in fairly ordinary circumstances with relatively low levels of superannuation lump sum payments. Therefore, I believe that the Government should closely examine the circumstances of particular classes of employees who find themselves in these situations. I draw the Government's attention to my suggestions in that area.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chaney) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Resolutions of Twelfth Meeting

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Whilst the agenda item for the Australian Fisheries Council primarily concerns the development of Australia's fishing resources-Senator Archer and some others in this chamber are experts in that matter-the matter to which I want to draw the Senate's attention has been on the agenda of the Council now for the last four years and has now become largely resolved. I refer to the importation of exotic fish. Some honourable senators will recall that, particularly three and four years ago, I asked a series of questions and spoke in the chamber about the importance of there not being an overall ban on the importation of goldfish and other forms of tropical and exotic fish. After all, after photography, keeping fish in aquaria is the largest leisure pastime of Australians, I am told.

The pet industry in Australia has been pulled together and consolidated very largely because of items on the agenda of the Australian Fisheries Council. Because there was a threat of government bringing down a ban upon the importers of fish, the pet industry in Australia formed itself into an organisation. The other day in Adelaide I was happy to speak to its national executive. Because of consultations between the industry and government that have been urged here in the Senate and in other places, a sensible outcome in the production of the list of fish that can be imported into Australia has been achieved. At one stage there was an open list of some 700 species that could be introduced. But, with some bureaucratic advice, this was to be reduced to less than 100 and goldfish in particular would have been excluded. As a result of careful consultations with the enterprising pet industry representatives and in particular the Australian Aquarium Fish Importers and Traders Association, we have seen a very happy outcome to this matter. I am sure that all honourable senators will rest much more happily and feel more relaxed when they see fish circulating in aquaria now that they know that the Australian Fisheries Council has largely resolved this matter to the satisfaction of the industry at large. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave not granted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to say a few words on the performance of the Australian Wool Corporation because it has indeed performed an enormously important task in maintaining a successful wool industry not only in 1981-82 but also for a considerable number of years before that. The stockpile was high in that period. It was a difficult period economically all around the world, which had obvious repercussions on the wool market and the operation of the stockpile. The Corporation was very significant in maintaining a relatively buoyant wool industry. In itself this was even more significant because last year there was almost a total failure of Australia's wheat crop east of Western Australia. That emphasised the importance of wool and the Corporation that governs its marketing very significantly.

As is highlighted in this report, the wool industry is very receptive to the problems of internal costs in this country, for the obvious reason that it relies almost 95 per cent on an external market, the price levels of which it has little control over. The market support fund, which has now begun to revolve , is in a strong position, as this report indicates. I will conclude my remarks by referring to a highly competitive industry in which there will be a continual necessity for funds to be available. I refer to the fibre industry around the world and to the field of promotion. Promotion has proved to be a very effective measure. I believe the need for it is gaining ground in present circumstances as the promotion and competitiveness of other fibres become more clearly apparent.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Australian Film Commission on a fairly comprehensive report. Once again we are in a situation in which a report has reached the chamber fairly late in the piece and in which a number of the matters questioned in it are either in process of change or could be subject to change. But some of the points made by the Chairman of the Commission, Sir James Cruthers, are extremely important and I think bear repeating to the Senate. For instance, he makes the point that this is a time of great change in the Australian film and television industry. He goes on to discuss in some detail the problems that are being created by the policy of having tax incentives in the film industry. It has caused a great number of problems, particularly, as he points out, the bunching of productions into a narrow time frame and normally in the second six months of a tax year so that investors may take advantage of the tax rebate in that period. He also makes the very valid point that it has led to a major problem confronting the film industry; that is, the disturbing escalation of the production costs of films throughout Australia. We have one of the oldest film industries in the world. It is heartening to see what whilst we are not doing everything that is necessary, I believe, in the preservation of the old films, at least there is now a move by governments and private enterprise to bring to the attention of the Australian Archives that there are films available so that they can be preserved. I hope too that a greater resource will be available to the Archives so that more films can be treated and preserved for posterity.

SPEECH.PARA: If one were watching television last weekend one might have been made aware that one of the very first films which was taken in Papua New Guinea, which I understand was taken by an Australian firm, was located. It is now 80 years old and has been recently presented at the Cannes Film Festival. This is an indication of the value of having these things available for people of future generations. I would like to think that at least, if we did not do so in the past, we now recognise that we have a responsibility to the future to have these films maintained in a viewing situation so that people in the future will be able to see them. The film was particularly interesting in that it was the first film taken in New Guinea of New Guineans. The reactions of the people of New Guinea to white people going in to take film and show them products which were at that stage considered to be normal in Australia, such as a record player, were quite remarkable. It was a very interesting experiment. We know that a larger number of films of similar age are available throughout Australia, but unfortunately they have not been preserved.

The report of the Australian Film Commission is comprehensive in that it details all of those films which have received funding. A number of areas cause me some little concern. It has not been possible, obviously, for the Film Commission to grant as much money as was needed to various producers for films that were of importance, but at least it was able to give them a start. I should like to think the Commission will have more money available to it to spread, not more wisely-it has obviously done a very good job-but over a much broader range to ensure that people may see that the contributions they are making for Australia now and for the future go ahead.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it a fact, as claimed by Mr Unsworth, that at the end of the National Economic Summit Conference, when the Government was bringing Australia together and when it had full knowledge of the economic circumstances, the Prime Minister gave the Australian Council of Trade Unions an undertaking that there would be no increase in taxation on lump sum superannuation payments? Why has the Prime Minister and the Government broken Mr Hawke's promise to the unions as well as, of course, his earlier promise to the Australian people before the last election?

—I am aware of the claim by Mr Unsworth. I am unaware of any undertakings given by the Prime Minister. When I say I am unaware, I am not denying that undertakings were given; I just do not know. I will certainly investigate that matter and give the Leader of the Opposition an answer to that question at a later time. A suggestion of broken promises has been made. The prime objective of this Government is to restore economic growth in this country and to create employment for almost one million Australians who are unemployed. In the course of the election campaign some matters were referred to which will have to be deferred or reconsidered by the Government because of that prime commitment which we have to embark upon in the light of the disastrous situation in respect of the economy of this country which we discovered only when we were elected to government. Of course, that discovery was possible only at that time because of misleading statements made to the people of Australia by the now Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As I pointed out in my original question, this promise was made at the conclusion of the Economic Summit, when the economic facts were known to the Government. I therefore ask the Leader of the Government: What relevance has the pre-election view of the Government to that promise? I also ask: Is the position, as Mr Crean suggested on AM today, that the Government has in fact an open attitude on this matter and may vary the decision?

—I thought that Senator Chaney's original question referred to broken promises, and I am sure that the Hansard record will show that it did. His question is now more specific in relation to a comment allegedly made by the Prime Minister after the Summit. I said in answer to Senator Chaney's question that I was unaware whether that statement had been made and that I would investigate that question.
—Very convenient.

—Of course it is convenient; it is also correct. I said that I would investigate that matter and give the honourable senator an answer as soon as possible. The relevance of my answer has been questioned. I answered the previous question on the basis that I thought it was addressed to general promises. Senator Chaney also referred to a statement made by Mr Crean this morning. All I can say about that is that Mr Crean has his views and his constituency. The Government yesterday had consultations with the life offices and the superannuation funds regarding the implementation of its program and next week will be having discussions with a number of other bodies, including the Australian Council of Trade Unions, of which Mr Crean is Vice- President.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. What surveys have been undertaken in his Department on incorrect payments to social security recipients? In what pension or benefit category have incorrect payments occurred most commonly? It is suggested in recent newspaper articles that fraud, which is usually associated with incorrect payments to the claimant, is most rife amongst the unemployed. Is this the case to his knowledge? If not, where are the problems on overpayments within the Department?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Surveys have been done in the Department of Social Security on overpayments. They are done regularly and they were done before I became Minister. One of the last answers to a question on notice I put down as a shadow Minister came from the previous Minister on this subject. It is interesting to note that overpayments in these surveys, from memory, made up about 4.7 per cent of a very considerable number of payments. It is also interesting to note that the highest percentage of overpayments occurred in the age pension area and the widows and supporting parent's benefits area. In the former case, the percentage was something like 29 per cent, which reflects the difficulty of calculating payments and calculating the income tests in these areas.

ANSWER.PARA: In the area of unemployment benefit and special benefits, the overpayments were of a considerably lower percentage-I believe about 4.3 per cent-which may surprise honourable senators. These figures reflect the difficulty in the calculation of payments in the area of age pensions and the relatively greater ease in calculating payments in the unemployment benefit area. It is a general misconception, fostered by some sections of the media and unfortunately by some politicians, that the area of difficulty is the unemployment benefit. The surveys in fact show that is just not true.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it a fact that approximately 1.8 million wage and salary earners are involved in superannuation funds? Is it a fact that a significant majority of these people are of modest income earnings? Are the great majority of these people-particularly those in the private sector-members of superannuation schemes which involve the payment of lump sums and not annuities? Did not all these people and their employers enter upon such superannuation schemes and arrange their assets and retirement plans on the basis that the principles of those schemes would be maintained? Why, therefore, is the Government intending to force people to surrender their capital acquired over a lifetime and to depend on an annuity which disappears without capital residue at death? How does the Government justify the use of punitive taxation to attack the capital assets of superannuitants, while not directing its attention to those others of the community who acquire capital by means other than superannuation? Does this foreshadow a capital gains tax?

—I will answer the last part of the question first. I hope Senator Martin's question implies her support for a capital gains tax. If members of the Opposition are keen to have a capital gains tax I am sure they will let us know and we will see what we can do to accommodate them in that matter. The first part of the question relates to whether 1.8 million wage and salary earners are members of superannuation schemes. I am unable to answer that part of the question insofar as it relates to a matter of fact. I will obtain the information from the Minister and provide it to the honourable senator in due course. I am also not able to say what percentage of the alleged numbers of wage and salary earners are involved in the payment of lump sums as an entitlement of part of their superannuation scheme. I remind the Senate, however, that there is no element of retrospectivity in the Government's announcement on this matter. The reference in the honourable senator's question to lump sums accumulated over a lifetime is, to that extent, incorrect. As I have indicated, I will obtain an answer for the honourable senator in due course on the other aspects of the question.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that the Leader of the Government has answered that he does not know and has to find out how many wage and salary earners are involved in superannuation funds and whether a majority of these are people of modest income earnings, does that mean that Cabinet did not have this information in front of it when it made its decision?

—It does not mean anything of the sort, of course. I make no pretence that in any government, Cabinet makes decisions about these matters. No Minister is necessarily conversant with all the facts, but I will certainly find them out. If the Opposition finds that admission offensive, I am sorry. The only other aspect of the honourable senator's question to which I refer is that it seems strange to me that the economic statement was brought down last Thursday, yet there has been a massive silence from the Opposition about all these issues until Question Time today. Not one question was asked about these issues yesterday.
—Mr President, I take a point of order. The relevant papers have not been introduced into the Senate by the Government.

—In relation to Senator Chaney's point of order, I just make the point that the fact that the statement has not been introduced into the Senate has not deterred Opposition senators today from asking questions about these matters. Of course, the claims that are being made in questions asked here today are claims which the Opposition has had assistance with from a number of programs in the media, many of which have been ill informed as to the facts.

—I refer the Minister for Industry and Commerce to the decision by General Motors-Holden's Ltd to cut its work force by 2,800 and, in particular , to its decision to cut back its Woodville plant work force to 600. Does the Minister intend to have further consultations with GMH management in the immediate future? What special employment assistance will the Federal Government give to South Australia, in view of the State's heavy reliance on the car manufacturing industry and the likely social hardship which will result from the company's decision?

—The answer to the first part of the question is yes; the Government will have further discussions with General Motors about its announced plans. It will do so in the middle of next month in the context of general considerations about the future of the motor car industry in Australia. The second part of the honourable senator's question relates to whether special assistance to South Australia should be considered by the Government in view of the particular regional impact of the decision of GMH on South Australia. All I can say is that that matter will be considered by the Government. I remind the Senate, however, that the terms of the program announced by General Motors- Holden's Ltd do not provide for any immediate retrenchments. The process of work force reduction is to take place over two and a half years. Of course the Government deplores the social and regional consequences of the company's decision. Nonetheless, we recognise that it is a problem which has to be faced up to by governments, both State and Federal, and we will certainly be talking to the South Australian Government about the particular problems which have arisen. We are not in a position to announce any particular programs at this stage. Indeed, there is no need to do so.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. It follows the answer he gave earlier to the Leader of the Opposition in which he expressed the Government's desire to cure unemployment in this country and create jobs as rapidly as possible. Is the Government aware of a large and growing body of opinion in the community for a system of part time work and job sharing in appropriate circumstances for those who want it? Would the Minister agree that these measures would share available work more fairly and so reduce unemployment? Is the Goverment currently negotiating with the trade union movement to gain its acceptance of these principles? If not, when will the Government do so? When can we expect changes in the industrial law to provide for a fair and regulated system of part time work in which at present many young people in particular are being shamefully exploited?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of general issues in Senator Mason's question relating to employment. I will discuss with the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations the specific suggestions which are implicit in the question . I think I can say now-I am not certain of this-that there are no current negotiations with the Australian Council of Trade Unions or any other peak union authority regarding part time employment. That does not mean that they should not take place. Of course consideration must be given to these issues, in a much wider context perhaps than the honourable senator implies, in discussions with the trade union movement in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that consideration has to be given to a number of other factors which affect the level of unemployment such as the very high participation rate of young people in Australia in employment. That matter should perhaps have some priority over the question of part time employment discussions. The Government is giving general consideration to these matters. It is discussing a wide variety of matters with the ACTU but I do not believe that specific discussions on part time employment are taking place at present. No doubt that matter can be brought forward. I will advise the Minister of the honourable senator's question .

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO THE USE OF CHEMICAL AGENTS IN VIETNAM

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. What have been the reactions from veterans' organisations, chemical companies, interested countries and the media to the setting up of the Royal Commission into the Use of Chemical Agents in Vietnam?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a large measure of support and response from ex- service organisations and veterans' organisations about the Government's decision to establish the royal commission. Indeed, there has been an interested response from the United States Government and the New Zealand Government about the course of action which prompted the Government to honour its election commitment to establish a royal commission to look into the problems of herbicides and other chemical agents which may have affected the well-being, both physical and mental, of 45,000 veterans who served in Vietnam. The royal commission is getting a degree of interest overseas as it has in our country.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the Senate that practically every newspaper in the country commented very favourably upon the Government's decision to establish the royal commission so that we can determine, on the basis of fact and statistics, what happened when the Australian Government was persuaded to become involved in the use of herbicides which were introduced into Vietnam by the American armed services. During 1984 perhaps we will see that matter resolved by the inquiry. I am sure that the governments that I have mentioned-the United States Government and the New Zealand Government-will watch very carefully with interest the way in which the royal commission carries out its function.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INCOME TAX CONCESSIONS ON HEALTH INSURANCE

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Did not the Government give a pre-election undertaking not to remove the income tax concession for health insurance until the introduction of Medicare? I further ask: What is the immediate cost to a family, per week or per month, of this broken promise?

—I am not aware that the pre-election statement was made in that context. However, if the honourable senator wants me to provide that information , I will do so. I will also seek from the Treasurer a statement of the exact cost, as the honourable senator puts it, to families.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that today is 'No Butts Day'-a major anti-smoking campaign in at least one State? In view of the fact that the Minister was a signatory to the 1977 report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare I raise the question of banning the advertising of tobacco products in areas under direct Commonwealth control, for example, at airports and in the Australian Capital Territory. In particular, I ask whether the Minister saw a letter some time ago from a number of medical students who commented that they:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . continually see patients seriously debilitated or dying of diseases that are a direct result of long-term cigarette smoking. Active encouragement of cigarette smoking, particularly in the light of increasing local and national awareness of its well-documented ill-effects on health and consequent drain on Government resources, is at best irresponsible.

Will the Minister ask the Minister for Health, the Minister for Aviation and other appropriate Ministers to take urgent action in this area as an indication of the Government's concern about the nation's health?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that today is 'No Butts Day' in certain States. I was reminded of it this morning every time I lit a cigarette by several of my colleagues, including some of those reformed smokers such as Senator Coates. I certainly do remember signing the 1977 report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare which dealt with drug problems in particular, the most serious drug problems we have in this country being cigarettes and alcohol.

ANSWER.PARA: At the time the difficulty of the Commonwealth Government, because of its limited powers affecting advertising, was brought forward. We had a discussion at that time on how best we could influence the effects of advertising on the consumption of cigarettes. It has been of great concern to us that, whilst the consumption of cigarettes amongst the older age group has been dropping, the consumption of cigarettes amongst the younger age group, particularly young females, has been increasing. We have been concerned about the effects that advertising has had on this group.

I am well aware of the medical effects of smoking, of the addictive nature of cigarettes and of the difficulties people have in trying to give up cigarettes. I believe that anything we can do as a parliament and as a government to cut down the consumption of cigarettes and other tobacco products would be a worthwhile effort.

I will refer to the Minister for Health and the Minister for Aviation Senator Coates's suggestion that there are areas where the Commonwealth Government can affect advertising, particularly at airports. I will seek from those Ministers an early reply to see whether the Government can, or should, affect this advertising and, therefore, reduce the effective advertising for the consumption of tobacco in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. As the majority of Australian families maintain health insurance, will not the mini-Budget mean that, after the introduction of Medicare, such families thereafter have to pay both the levy and health insurance if they wish to maintain anything other than the basic health cover? Indeed, I point out that in Queensland they will have to pay for what they already get for nothing.
—The burden of the abolition of the rebate will not be felt until the income year 1984-85. By that time the Medicare proposal will be in place.
—Be honest.

—I am being perfectly honest. That statement is correct. I am not able to say the precise numbers of Australians who are currently in private medical funds but I will obtain that information from the Minister and advise the honourable senator.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Health is no doubt aware of the comments made by the shadow Minister for Health complaining about the proposed changes to health insurance by our Government. In particular he complained of the potential loss of jobs and the extra cost. Could the Minister explain to the Senate how the shadow Minister is wrong in his facts and figures and his interpretation? Further, could the Minister say how much it cost to dismantle Medibank when the previous Government came to office? How many jobs were lost by its callous breaking of an electoral promise? What is the estimated size of medical fraud, which became so easy once the previous Government dismantled the one central Medibank computer that was the most important check against such behaviour? How many medical schemes were there under the previous Government and what was their increasing cost to the community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Crowley for her question. It gives me an opportunity to comment not only on her question but also on some of the other remarks that have been made here today. The Senate should be reminded of the record of the previous Government in the health insurance area. I well remember sitting on this side of the chamber in 1975 when the Medibank legislation was introduced, and watching the Opposition oppose the introduction of the Medibank levy. In fact, it had sufficient numbers to do so. It opposed that levy and the legislation was defeated. The Governor-General used the rejection of that legislation as one of the excuses to call the infamous double dissolution in 1975. The previous Government marched into Parliament and introduced the same legislation to introduce a levy which it had opposed only a matter of months before.

ANSWER.PARA: In the election campaign of 1975 Mr Fraser, the then Leader of the Liberal- Country Party coalition, made this infamous statement in his policy speech: 'We will preserve Medibank'. The previous Government, when it came into power not only dismantled Medibank; it proceeded to introduce over the next seven years no fewer than seven health schemes. I was the shadow Minister representing the Health portfolio in this place. Regularly each year a series of health amendment Bills were introduced and regularly at the end of the debate I said: 'I will see you here again next year. This won't work. This will be too expensive. This will be hopeless'. Regularly every year the Minister for Health, whoever he may have been at the time, felt a new health scheme coming on, and introduced it. We had seven years of disastrous confusion. We had seven years in which no one knew where he stood in relation to health insurance. Medibank was dismantled in 1975, with no regard being paid to the loss of jobs. There was no job program such as the one which has been announced by the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, in another place today and which will be announced by me in this place in a statement later.

I remind honourable senators that this Government had clearly in its election policy the introduction of a universal health insurance scheme called Medicare. We spelt it out over a period of two years before the last election. I remind honourable senators opposite that we overwhelmingly won that election. The health insurance funds, the patients and the doctors knew what our policy was. Although the scheme will not be introduced till February, Dr Blewett has spelt out, and will continue to spell out, exactly what he and the Government will do in February so that we can have proper discussion. I am pleased to note that the health insurance funds now seem to agree with Medicare because they are very keen to run it. Unfortunately, we will not be able to oblige them in that regard . We will have not only a fair and equitable health insurance scheme, but a system whereby the Government will be able to monitor the overservicing and fraud which are rife in the present health insurance system.

I believe that the situation now is different from that of 1975. I vividly remember in 1975 Senator Baume, who was then the spokesman for the Australian Medical Association in this place, saying: 'Doctors will co-operate with anyone except the Labor Party'. In fact, the majority of doctors are responsible citizens who will co-operate with Medicare. Medicare will be introduced. We will have a fair health insurance system which will last longer than the six months or nine months that the previous Government's schemes lasted. People will have certainty. They will know where they are. We will have at last a fair and equitable economic health insurance scheme. If I have missed anything in Senator Crowley's question, I will seek the information from the Minister and give it to her later.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Arising out of Senator Grimes's answer that he could not accommodate the private health funds in the new Medibank scheme, I ask: What plans has the Government to find alternative employment for the thousands of employees of private health funds who will be displaced following the introduction of Medicare and who will not be absorbed into the new Medibank?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Hamer had read the statement brought down in the other place yesterday by Dr Blewett or if he could contain his impatience and listen to the statement that I will bring down in this place today, he would have known or he will know the answer to that question. But, first, there will not be thousands of unemployed people displaced from health insurance funds who will not be able to be taken up under the new Medibank scheme. Of course the Government is concerned about the potential employment consequences of this decision. I repeat that of course we are concerned about it. We are far more concerned about the disemployment in this situation than the previous Government was when it came to office and threw all those employees of Medibank out of a job in 1975. It did absolutely nothing about the re-employment of those people. We are taking several measures in this area. First, the Health Insurance Commission, which runs Medibank Private, has been requested to offer preference in clerical employment to those people who will be displaced. Of course people will be displaced. We have never hidden that fact.

ANSWER.PARA: Discussions are being held between the Department of Health and the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations on this whole matter of employment preference. We are discussing the matter with the trade union movement-something the previous Government never did. All those trade unions, particularly the clerks' union, that are involved in the private health insurance industry are being considered. The Minister for Health has already had discussions and will continue to have discusssions with State departments of health and State governments about preference for clerical employment. But I remind honourable senators that in this voluntary health insurance area there is a very high turnover of staff-something like 25 per cent. A combination of those measures taken to ensure that people receive employment, plus this high staff turnover, will in fact mean that we will show concern and act on that concern for the unemployment which will be caused by this changeover. But we cannot allow the consumers of health care in this country not to have a fair and equitable health insurance scheme. We intend to proceed with that but, at the same time, to make provision for those who will be directly affected.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General and concerns the Freedom of Information Act. How many requests have been made under the Act since it commenced operation on 1 December 1982? Does the number of requests justify pre-Act concerns about the burden of the Act on agencies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I happen to have some figures available about the number of requests received in the first four months of operation of the Freedom of Information Act. They represent only a tiny fraction of the number of anticipated demands under the new legislation. The total number of requests has been 2,778 until the end of March-an average of 700 a month plus or minus. Requests have been directed to less than a quarter of all government departments and agencies. That is to say, some 75 per cent of government agencies and departments have received not a single request under the legislation. The number of requests certainly has been substantially less than the predictions that were given to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs by the Public Service departments in 1978-79.

ANSWER.PARA: For example, in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs there have been 179 requests in three months as against a prediction to the Senate Standing Committee of an annual number of 103,700. In the Public Service Board there was a prediction of between 2,000 and 5,000 requests per annum. In fact, there have been 34 requests in three months. In the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet there was an estimate of between 1,000 and 2,000 requests per annum. There have been 14 requests in the last three months. However, I think one of the most interesting figures is in relation to the Department of the Treasury. There was a departmental communication at the end of February stating that the work arising out of the FOI Act was proving to be particularly consuming of both time and resources. At that stage Treasury had had 10 requests in three months, as against the prediction of something like 12 per week.

I will say one other thing. The actual pre-Act predictions of increased work load on agencies have not been borne out not only in terms of numbers of requests but also the numbers of staff and resources that have been required to meet the activities arising under the Act. In mid-1982 the Public Service Board, after having been fully aware of the content of the current Act and the predictions of the Department based on the actual text of it, advised that 685 full time Public Service Act positions would be necessary to accommodate the new legislation. Although these bids were best estimates and subject to review within 12 months of the Act coming into operation, to date a number of agencies simply have not taken up their pre-Act staff ceiling allocations.

The six agencies which account for 472 of those positions have filled only 205 of them. Defence, for example, has taken up only 28 of the 75 positions allocated to it. Veterans' Affairs did not take up 50 out of the 79 positions that were allocated to it. That experience has been repeated right across the entire Public Service. So much for floodgates arguments about freedom of information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister table the paper?
—The Leader of the Opposition has asked that the paper from which the Minister was citing figures be tabled.
—I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a more detailed tabular statement of the information on which I was speaking.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The table read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it a fact that approximately 40 per cent of all Australian families- many of them on low incomes-are currently in the process of paying off their homes? Is it also a fact that the Fraser Government's housing interest subsidy had the effect of reducing the interest burden of current home buyers by about 2 per cent? Did the Australian Labor Party give a firm election promise that it would maintain the housing interest subsidy? Will not the removal of the interest subsidy by the Hawke Government, in breach of its election promise I believe, add a substantially higher interest burden to home buyers?

—I am unable to say whether approximately 40 per cent of Australian families are currently paying off their homes, but I believe that to be a fairly accurate estimate. I was asked whether the Fraser Government scheme for home buyers reduced the interest burden by about 2 per cent. I believe that to be so. There was in fact a necessity in the case of most home buyers to reduce their interest burden by much more than 2 per cent under the Fraser Government's economic policies, because the interest rate has never been as great as it was in 1982. The Fraser Government presided over record interest rates in Australia. That is a fact from which I think the Opposition cannot retreat. The Government did give pre-election undertakings that it would initiate schemes which would provide maximum access to home ownership in Australia, and we believe we have done that in the course of the May statement which was released last Thursday.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce, refers to the motor vehicle industry. In light of the difficult situation faced by car manufacturers in Australia, does the Minister believe that there are any prospects of mergers or other rationalisations in the Australian motor vehicle industry? What effect does the Government believe such changes would have on the long term interests of this industry?

—Yes, I do believe that there is a capacity for mergers to take place within the motor car manufacturing industry in Australia. It is not my task to suggest how those mergers should be accomplished at this stage. If there are mergers of the activities of motor car manufacturing companies in Australia, they will be following trends which have emerged world wide because of the cost of motor car manufacture and the general decline in demand for motor cars throughout the world. I mention, for example, the effective merger agreements between General Motors and Toyota to manufacture in California. I cite other examples between Alfa Romeo and Nissan, and in the United Kingdom between British Leyland and Honda. All I am saying is that there is a world-wide trend towards rationalisation of the activities of the major motor car manufacturing companies. In suggesting that mergers might take place, I think it is also important to consider that there is always the capacity, even without formal mergers, to arrange for cross-sourcing of supplies to motor manufacturing companies. For example, General Motors-Holden's Ltd has been supplying engines to Australian Motor Industries Ltd, a Mitsubishi subsidiary, and another company has been supplying shock absorbers to all producers in Australia. Those sorts of rationalisations of the manufacture of component parts of motor cars have been taking place under the existing schemes within the industry. What the Government looks forward to, of course, is a motor car industry in Australia which is rationally organised, efficient and employs a secure work force well into the future. To do that the industry will have to be perhaps more competitive and more efficient than it has been in the past. We hope that in conjunction with the sorts of things that I have suggested those things will take place.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It follows his failure to answer specifically parts of the previous question from the Opposition. Does the Minister recall his party's election commitment to provide the existing tax concessions on mortgage interest payments ? Can he indicate whether, in the light of that commitment, the Government will review the decision announced last week to terminate those concessions, the effect of which will be to increase mortgage interest rates at a stroke by up to 2 per cent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not personally recall that pre-election commitment.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition senators might laugh. I would like to hear them recall some of their pre-election commitments. That would be an interesting exercise. I will certainly jog my memory for Senator Hill about the first part of the question before the next Question Time. In answer to the second part of the question, which I take to be the most important part, there will be no review of the Government's decision announced last Thursday.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport aware of statements by the Northern Territory Chief Minister, Mr Everingham, that he intends to sue the Commonwealth in the High Court of Australia over an alleged breach of agreements on the Alice Springs-Darwin railway, and that there were precedents for the Commonwealth building State railway lines at its own cost, for example, the transcontinental line? Does the Minister see any basis of fact in these statements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Robertson has asked a question which clearly is of great interest to the residents of the Northern Territory. Of course, this matter has been substantially exaggerated by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. At no stage has the Government withdrawn its support for the building of the Alice Springs-Darwin railway. In the light of the information that became available to it after the election-instead of inheriting a $4.5 billion deficit it found itself faced with a $9.5 billion deficit-the Government has had to recast its attitude in respect of a whole number of public works activities. We have not withdrawn our support for the construction of the railway. What we have done is to suggest to the Northern Territory a new arrangement under which the railway can be built. As is usual with Mr Everingham, he shoots from the hip. He does not always speak with any degree of accuracy in his comments relating to his relationships with the Commonwealth Government. When he talks about more than one million Western Australians not contributing to the cost of the east- west transcontinental line he of course ignores the fact that one of the conditions that applied at the time of Federation was that the Commonwealth would accept its responsibilities in respect of the construction of the rail line from Western Australia to the east coast of Australia. Consequently, the Western Australian Government, having accepted its responsibility, provided out of its own funds for the construction of the rail line from Perth to Kalgoorlie.

ANSWER.PARA: Any suggestion that the Northern Territory is being treated differently from what Western Australia was at the time of Federation is incorrect. I remind the Senate that at the beginning of the century a lot of reluctant colonies had to be persuaded to come into the Federation. One of the conditions was that the Commonwealth accept responsibility in regard to the construction of that rail line. That is not the position with respect to the Northern Territory.

I remind honourable senators that the Commonwealth Government pays per capita to the Northern Territory something in excess of $5,600, which is five times the average amount paid to the other States per capita, in terms of tax reimbursements. So the Commonwealth has in no way reneged on its responsibilities. It has suggested a form of financing of that construction and has suggested to the Northern Territory Government that it has the legal power to raise the funds in the form of loans, either from the Commonwealth or elsewhere. The Commonwealth has indicated that it would assist in that process.

I also remind the honourable senator that the Commonwealth has already built the Tarcoola-Alice Springs section of 830 kilometres at no cost to the Northern Territory. The contribution sought from the Northern Territory should not be seen as a contribution of 40 per cent of the cost of construction. In real terms it represents only a contribution from the Northern Territory of some 25 per cent. Senator Kilgariff and his confreres in the Northern Territory, including Mr Everingham, are completely astray in their critisicisms of the attitude taken by the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question which has been prompted by some of the comments by our friends on the other side of the chamber . I ask the Minister to indicate to us how much of the building of railways since 1911 has been initiated by the other party opposite?

—The construction of railways has always been a responsibility of the States. Of course the Northern Territory wants to be regarded as a State. It is regarded by the Commonwealth as a State, and therefore it should accept its share of responsibility, as indeed all the States have done in regard to the construction of their public railway systems.

—Is the Minister representing both the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance aware of the different attitude being taken by the Australian Taxation Office in relation to donations of cash as distinct from donations in kind for the victims of the Victorian and South Australian bushfires? To give an example, there was an appeal for fodder and dairy cattle for the farming victims and a number of dairy farmers, including Tasmanians, made contributions of dairy cattle. Is it a fact that the Australian Taxation Office has decided to interpret certain provisions in the Income Tax Assessment Act so as to require farmers who make donations of farm produce and livestock to charitable appeals to pay tax on the value of such gifts? If so, is that not distinct from the attitude of the Commonwealth in respect of these appeals?

—In reply to the first part of Senator Harradine's question, I am not aware of what distinctions, if any, the Taxation Office is drawing between donations of cash and donations in kind. I will seek that information from the Minister. I can, however, see that an argument could be mounted for making a distinction between the two types of donations. Expenses incurred by a farmer in producing the two commodities that Senator Harradine has cited-fodder and animals-have been tax deductible. If, in addition to that, the item that was donated was allowed as a tax deduction at full market price there would be an element of double counting. Whether that is the basis for the Taxation Office's distinction, if in fact it draws such a distinction, I do not know. But I just raise the point that that could well be the case. I will seek a definitive answer from the Minister.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry aware of the concern of some Tasmanian farmers who have shown great initiative in establishing a multi-million-dollar onion export industry. Their concern is that New Zealand onion growers are undermining the viability of the Tasmanian industry by dumping onions on the Australian market. Do closer economic relations with New Zealand require any sector of the Australian agriculture, fishing or timber industries to accept any level of imports detrimental to those sectors? Will the Minister acknowledge the need for a viable and diversified agricultural sector in Tasmania with all the multiplier effects in employment, especially in this era of post-hydro- industrialisation?

—I am not sure whether this question should be directed to the Minister for Primary Industry or the Minister for Trade, but I represent both, anyway, so either way I can answer. The matter to which Senator Tate has referred has been brought to my notice. The middle part of his question-I paraphrase it-was: Do Australian industries have to accept any level of import competition under any circumstances? The answer is that provision is made within the CER agreement under which action can be taken. I am not familiar with all the details, but it is required that the country taking the action to restrict imports must determine firstly that a local industry, actual or potential, has been harmed and that dumping is in fact taking place. There is also a very comprehensive obligation on the country contemplating such action to notify the other party to the agreement both very fully in detail and very quickly. If any action is taken it has to be reviewed at the end of about six months. I will contact the Minister for Trade and the Minister for Primary Industry and see whether they have anything to add to that reply. If they do, I will provide it to Senator Tate.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Can the Government indicate when telephone charges will rise as announced in last week's mini-Budget? Will postal charges rise for a similar reason? Were any estimates made, before this decision was taken, of the effect of these rises on small business? If so, what were those estimates?

—In answer to the first part of the question, I am unable to say when telephone charges will rise. That is a matter for Telecom Australia to determine. It will depend very much on Telecom's availability of capital to carry out its current works programs. I am asked whether postal charges will rise on the same basis. I believe not. The answer to the third part of the question, as to whether a small business impact study was done in respect of postal and telephone charges, is no, because the first two questions were not strictly before us. Of course, the overall economic impact of last week's statement in respect of small and large business and all sectors of the community was taken into account. The guiding philosophy of the statement was that there should be a sharing of the burdens of the current economic difficulties.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it from that answer that it was not considered that the interests of small business warranted a special investigation.
—I say to honourable senators that the supplementary questions are becoming a bit loose. I am going to watch them more closely in future. I call the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

—I have already indicated that the interests of all sectors of the community were taken into account in preparing the economic statement. Seeing Senator MacGibbon is trying to make a big fellow of himself, presumably, with small business by asking these questions, I might say that the interests of small business were taken into account quite specifically in relation to a number of matters considered prior to the making of the economic statement. Of course, one of the things which small business has suffered from most, amongst others, is the high level of inflation which this Government inherited from the previous Government. That matter was specifically taken into account in dealing with the economic statement.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Prior to the March election, did the then Opposition indicate that, on becoming the Government, it would remove the entrance fee to the Australian National Gallery, a fee which was imposed by the Fraser Government? Is a fee payable for entry to other Australian Government buildings of national significance in Canberra, for example, the Australian War Memorial, the National Library of Australia and the Royal Australian Mint? Does the Government intend to remove the entrance fee to the Australian National Gallery and, if so, when?

—The answer to the honourable senator's first question is yes. It was a part of the Government's pre-election undertaking to remove the entrance fee to the National Gallery. The answer to the second part of the honourable senator's question is no. No other national institutions in the Australian Capital Territory have such an entrance fee.
—Not even Parliament.

—Not even Parliament, as my colleague Senator Evans points out. Nor is it the intention of the Government to impose an entrance fee on Parliament or any of the other national institutions. As to the timetable for the Government's implementation of its intention to wipe out the entrance fee to the National Gallery, I will have to consult the Minister who is responsible for this area, Mr Barry Cohen. I will let Senator Colston know as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it true that the Government intends to review family allowances with a view to imposing taxation on them or restricting eligibility?

—All matters of Government economic policy will be dealt with in the context of the forthcoming Budget. As far as I am aware, it is not the intention of the Government to review family allowances in any particular respect. But, of course, family allowances, like all other government benefits, will be considered in the overall context of the Budget. Senator Watson and other honourable senators will, of course, be informed in due course if there is any decision in relation to family allowances or any other allowances which the Government seeks to review.
—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Defence give further details of an incident involving the shelling of the HMAS Buccaneer by one of its own guns?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not entirely unknown for people to shoot themselves in the foot but to my knowledge this is the first time it has happened to a ship .
—The Government is doing it regularly.

—Oh, Shirley, you are so acute. The information available to me from the Department of Defence is as follows: HMAS Buccaneer, an attack class patrol boat based in Darwin, was taking part in a squadron task element exercise in the Beagle Gulf area when, on 23 May during a saluting gun practice evolution-whatever that is-it accidentally fired a 40 millimetre Bofors round through its forecastle bulwark plating. I hope Senator Hamer will correct my pronunciation if I have all that wrong. The evolution had taken place with Buccaneer using high explosive fitted with tracer-HET-rounds instead of breakup shot or practice weighed and plugged-PNP-ammunition. The accident occurred when gun clearing procedures were being carried out. The gun had been trained on a safe bearing but it was not sufficiently elevated.

ANSWER.PARA: Damage to Buccaneer was restricted to a 40mm diameter hole through the bulwark plating. No injury to personnel took place. The HET round did not detonate on impact with the bulwark because the round's safety and arming device would not have allowed the fuse to be armed after travelling for such a short time. Buccaneer's participation in the squadron exercises was not affected by the incident. The squadron returned to Darwin on 25 May on completion of the exercises. An investigation into the cause of the accident is taking place and a further report will be forwarded to the Department of Defence when the results of the inquiry have been forwarded to Navy Office.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Can the Government indicate whether it expects any further prices and costs to rise as a result of its mini-Budget last week in addition to telephone charges, superannuation, mortgages, health insurance, air fares and petrol prices in non-metropolitan areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without conceding any particular item in the extraordinary list which has been read to us by Senator Lajovic, the answer is no.

ANSWER.PARA: Sitting suspended from 1.1 to 2.15 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Allegations made yesterday by a Mr Volkman before the Stewart Royal Commission into the Activities of Nugan Hand, to the effect that he had been intimidated from the highest level have been widely reported in the media both last night and today. His allegations have involved the Leader of the National Party, Mr Anthony, and the honourable member for Farrer, Mr Fife. However, it appears that the allegations of intimidation have been directed principally at myself as a result of a prosecution brought by me against Mr Volkman and others when I was Attorney-General. Similar allegations were made by the present Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) in the House of Representatives last October and November. At the time, I was convalescing and I was unable to answer them. I completely repudiate these allegations which make the gravest reflections upon me.

SPEECH.PARA: The facts are these: Mr Volkman and four others were charged with conspiring together and with one other person in 1979 to export Australian native birds, which are a prohibited export. Conspiracy charges were laid under section 86 of the Crimes Act and, in the circumstances, carried a maximum penalty of three years' imprisonment. Committal proceedings on the conspiracy charges were heard before a magistrate in Sydney in 1980. At the end of the proceedings, the magistrate found a prima facie case against all defendants but declined to commit them for trial.

On 13 July 1981, acting on firm advice from a most experienced senior counsel, Mr R. J. Marr, Q.C., I signed an ex officio indictment against all defendants. This was not the only case in which an ex officio indictment was presented by me when I was Attorney-General. One consequence that can follow an ex officio indictment-namely, that the accused does not have the benefits that go with committal proceedings-did not apply in the case of Mr Volkman.

On 10 May 1982, one of the accused pleaded guilty to the conspiracy charge. He was subsequently released on a bond to be of good behaviour for three years and he had to pay a fine of $1,000. The trial of the remaining accused, including Mr Volkman, commenced on 10 May 1982 but, on the application of the accused, the jury was discharged before the trial was completed. The retrial of the accused commenced on 13 September 1982 and concluded on 12 October 1982. At the close of the Crown case, the trial judge directed that one of the accused be acquitted but found that there was a case to answer in respect of the remaining accused, including Mr Volkman. After deliberating for six and a half hours the jury returned verdicts of not guilty against the remaining accused, again including Mr Volkman. The charges against the accused were serious and it was clearly proper for the prosecution to be brought. My decision to proceed with the trial was made on the advice of senior counsel. The trial judge ruled that there was a case for Mr Volkman to answer. I utterly repudiate the allegation of malice by me in the prosecution of Mr Volkman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Last night in another place the honourable member for Braddon, Mr Ray Groom, made an allegation, as I see it, against my character and my integrity. In the course of a five-minute contribution on the subject of the decision by this Government not to proceed with the upgrading of Wynyard Airport, which five minutes he devoted to a tirade of abuse against me rather than mounting any argument concerning the case for the Wynyard Airport, he stated, amongst other things:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tate . . .
Was: party to this false promise . . .
He stated further that I:
. . . had advance knowledge that this promise was likely to be broken . . .

At no stage have I been a party to any false or deliberate misleading of the Tasmanian public or of my constituents. I was never a party to any contrived deception in this regard. I was a party to the undertaking which the Government has decided up to this point will not be proceeded with because of compelling economic arguments regarding the Budget deficit. I was not a party to a false promise.

As to the allegation that I had advance knowledge that this promise was likely to be broken, that is also false. From departmental contacts-I am sure Mr Ray Groom is as aware of the rumours as I am-I knew that the Wynyard Airport project was vulnerable. Being concerned I sought a conference with the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley), Mr Hugh Loane, the Master Warden of the Burnie Marine Board, Mr Brian Loring, the Executive Secretary of that Board and Mr Ray Groom on Tuesday of last week, which meeting took place. At no stage was I privy to any decision by the Government. Indeed, the Minister was completely honest and thoroughly infuriating in not indicating what the Government's decision in this matter would be. As I have said, to that extent I have been grossly misrepresented in the statement made by Mr Groom last night.
