DEBATE.TITLE: GOVERNMENT PROPOSALS: IMPACT ON FAMILY INCOMES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President has received a letter from Senator Messner proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The disastrous impact on family incomes of the Government's mini-Budget proposals and, in particular, the abolition of the home interest and the health insurance rebates.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of the mini-Budget brought down last Thursday, it is likely that the average family in Australia will be worse off to the tune of almost $20 a week. This figure results from a calculation of the costs of the abolition of the housing rebate, the health insurance rebate, a rise in the threshold of concessional expenditure rebate and other incidental rises that have resulted from what might be termed 'Keating's kickshaw'. The Government should note that the people of Australia simply will not swallow this package. I note in today's Press the comments of the Secretary of the New South Wales Trades and Labour Council, Mr Barrie Unsworth about the superannuation changes announced in this mini-Budget. Clearly, he was making the point that the Whitlam Government's decision of a 25 per cent tariff cut was just as disastrous to the electoral prospects of the Whitlam Government as this decision is likely to be for the Hawke Government. Of course, we are facing a by -election this coming Saturday. This may well be the litmus test for the mini- Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: This mini-Budget represents an attack on the thrifty. If people save their money, invest in their retirement, invest in their health, invest in sending their children to school, invest in the jobs of others by investing in Australian industry as small stockholders if people work hard to increase their incomes to save for homes, they are the people who will be penalised. As we all know, this has come at a time when the average Australian can least afford it. The mini-Budget presented by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was one of the most amazing documents that has ever been presented to this Parliament. While it was portrayed as a simple exercise in expenditure restraint, it was nothing more than an exercise in raising taxes-taxes that will be paid for by all Australians . The business editor of the Age, Terry McCrann, has been one of the few journalists not to be duped by last Thursday's statement. He said yesterday:
. . . on Thursday night, Paul Keating, spoke of savings on the 'expenditure and tax expenditure programs' of the previous Government which would total $985m in 1983-84.

'Mr Keating could have expressed this slightly differently. He could have said cuts in spending would slice $532m off expenditure in 1983-84 while removal of various tax concessions-more explicitly, tax increases-would add $452m to revenue.'

Under the mini-Budget those tax increases will rise dramatically in the years 1984-85 and beyond. Tax increases will amount to $1,437m in 1984-85 and $1,590m in 1985-86. The Australian people need to have that fact brought to their attention because they are the ones who will have to pay the increased taxes that are hidden in this mini-Budget.

That shift brought about in the mini-Budget of higher taxes has come about despite an election commitment. We know how worthless those are of course, as evidenced by Senator Button's remarks in this place this morning when he could not even remember what the promises were. But he did say that one of the promises was an immediate reduction in income tax for six million Australians. Now ten weeks later taxes are increased by $0.5 billion. I point to three areas- housing, health and concessional expenditure rebates-in which, in one stroke, those same 6 million people will face immediate tax increases. The housing rebate is an example. As a result of the abolition of the housing interest rate rebate the average first home buyer will be worse off by $6 a week. This figure assumes that he or she has a loan of $30,000 and is based on an interest rate of only 13.5 per cent. Both of those figures are reasonably conservative in today's world. The Government's decision to abolish the rebate has, in one stroke-this is tacitly acknowledged by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford )-put up interest rates effectively by 2 per cent.

Let us consider the case of a person who borrows $50,000 and is required to pay to a building society or bank an interest rate approaching 14.5 per cent. The extra cost to that person will be $13 per week. A person who borrows even $20, 000 at the same rate of interest will suffer increased costs of $5.20 per week. So a range of taxpayers will suffer a very significant loss of income as a result of the abolition of the rebate. This is occurring at a time when interest rates are still very high and under pressure. The effect of the decision upon those first home buyers who decided to purchase a house because the rebate was in existence is utterly immeasurable. I ask the Government to consider that situation. There is no doubt that the scheme assisted many people to make the decision to buy their own house.

This decision by the Government, which is so disastrous, will affect families. It is not simply the view of the Opposition. Last Friday a spokesman for the Australian Taxpayers Association, Mr Robin Logan, stated:
This mini-budget will hit the average family man-the man who is most likely to spend to get this country going again.

Another alarming matter is the decision to abolish the special home loan interest tax rebate which was introduced by the Fraser Government in March last year specifically to aid low income first home buyers. This special rebate is to be abolished from 30 September until the new First Home Ownership Assistance Scheme comes into effect. The Treasurer stated in the course of his address last week:
We have placed emphasis on . . . directing assistance to those in need and on removing unwarranted concessions.
In relation to the housing package generally, he stated:
Assistance will be directed to those most in need.

Clearly, that is an objective which all of us would have. Yet the Government, in its rush to raise revenue and increase taxes in the mini-Budget, has cut out a program directly assisting, and designed to assist, those most in need. Again, I refer specifically to the package brought in last March.

One of the main reasons for the change in policies in the housing area is allegedly to provide more funding for the whole area. Let us examine that situation. It is simply not true. In 1983-84 it is true that an extra $77m will be provided in the Budget for housing. But in later years the position changes dramatically. In 1984-85 savings from the abolition of the home rebates and the Home Deposit Assistance Scheme will amount to $240m; that is, a net loss to the housing sector of $420m. The new assistance scheme will entail an expenditure of $165m, leaving a surplus in favour of revenue of $255m. Part of this amount will obviously go towards welfare housing. But how much? The Government has not spelt that out. Let us assume that it might entail an amount of $150m-an increase of 20 per cent-which is by no means an ungenerous figure over last year's amount. That would still mean a net reduction in housing funds of about $100m. Similarly , in 1985-86, without an allocation to be determined for welfare housing, overall savings would be about $265m. How can Australians be convinced, in the light of that information, that this Government has been generous in the housing area? It has implemented a superficially attractive scheme which, when examined, actually makes savings to revenue in the whole housing area. This illusion was recognised in the editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald last Friday, which stated:

The element of illusion in the housing package is simply the extent to which it will assist first-home buyers. Despite Mr Keating's assurances to the contrary, the additional demand for housing must, to some extent, push up home prices. Part of the benefit will go to existing home-owners. It is, of course, also absurd to regard anyone who is within striking distance of acquiring a home as being in urgent need of the taxpayer's assistance. They must, at least, have a job and a fair amount of money in their savings account to be able to take on a housing loan, even a heavily-subsidised housing loan.
Again, the Minister for Housing and Construction, in answer to a question asked in the House yesterday, said that the package would have a downward thrust on interest rates. He stated further:
A one per cent reduction in interest rates will have far greater effect for the vast majority of Australians than will any general tax rebate.

Is the Minister, who is not exactly known for his success in the area of economic policy, guaranteeing Australians a reduction in interest rates? Is he saying that interest rates will be lowered and that that will offset the disadvantages? Is that what he would have us believe? Is he telling people that his policies will do this?

The abolition of the health insurance rebate will cost the average family which has basic private medical and hospital insurance some $5 to $6 a week next year. It has been brought in six months before it was necessary. It removes an incentive for people to enter health insurance schemes in the six months between July and the introduction of Medicare on 1 January. This will obviously have a very costly effect on many people in the community. The decision to abolish the rebate will obviously increase the overall costs of families. Medicare, or Hayden's 'Medibank Revisited', or, as some people call it, 'Mediaeval', will provide Australians with 85 per cent of medical and hospital cover, paid for by the levy. It is supposed to be a one per cent levy. But the private funds suggest that that figure is unrealistic, given the enormous administrative costs involved in the operation, now that the Minister has rejected moves for the offices of private funds to be agents for Medicare. But people requiring optometrical, dental or other services will have to take out extra private insurance. Without the rebate, costs will not be offset and people will be discouraged from taking the necessary extra cover. The results of that could be potentially disastrous.

I turn to the concessional expenditure rebate. The increase in that rebate threshold from $1,590 to $2,000 will result in a tax increase of $136.60 per annum for each individual who falls into that category. Fifty per cent of income earners who earn an average salary below $6,000 per annum and who were able to claim concessional expenditure rebates are $136.60, or nearly $3 a week, worse off. That is based on 1980-81 figures. Nearly 50 per cent of income earners earning between $9,000 and $11,999 per annum-very modest levels of income-who were able to claim concessional expenditure rebates are, again, $136.60, or nearly $3 a week, worse off. Of income earners at or below the level of the average wage earner who were able to claim concessional expenditure rebates 54.5 per cent will be $3 a week worse off. Raising more tax from so-called low income earners is what this mini-Budget is about. The general concessional rebate was introduced to make a more equitable distribution of the tax burden. That was acknowledged as a fair thing when it was introduced in the Hayden Budget of 1975 . This mini-Budget reverses that process and goes down the way of laying increased tax burdens upon low income individuals. The increase in that threshold is, I believe, a direct attack upon the self-employed, the small businessman who, by taking out insurance and superannuation, prepares for his and his family's future security. These people do not have the advantages enjoyed by public servants and workers in large industries. They must fend for themselves. The Government has made their task, particularly, harder.
Let me turn to the superannuation payments. Last Thursday night the Treasurer stated:
We have been determined not to rush into decisions which require more thorough study and deliberation.

Yet, on the same evening, he committed the Government to a decision with respect to superannuation which has all the hallmarks of a decision made without study and without deliberation. Obviously there are other costs in the Budget-my colleagues will deal with those matters-which have to be borne by the family. Telephone charges are but one of those matters. I do not remember them as being part of any election promise. But, as we were told today, election promises are very hard to remember once one gets into government.

The mini-Budget will have many indirect effects on family budgets as well. It will push up prices. It will increase the demand for higher wages. Inflation may well be affected by the mini-Budget and interest rates could rise as a result. All of these factors will have a very costly effect on the average Australian family. It could well be that that $20 a week figure is just the beginning. In this mini-Budget Labor has reneged on all those who supported it on 5 March. Then it captured, as it claims, the middle ground of the electorate. It is now squeezing those people dry. The Government stands condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GRIMES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that Senator Messner and the Opposition really take the prize for cheek this afternoon in producing a matter of public importance with this sort of wording at this time. (Quorum formed). The MPI states:

SPEECH.PARA: The disastrous impact on family incomes of the Government's mini-Budget proposals and, in particular, the abolition of the home interest and the health insurance rebates.

I think this MPI is a bit rich coming from Senator Messner, who was a Minister in the previous Government, whose polices had such a disastrous effect on the economy of this country and on the well-being of all but a few wealthy people. Such was the effect of the previous Government's policies and actions that I would like to remind supporters of that Government that they were tipped out of office on 5 March, at an early election, an election of their calling in which the Australian Labor Party received a huge swing and the mandate of the people. On a Wednesday afternoon so soon after that election we have the Opposition coming in to this chamber pretending that it has some concern about family incomes and about the economic situation of families. Yet it was the previous Government which, over seven years, created the greatest tax rip-off in Australia's history. The Government that we have just deposed saddled the incoming Government, the Labor Government, with the monstrous deficit we have to face. This deficit is largely the result of uninhibited vote buying in the 1982 Budget and the disastrous economic policies of the previous Government. In 1975 Mr Fraser promised:
We will reduce the tax burden . . . We will fully index personal income tax for inflation over three years.
In 1977 he said:
We have ended the big tax rip-off . . . The Government will bring taxes down further-not increase them.

What happened? In the Fraser Government's seven years in office it collected more taxes than the total collection of all governments for the prior 74 years. Tax indexation in those few years in which it was practised was, in fact, a sad farce. As a percentage of national income, tax receipts rose from 23.3 per cent in Labor's 1975 Budget to an estimated 25.5 per cent in the coalition Government 's 1982 Budget. This was despite the massive tax avoidance and evasion industry that flourished in those years. In this time pay-as-you-earn taxpayers were the hardest hit. These are the ordinary families about whom Senator Messner was allegedly talking. Over this time the increases cost Australians $4,000m a year, an extra $17 a week for an average household. Now this Opposition comes into this chamber and professes concern about the living standards of families and the amount of taxation they will have to pay. The fact is that the coalition Government left this country in such a parlous state that we are faced with no real choice except to try to distribute the burden-the burden being the cost of the previous Government's incompetence-more equitably.

Let us look at those costs. This year the Australian economy has actually contracted for the first time in 30 years. Each percentage point loss of potential growth means a $1.5 billion loss of national output and a huge cost to the budget in lost taxes and, in fact, higher unemployment benefits. In the 1982 Budget, unemployment benefits were estimated to cost just less than $1.6 billion . At that time we recognised that this was an absurd estimate. That very Budget night we pointed out that it was an absurd estimate. It proved to be more so as the economy dropped through the floor. So two adjustments later we have come to the present situation where the cost is estimated to be $2.2 billion-even more than we thought possible when the Budget came down last year. In fact, these estimates may be very conservative. That is just part of the cost of unemployment. How much greater are the individual and social costs of three quarters of a million Australians out of work-some 10.3 per cent of the labour force? That result is entirely due to the economic failures of the previous Government.

Let no one in this chamber or anywhere else be in any doubt about just what those failures were. First, an erratic and generally contractionary money and fiscal policy was conducted over the years and this added to rather than counteracted other fundamental factors which were inducing recession at the time . In the face of a steep and prolonged international recession Australia experienced a loss of international competitiveness brought on by the appreciation of our currency which was compounded for some time by an acceleration in our costs relative to those of our major trading partners. The resource boom euphoria, which was induced by the previous Government and which those of us in the chamber heard Senator Sir John Carrick drumming up every day at Question Time and whenever he had the opportunity, was a major contributing factor to these sorts of developments. The inflationary consequences were met by that Government with a tight monetary policy which resulted in higher interest rates, which further contributed to higher business costs and which severely affected the housing industry and every other industry in this community. The result was a severe squeeze on business cash flows and profits and the massive retrenchments that we in this country have been facing over the last few years.

With the economy in a tail spin, it is no wonder that the Budget deficit had blown out. This, of course, was exacerbated, as I have said, by the tax expenditures which were entered into by the previous Government in the last Budget in a desperate attempt to hold office. It concealed from the Australian public the true costs of this spending spree by making sure that the bulk of the costs, about $3,000m, would first come to account next financial year. When it was revealed that the true extent of the 1983-84 deficit was likely to be $10 billion, Mr Howard, Mr Fraser and Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle conspired to conceal this fact too, not only from the then Opposition but also from the public at large. Only weeks before the election Mr Howard was talking about a likely deficit of the order of $6 billion and was suggesting in fact that that was too high. We do not have the obsession that Mr Fraser and Mr Howard allegedly had with Budget deficits, but we recognise that we need to achieve a reasonable balance between the financial demands of the public sector and the private sector. We know the likely effects on interest rates if that balance is not achieved.

The Opposition cannot have it both ways. It said it would have taken steps to reduce the 1983 deficit. Before the election Mr Howard spoke in terms of a maximum deficit of 3 per cent of gross domestic product, which would have meant a deficit of $5 billion-not $10 billion. We must first ask Opposition senators, before they bleat here in the way they have done, what they would have done to reduce the deficit. What taxes would they have raised to reduce the deficit? What expenditures would they have cut? One can sell something like the Belconnen Mall only so many times. One has to raise taxes or cut expenditures if one is to cut the deficit. Senator Messner and his colleagues can throw stones at the Labor Party's measures, as they have done. I point out that every single item in the economic package which was brought down last Thursday night has been opposed by one or other member of the Opposition. Honourable senators from Queensland have been bleating about Brisbane Airport. Looking at the speakers' list, I dare say we will have that again this afternoon. We have heard people talking about the Alice Springs-Darwin railway. We have heard Senator Messner opposing everything in this package. Every single item has been opposed. Is it not then reasonable to ask: What would the Opposition have done? Would it have done nothing? Would it in fact have allowed the deficit to blow out to the $10 billion that it was going to blow out to?

I put it to the Opposition that there has been general support for this economic package. Certainly there is universal support from the housing industry . On listening to Senator Messner this afternoon, one would have thought that the housing industry was in fear and trepidation that it would collapse. In general it supports this package, and Senator Messner knows that. Senator Messner knows that the business community generally has in fact supported the overall effect of this package. Everyone except the extremely conservative economic writers in this country has supported it. Of course, there has been some opposition, fed by the grossly misleading propaganda put out by Senator Martin and Senator Messner today in regard to some people receiving lump sum superannuation payments. We received grossly misleading information from Senator Martin in Question Time today when she implied quite clearly that those who had accrued lump sum payments up until now would be paying tax on them from this day . She is clearly attempting to stir up strife in the community. People will come to realise what it means. All the groups I have mentioned and general community groups have accepted this economic package, but all we have from the Opposition is opposition item by item to everything in the package. We have not heard anything from the Opposition about what it would do.

I repeat: The Opposition cannot have it both ways. Its former Treasurer cannot say that the deficit should be $5 billion; honourable senators opposite cannot say that the deficit of $10 billion is far too high, but that it is not a true deficit; they cannot say: 'Had we been in government we would have reduced it to $6 billion', and at the same time oppose every economic measure that has been produced in this package. We sought savings in areas where those affected can most readily afford to shoulder the burden. In fact we have spread the tax burden as best we can and have had to make difficult decisions in doing so. We have had to face the difficulties for the good of this country. Time after time the previous Government sought to conceal the true costs and extent of its regressive redistributional policies by hiding them in the tax system as tax expenditures. Assistance for health, for housing and for retirement incomes all became increasingly concentrated in the tax system, not for reasons of equity, efficiency or administration, but so that the Australian public would not see what was going on. The Labor Party and the Labor Government believe that, in general, direct expenditures are more accountable and more fair to low income earners than tax expenditures. Our recent moves in housing, health and occupational superannuation illustrate this principle.

Senator Messner spent a long time in his speech making general accusations about the effects of what he sees as an unfortunate economic package. At the end he skated over the main items that he introduced in his matter of public importance. I will treat them in the same way and deal with them now at the end of my speech. I repeat: There has been general support from the housing and the building industries because they realise that the position in which only 106,000 new dwellings were to be commenced in this country in the present financial year could not continue. This is the lowest annual level of housing commencements since 1962-63 and compares with 132,300 in 1981-82 and nearly 150,000 in 1980-81 . The previous Government's combined economic and housing policies had resulted in the last financial year in the lowest number of new dwellings commenced. The previous Government's policies in this area had quite clearly failed. Yet Senator Messner, faced with an economic statement which introduces a new housing scheme and greater expenditure in that area and which distributes that expenditure more efficiently so that people can start new housing, although the scheme is welcomed by the housing industry and the builders, says: 'No, you should not do this. You should go back to what we were doing'. This is despite the fact that what the previous Government was doing resulted in the lowest number of housing starts since 1961-62.

Our housing package removed some of the inequities which were in the previous Government's program and enabled an amount of money to be spent and distributed to those in most need, in particular to first home buyers. The policy is consistent and is aimed at directing scarce resources to the needy. Sure, the general tax rebate scheme will be terminated on 30 June, but this was a highly inequitable scheme. The great bulk of the assistance was going to those high income earners who were able to take out the sorts of high loans about which Senator Messner was talking. Less than 20 per cent of people claimed the rebate through the pay-as-you-earn system, showing that they did not need the rebate to assist them to meet their regular mortgage payments. The average savings bank borrower in Australia will in fact lose about $4 a week through the abolition of this scheme.

We had previous to that the March rebate scheme for first home buyers. In order to meet this Government's social commitments and obligations this scheme will be continued for low income first home buyers who entered it before 1 October. The scheme will continue for low income earners on an income tested basis set at the same level as that for the new first home owners assistance scheme. This will ensure that lower income first home buyers who enter home ownership at the time of high interest rates will continue to receive assistance to the end of their first five years of home ownership. The new package will provide a significant boost to building activity, increase commencements to about 130,000 in 1983-84 and create an additional 25,000 jobs on building sites and in related building industry suppliers. The first home owners assistance scheme and all the other increased expenditure will do this; yet Senator Messner has got up and said: 'We should return to what we had before'. What we had before was inequitable. It was aimed primarily at those who could afford the high loans that Senator Messner was talking about and would result in a disastrous fall in the number of new home starts.

Senator Messner then went on to make great play-he thought-about the health insurance tax rebate. As I said, we were faced with a disastrous budgetary situation which was bequeathed to us by the previous Government. This left us as a government with no alternatives but to make tough decisions on government expenditure. If we were to have the funds available for necessary expenditure on job creation and housing we had to do this. I remind Senator Messner and this chamber that all Australians will receive a full year's tax rebate for their health contributions in this year's tax return. There will be no increase in the out-of-pocket cost of health insurance as a result of the abolition of the rebate and the introduction of Medicare from 1 February will halve the cost of basic health insurance for a family in receipt of $450 a week. So most people will pay less for health insurance in 1983-84 than they pay currently. Senator Messner knows that. This MPI is nonsense. I am sure that the speakers who follow me will demonstrate even further that it is nonsense. I believe that we should dismiss it as such.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The disastrous impact on family incomes of the Government's mini-Budget proposals and, in particular, the abolition of the home interest and the health insurance rebates.

Senator Grimes spent some time at the beginning of his speech on the subject of what the Opposition would have done to reduce the deficit had it been in government. It is not for me to write an alternative Budget for the present Government. Perhaps it would like a few clues-it could probably use some-but I think I can say one thing fairly confidently. This Opposition, had it been in government, would have done the same thing in the first instance as will the present Government, that is, it would have substantially reduced the forward estimates of parliamentary departments, which are the upper level of spending in any event. The Government will not find it very difficult to take several billion dollars from that so-called projected deficit of $9 billion without affecting present policies. Then, of course, it will add in a couple of million dollars new expenditure and claim that it has actually saved money.

The Government's management is not as good as it has claimed. The mini-Budget presented last week was an interesting document in terms of just how quickly this Government has moved to break election promises. There was not much surprise in the Government's moving to break election promises. Indeed, before it was elected, which is quite extraordinary for an incoming government, it made it fairly clear that it would look around to see which promises it considered to be of least priority so that it could break them. What are extraordinary are the targets that the Government has chosen. I would have thought that it was accepted wisdom throughout politics in Australia, whether in the Parliament or in the public at large, that family groups are basic to the welfare of this country in a number of ways. I thought it was accepted wisdom for quite some time that a high priority would be put on home ownership. I would also have thought, from all the debates in this chamber in the last year, that there was a quite good awareness amongst those who are now in government of the effect that higher interest rates have on people's ability to own homes.

Let us make no mistake about it; this Government has, through this mini-Budget, increased taxes. Removing a tax rebate, which means that someone pays more tax, is the same as increasing taxes. The Government has increased government revenue by $452m through this mini-Budget, that is, the Government take is $452m higher. That squares rather strangely with the promises made by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, during the election campaign of an immediate reduction in income tax for six million Australians. What we have is dashed expectations for all and a particularly disastrous impact on families. In an article in last Friday's Melbourne Herald Mr Robin Logan of the Australian Taxpayers Association was reported as having said:
This mini-Budget will hit the average family man-the man who is most likely to spend to get this country going again.

The average family-we are talking about average income and average size-is a dedicated consuming unit. It spends its money, and it spends it on things such as housing because it has to. That represents a high proportion of the family's income but in doing that the family is fulfilling its dream of owning its own home. Early this afternoon we had the extraordinary spectacle of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), the principal spokesman for the Government in the Senate, not being able to remember the Government's election promises on various items-not obscure items, not little nooks and crannies in the election campaign, but basic stuff such as housing interest rebates and health insurance rebates; stuff which was concentrated on during the election campaign and to which the then Opposition, now the Government, was pressed to give its attitudes. The then Opposition, now the Government, gave its attitudes. I really find it difficult to believe that leading members of the Government can no longer remember what they were saying on the subject of health insurance rebates and mortgage interest rebates. Someone really ought to send all members of the Australian Labor Party in this Federal Parliament copies of their own policy speech and of their major statements during the campaign.

There are a number of areas in which this mini-Budget will hit the family and hit it hard, thus reducing the family's disposable income. Senator Messner, leading for the Opposition in this debate, has outlined a number of them. I wish to refer just briefly to one of the matters which were touched on this afternoon again in Question Time and which will affect most Australians and certainly families. I refer to telephone charges. When Senator Button was asked whether the Government could indicate when telephone charges were likely to rise as a result of last week's mini-Budget, he said that really that was up to Telecom Australia, that that was Telecom's decision. If ever there was a three card trick it is this one. Telecom will have to increase local telephone calls, it is estimated, by one cent a call, STD calls on a proportional basis and rentals by $10 a period as a direct result of government action. This Government is increasing its revenue from Telecom sufficiently to force Telecom to implement those sorts of increases. It is all very well for Senator Button to say that increases are Telecom's decision. There really is no difference in kind from the Government having made the decision, a very conscious decision, to take extra revenue out of telephone users' pockets. Telecom may actually issue the bills but the fact is that increased charges will be specifically because of this Government's decision, as announced in last Thursday's mini-Budget, and not because of some general cost increase or because of general circumstances. It is almost an arms length taxation policy, Mr Acting Deputy President. In fact Australians and Australian families will know when they regularly pay those higher charges through the year that it is directly as a result of Government action.

The abolition of the health insurance rebate will cost each average family an additional $3 a week. That is $3 a week they will not have in their pockets and it is that much extra revenue the Government will have. It amounts to a tax increase. That increase is not, I reiterate, in line with Mr Hawke's very clear and firm promise of immediate tax reductions for six million Australians. Instead there will be a substantial and almost immediate tax increase for millions of Australian families.
The Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, has been quoted as saying:
Medicare will be introduced early next year, and by the time the rebate would have become payable most Australians would have had reduced health costs for over six months.
I shall not dwell on just what brand of cynicism Dr Blewett has displayed in that statement, but I should like to comment on a couple of aspects of it. First of all, he said:
. . . most Australians would have had reduced health costs for over six months.

That is if they go to a doctor or to the hospital and accept the public health system, and do not choose private health care instead. They will not experience reduced costs in their health insurance. On the contrary, the indications are very clear; they will experience increased health costs for their health insurance. They will also pay a tax levy of at least one per cent on top of the tax that they are paying at the moment. They will be very aware very quickly of the fact that they will pay extra tax for health care they may or may not need in that period.

I query the daring of the Health Minister to refer also to 'most Australians'. How does he know most Australians who need health care in that period will avail themselves of the public health system? Is he so sure that most will not insure or is the Government trying to make it so much more expensive that most Australians are forced out of the private funds? If that happens, will the Government therefore make the next daring conclusion that most Australians would prefer to have Medicare to the present arrangement of a reasonably priced, although not cheap, health insurance?

If Dr Blewett is tempted to think that, I suggest that he take a brief glance at the situation in Queensland, particularly as it used to obtain. The situation is that for decades Queenslanders have had and have been conditioned by access to free medical and hospital treatment if they need it. When they also had access to reasonably priced health insurance the behaviour of Queenslanders was very interesting. A lower percentage than national average had hospital insurance-that is, they took a chance on the extremity of having to go to hospital. However, the medical insurance pattern of Queenslanders, even though they had free medical treatment, was similar to the national medical insurance pattern. In other words, people who had been conditioned for a long time to access to free medical care nevertheless chose to take private medical insurance at least, and a substantial proportion of them also chose to take private hospital insurance.

If, as a result of the introduction of Medicare and the other economic policies of this Government, families cease to take private health insurance, I do not think Dr Blewett can console himself with the thought that he has brought in something more attractive. On the contrary, it will mean that he has priced private health care and private health insurance out of the reach of average families. That is one issue that will have an impact on family incomes, and it is probably one that people will decide that they have to dispense with. Does the Government really think people will not notice in that six month period, as indicated by Dr Blewett, that they are paying more tax each week, courtesy of the tax levy, and that at the end of the taxation period they will have a lower taxation rebate than they otherwise would?

Of course, an area in which most of these families who are affected by this mini-Budget will give a high priority to not changing their present pattern of consumption is that of home ownership. Most Australians will, if they own a home , try to keep it at any cost. The Labor Party gave a firm election promise that it would maintain the mortgage interest tax rebate. It has broken that promise. Whilst Australians might put a high priority on owning their own homes, the Hawke Government-(Quorum formed).

Mr Acting Deputy President, I say in conclusion that Senator Robertson has managed to interrupt everything I had to say in relation to housing rebates because Government senators were not interested in this debate on the impact on family incomes of the Government's mini-Budget proposals. If Senator Robertson had not called a quorum two minutes before the end of my allocated time, I would have been able to detail those matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't waste it. Get on with it.

—We had to wait. I now have five seconds. What is the point? I will not be cut off in the middle of my argument. Senator Hamer, who will follow from this side in this debate, will, I am sure, deal with the subject more than adequately. The Government will have to listen to the effects of its own decisions, the impact that its policies have had on families and the effect that they will have on the opportunities for ordinary Australians to own their own homes.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it remarkable that the honourable senator opposite actually talked about this Government breaking pre- election promises after the challenge that I had answered so well this morning in terms of what her Government did with Medibank. Opposition senators should well know a broken election promise! The other claim that Senator Martin laid on us was that the average family man is the one who will spend us out of recession . Bless her heart! He has had a long time to do it, and he certainly is not doing it. The inflation that the previous Government lumped on us made sure that no average family man was about to spend anywhere.

SPEECH.PARA: What I find interesting about honourable senators opposite is that they fail to realise that this Government is quite unashamedly changing the incomes of various families in this community. Higher income families are faced with the fact that they will redistribute their incomes to lower income families. At the same time we will produce a redistribution of money into the building industry to create not only jobs but also houses in the public and private sectors. The Government unashamedly sets out to do that. That is its principal election promise. It realises that the biggest damage in our community is caused by unemployment and is a vestige of the previous Government's seven years in office . That is what it has principally addressed itself to. The previous Government had seven years. Senator Messner, who proposed this matter of public importance, was part of that Government. He had the opportunity to protect family incomes, to guarantee jobs and incomes to all Australians. What did he and his Government do? They allowed unemployment to rise at an ever-increasing rate, till it reached the disastrous figure that it is now. In April 1983 we had 10.2 per cent unemployment-a total of 707,300 unemployed people. Tell me about their family incomes, Senator. That is only the measured figure too; it does not take into account the hidden unemployment that is assessed by many to be at least equal to the measured unemployment. Again I ask honourable senators opposite: What did that do to family income under their Government?

The Opposition, when in government, callously and disgracefully reduced family incomes of thousands, in fact nearly a million Australians. Yet it has the gall to challenge this Government on its humane and fiscally responsible program to spread the wealth of Australia over many more families, to create jobs by stimulating the building industry, with increased construction of private homes and public sector homes, and by the Government's specific job creation scheme. I find it quite remarkable that the Opposition, with its own previous record, complains so loudly about family incomes.

Mr Keating's economic statement delivered on 19 May could be summed up as an exercise in three Rs: Reduction, restructuring and redistribution. As such, it reflects the different priorities of a new government compelled by the actions of a previous government. (Quorum formed). Mr Keating's economic statement reflects, unashamedly, the different priorities of a new government compelled to take immediate action, faced with unsuspected financial difficulties and daunting economic problems that it inherited. The aims of the mini-Budget are to reduce the deficit to responsible bounds, or at least to take a first step towards that, to restructure tax concessions and to redistribute income from better off members in the community to the more needy. Most of the measures announced can be justified in terms of economic responsibility and social equity .

In round figures, the mini-Budget slashed $1,000m from Government's projected outlays and concessions in 1983-84. On the other hand, it proposed to spend about $500m, mainly on housing and job creation schemes, leaving a net reduction in the Budget deficit of about $500m. To achieve savings of about $1,000m has been no mean feat. By comparison, the previous Government's notorious razor gang which deliberated for 12 months before producing proposed economies produced savings totalling only $600m, many of which were subsequently reversed. Most of the new cuts in expenditure by this Government, in its mini-statement, unlike the razor gang's cuts, will produce even bigger savings next year and in subsequent years. To reduce the deficit and yet provide funds to create jobs, build houses and help the needy, the Government has had to cut heavily into many of the expensive, inequitable and largely electorally motivated subsidies and concessions provided by the last Budget, for example, the home interest rebate scheme. This Government has taken the courageous decision to eliminate some of the tax benefits enjoyed mainly by those who may be judged to be sufficiently well off not to need them. I will quote from an editorial in the Advertiser of 20 May. The Advertiser is no radical journal. It states:

The Government's clear intention is two-fold: to assure business that it is determined to get the massive deficit down to more manageable proportions, and to head off an inevitable spiral of interest rates in the long term; and secondly, to make a start on fulfilling the pledges to stimulate the economy and to bring down unemployment.

It is clear that wealthy older people, farmers and middle-class families have been asked to bear the brunt of the austerity program. The poor have been rightfully protected, and at least a start has been made on tackling the crisis of the jobless.
I will also quote from an editorial in the Age on the same day, 20 May. It states:

In social terms, the redistribution of concessions from those who need them less to those who need them more must be welcomed. Politically the mini-Budget may lose the Government some of the support it had won from the middle class. But if hard decisions had to be taken and if sacrifices had to be made, it is best that they be taken sooner rather than later and that they be shouldered by those best able to bear them.

That is unashamedly the aim of the mini-Budget. That is why I find it remarkable that Senator Messner decides to go into bat against the very stated claims of this Government. I shall itemise some of the individual points of that mini- Budget to make the point even further. One of the claims the Opposition makes is that we are going to ruin people for ever by doing away with the health insurance rebate which was introduced by the Fraser Government to soften the impact of rising premiums and the withdrawal of free hospital treatment for the uninsured. This was one of its many variations on medical health care during its time in government. The removal of this rebate is supposed to sock the average family $4 a week. For a start, it will not affect any family until June/July 1984. As it will apply to only six months-that is, the first six months of the next fiscal year or the last six months of this ordinary year-in effect, a very small amount of money will be involved. By the time people have enjoyed the benefits of the Medicare scheme, once it is introduced early next year, the initial loss of the health insurance rebate will be absorbed.

The complaints about the health insurance rebate amount to a very small or insufficient basis on which to impose this matter of public importance. Taxpayers will still be able to claim their health insurance rebate this year. When they submit their tax next year they will have found the benefits that I have listed with Medicare will have balanced out the loss. The number of home loan interest problems that the previous Government introduced have also been done away with, causing some outcry from the Opposition. The home loan interest rebate now available to all home buyers, regardless of income, was perhaps the most blatantly political and the least justifiable on social equity grounds of the Fraser Government's pre-election Budget measures. In its place the Government has planned a generous home ownership scheme. (Quorum formed). This is becoming a most entertaining up and down contribution to the matter of public importance. I thought it was only in Question Time that we were up and down like yo-yos. I will not spend too much time spelling out the advantages of the housing program under the mini-Budget. Senator Grimes has done that most adequately. It is interesting to note though that a number of the organisations in our community are very supportive of and sympathetic to the broad aims of this mini-Budget, in particular the housing proposals. On 20 May the Age stated:

Australia's largest employer group, the Confederation of Australian Industry, described the statement as ''a responsible document'' which imposed additional sacrifices on some sections of the private sector . . .

The national chief executive of the Housing Industry Association, Mr Bill Kirkby-Jones, said that the moves would considerably improve prospects for lower income earners to afford homes, while boosting employment in the industry by 20, 000 . . .
The Confederation of Australian Industry called the statement a ''responsible document'' . . . although it imposes additional sacrifices on some sections of the private sector'.

These people are not members of the Australian Labor Party and, I would have thought, not necessarily Labor voters who are looking at this mini-Budget and seeing it as a responsible document in keeping with the proposed outcome of the principal Government policy. The Opposition says that the Government has broken its promises in all sorts of ways, but this Government was elected with a massive vote from the Australian people on the principal aim of reducing unemployment. Unemployment is the social cost that this Government says it will not tolerate any more. It says that it is prepared to take some money from various small places so as to make at least a start on this job creation scheme. Through a boost to the housing industry it will not only provide homes but also stimulate employment.

In summary, I think the mini-Budget is what Mr Keating claimed in his statement -a document that represents this Government's belief that the Australian ethic of a fair go provides the will to share the burden, that all Australians are prepared to take these bits and pieces of cuts and not complain, as the Opposition has been doing so ineffectually, about bearing that small burden to enable the unemployment figures to be reduced so that all Australians can start sharing in the wealth of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Time and again this afternoon the Opposition, despite having put up what it claims to be a matter of public importance, has not raised its level of participation in this chamber to more than a handful of honourable senators. What I put to you, sir, is that the matter of public importance is either not a matter of public importance or not sufficiently important for members of the Opposition to be here. If that is not so, the Opposition's frustration with the Senate should in some way be curtailed.
—I think the honourable senator realises that there is no point of order in that statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering a matter of public importance-

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I realise that Senator Martin followed Senator Grimes in the list of speakers that is before you, but surely that does not alter the fact that I still follow Senator Crowley.
—Senator Haines, I have a list before me which I am following. I expect that is the one that has been arranged. It shows you as speaking after Senator Hamer.
—Thank you. I would have appreciated a little earlier acknowledgement of that.
—The Senate is considering a matter of public importance in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The disastrous impact on family incomes of the Government's mini-Budget proposals and, in particular, the abolition of the home interest and the health insurance rebates.

Throughout this debate we have constantly heard as an excuse for the Government' s performance and for its broken promises talk about the $9.6 billion deficit. That deficit is for next year. The deficit for this year, the last year for which we bear direct responsibility, is just over $4 billion. What happens next year is up to the Labor Government. It will now have to make decisions. We hope they will be good decisions. We will examine them to see what the Government is doing. The deficit next year is entirely the responsibility of the Hawke Government. The deficit this year is our responsibility.

We all know that the economic climate is very difficult. We have a depressed mining export industry with low commodity prices. We have a collapse of primary industry because of the drought, though the drought is now over. We have declining manufacturing exports because of the explosion of wages last year. I agree that it is necessary for any government to take tough decisions. However, decisions, as well as being tough, must be fair and well directed. It is proper for the Senate to examine the decisions this Government is planning to take to see whether they are tough but fair.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your alternative?

—I will come very quickly to where I think the Government is going wrong. It is necessary to deal with the terrible problem of the 700,000 unemployed, which is socially disastrous and a great loss to our economy. It is necessary for the 90 per cent in work to make some sacrifices so that work can be provided for some-or all, if we can-of the 700,000 unemployed. This is where this Government is failing. It has failed to take action. It knows that on economic and on employment grounds it should be pressing for the wages freeze to continue into next year. It is not doing that. The Government is committed to supporting the campaign of the Australian Council of Trade Unions-committed by its own prices and incomes accord with the trade union movement-for quarterly indexation, although it knows that this will be disastrous for the unemployed, will do great social damage and will not decrease unemployment. By its own figures, it will increase unemployment by something like 100,000 people.

SPEECH.PARA: This mini-Budget has increased costs to the average family by between $8 and $9 a week. The home loan rebate has been abolished. That is despite a promise in the election campaign that it would be retained. That will push up interest rates by about 2 per cent. The health insurance rebate has been abolished, despite a promise that it would be retained until Medicare was in place. The concessional tax rebate floor has been raised to $2,000. The average cost of that will be something like $3 a week.

Pensions for the over 70-year-olds are now to be means tested. My party believes that social security benefits should be given on the basis of need. I cannot oppose on principle the idea of reimposing the means test for those over 70-year-olds. However, when the Government makes changes like these, particularly with elderly people, it must give them a chance to plan for them, and not make them abruptly against all the promises and commitments of the party making them. It is worth remembering that while we were in government we introduced automatic indexation for pensions and family allowances, both major improvements in social security. Now, in one sweep, the means test for over 70- year-olds has been introduced.

Worse still, and more clumsy, particularly as the Treasurer, Mr Keating, has said that we must not rush into decisions, is the decision in regard to taxing lump sum superannuation, which is certainly a case of rushing in. The Treasurer does not know-nobody knows-what it means. He is now having meetings to try to find out what he meant when he said it. This is a ridiculous situation. There are great problems with his decision. Something had to be done about lump sum superannuation payments, but not in isolation. If one makes a change I think that one must look at the ramifications, the alternatives and the impacts and that was not done when this Government rushed in. I suppose its explanation, which we have heard so often, is that it seemed like a good idea at the time. The Government is still trying to find out what it meant.

The other, and in some ways very significant, effect of the mini-Budget was to take away the tax rebate on the first $1,000 of dividend income. The purpose of that was to encourage Australians to have a part-ownership in their own enterprises. The Labor Party claims to be in favour of that. What does it do? It wipes out this incentive. I think we can all remember the promise that the Government made before the election. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said:
This is not a fistful of dollars to be snatched away. We are promising immediate tax cuts for six million Australians.

What the Prime Minister has given Australians is not immediate tax cuts but immediate tax increases and he is charging-in my view totally fraudulently-that the reason for this was the unknown deficit. Last year all Labor pressure was for an increase in the Budget deficit-more expenditure. If we had listened to what the then Labor Opposition said last year at Budget time the deficit this year would have been about $9 billion and much more the following year. All the pressure from the Labor Party was for an increase in the deficit. During the election campaign members of the Labor Party made promises, regardless of their effect on the deficit, of more expenditure in every area one could conceive.

I turn to the details of a couple of areas of the mini-Budget. The first one at which I think we should look is its effect on housing. In the early months of the year housing starts were rising. Last year was disastrous for the housing industry. The effect of the way this matter has been handled by the Government- it has promised that the benefits it is offering will come into effect in October-will be a four-months fall in housing commencements. There will be damage to the housing industry. A good heading in the Sydney Morning Herald states 'Housing slump likely as buyers await new aid'. The Government is saying that it is trying to help the housing industry. I would hate to be helped by the Government because the sort of help that it gives is nearly always damaging. In addition, because of the changes the Government has made in abolishing the home loan rebate, pushing up interest rates by probably 2 per cent, the cost to the average family with a loan of $30,000 will be about $5 a week. Honourable senators must remember that about 40 per cent of families are paying off their homes. This is the damage that is being done by this mini-Budget to housing in Australia. It is harming the average family by the inept way the measures are being introduced. It will damage the housing industry which Labor claims it is trying to help. This is very clumsy and incompetent. The decisions that the Government made may have been tough but they have also been foolish.

Worse still, a recent tax decision is very damaging to property investors. Several of Australia's biggest property developers have shelved projects worth up to $1 billion because of Australian Taxation Office rulings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—I think Senator Tate should look into this matter. It is not a minor matter; it is a very serious matter for investment in property. The consequence of this decision, unless it is reversed by the Government and there was no mention of reversing it in the mini-Budget, will be to cause further unemployment, reduce overall tax collections, push up residential rents and further depress property prices. These are all serious matters and the Government in the face of this has taken no action at all. These are very unfortunate matters which show the way in which the Government, claiming to be helping housing and claiming to be helping the family, is in fact damaging both.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the effect of the mini-Budget on health insurance. I think it is acknowledged that the Medicare scheme will cost $400m extra in government expenditure. That, I suggest, is a minimum. We have to remember that in the time of Medibank its cost went up four-fold in three years. I think health expenditure will probably increase a lot more with Medicare. Some wise words were said about Medicare. They were actually said by a Labor man, the former Labor Party spokesman on health, Dr Klugman. He said:
. . . Medicare should not be introduced.
His further words were reported as follows:
He argued that Medicare would encourage doctors to over-service patients because medical and hospital fees could be bulk-billed directly to the Government.
Dr Klugman, a general practitioner for 15 years, said Medicare was wasted on the very poor who would not be better off. As holders of health care cards,--
At present, that is-
they were entitled already to free treatment, while families earning up to $15, 000 a year would only save about $2 a week.

Dr Klugman, the former Labor Party spokesman on health, said that Medicare should not be introduced. I must say that I agree with him. The consequences of the way that this matter has been handled will cause confusion and damage to the people who are presently insured, who will lose their tax rebates. Next January the Government will introduce an expensive scheme which, according to a Labor spokesman, and I agree with him, should not be introduced because it will not be beneficial. I entirely agree with him. This is part of a pattern of muddle and confusion. Muddle and confusion are the characteristics of this Hawke Government . We all know that we are in a very difficult economic situation but people are looking for tough but fair decisions. What we are getting is just confused Hawkespeak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The matter of public importance before the Senate today is:

SPEECH.PARA: The disastrous impact on family incomes of the Government's mini-Budget proposals and, in particular, the abolition of the home interest and the health insurance rebates.

Given the rather Alice in Wonderland tenor of the whole debate today, with quorums being called punitively from both sides of the House, I wonder why, Mr Deputy President, I called your attention to the fact that the speaking list has been changed and that I was not a little higher in the speaking order. Of course there can be no question at all that the mini-Budget will have a considerable impact on the incomes of the average Australian family. However, it will not be quite the disaster that some speakers from the Liberal Party have suggested. It is certainly not the panacea for all ills that the Government has suggested it is. That has been acknowledged in the reaction from various groups in the community, which have indicated that there is less than complete approval of the provisions in the mini-Budget. So much for Mr Hawke's much vaunted theme of consensus.

The Australian Council of Trade Unions, health care professionals, businesses, farmers and ordinary individuals have all expressed concern for, and in some cases condemnation of, the proposals put down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last week and by some Ministers, notably the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, this week. The matter of public importance raised by the Liberal Party mentions only two of those matters; there are others that I will mention a little later, some of which I consider are far worse. Certainly the changes to the housing interest income tax rebate scheme are going to inconvenience many families who, quite legitimately, planned ahead following last year's introduction of the scheme by the previous Government and who now find that a rebate they had depended upon has been taken away from them. Of course for some families that inconvenience will be compounded by very real economic hardship. For instance, those families who have taken out what is about the average loan of $30,000 at what is quite a low interest rate of 12 1/2 per cent from some State banks, will be somewhere in the vicinity of $4 to $5 out of pocket per week as a result of this proposed change. People with loans from building societies for instance which offer higher interest rates on mortage loans will have an extra cost imposed on them.

One could argue that the scheme introduced by the Liberal Government last year will be of decreasing value to the people who are making use of it as interest rates fall. But that is assuming that interest rates will fall and, therefore, will negate the tax rebate that accrues from interest rates of over 10 per cent. But interest rates are hardly likely to fall in the face of a record $1.5 billion bond tender which, certainly in the short term, will mitigate against this happening. I am not alone in my fears about that. On 20 May the Sydney Morning Herald had an article headed '$1.5 billion bond tender to fuel rises in rates'. The first paragraph of that article stated:
Short-term interest rates are expected to soar from today following the Federal Treasury's huge $1.5 billion Commonwealth Bond tender announced last night.

Presumably, when talking about short term interest rates, we can say that they will extend perhaps no more than six months, in which case there was no need for the present government to reduce both halves of the 1983-84 rebate on housing interest. The Government asserts that its new measure is intended to assist first home buyers and to provide additional funds for welfare housing. For this it is to be commended. However, I insist that it is regrettable that it does this by placing an additional financial burden on people who, in good faith, arrange their affairs in this area because of the last Government's 1982 policy.

However, a more drastic cost affecting families will result from the abolition of the health insurance rebate six months earier than the Government indicated would be the case during its election campaign. The Government then said that the advent of Medicare would obviate the need for this and it would in part be funded by removing the rebate. I guess that that is fair enough. However, as I have said, this was introduced six months early in a purely cost cutting measure and not to offset any other consideration that the Government will be introducing. According to the Victorian Taxpayers Association the cost to the average family is of the order of $4 a week-another $4 a week on top of the amount that families will lose with the abolition of the housing interest income tax rebate scheme. As a result of the Government's reduced contribution to the Hospital Benefits Reinsurance Trust Fund the cost to the average family could rise to $4.50 a week. I believe that this action by the Government-that is, the Government's reduced contribution to the HBRTF-is a direct attack on the chronically and terminally ill. The rest of the Government's action-the reduction or the removal of the health insurance rebate-is an attack on those with the foresight and the concern to take out health insurance cover. It is also an attack on the private health funds. I believe it is nothing more than an ideologically inspired move by a socialist government to eliminate the private sector, to remove people's democratic right to choose and to turn us into a mob of sheep with Dr Blewett acting as a yapping heeler, forcing us into its universal health sheep dip.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lovely imagery.

—It is probably more than appropriate. No one questions the fact that some hard decisions have to be made if the legacy of the previous Government's deficit is to be reduced, although, as Senator Hamer pointed out, the extremely high figure that is touted in the community is next year's figure rather than this year's figure. But hitting the average family is not the way to do this. As Senator Martin pointed out, these people are the big spenders; the consistent, regular spenders in Australia. They are the ones who buy goods and who keep the economy moving. The ordinary family has been hit time and again to the tune of at least $8 a week by this mini-Budget. That is only a minimum estimate because other areas in this mini-Budget will also have an impact and have yet to be costed.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look now at some of those areas, in particular those related to people in the country. I must say that I am suprised that the official Opposition did not make more of the impact that this mini-Budget will have on people in country areas. Not only, of course, are they faced with a reduction in the rebates that have already been mentioned but also they are faced with two fairly dramatic items-which are small in themselves as far as this mini-Budget is concerned but fairly large in their effect on country people.

TALK.START.PARA: —We did make the point during Question Time this morning in relation to extra charges that would affect country people.
—I acknowledge that.
—And telephone calls, including STD calls, were very much affected.
—No doubt that will save me a number of minutes. No doubt that time will be taken up by the inevitable quorum call.
—You are lucky you are escaping that.

—I am not asking for one. Let me turn to the point affecting country people about which I am particularly concerned. The very likely increased costs through Telecom Australia and the Australian Postal Commission will impact on rural families far more than they will on urban dwellers. Under the heading 'Economic Services' to be found on pages 56 and 57 of the printed mini-Budget there are increases in the rate of excise on aviation fuel, specifically avgas and avtur by 2c a litre, and an increase from 1c to 1.1c a litre in the non-subsidised part of the cost of freighting certain petroleum products. It would not surprise me at all if the Opposition were to support these measures when the enabling legislation comes down. In the past two years it has proposed its own increase in air navigation charges which has had a similar impact on the cost of transport in country areas and hence the prices in country areas, particularly the more isolated areas.
—Senator, the impact on the CPI in a full year is 0.17 per cent. It is very light.

—That may well be the case, Senator Cook, but one knows what happens when one starts using statistics: They can be used to prove almost anything. I venture to suggest that those country people who are losing $8 a week from their income, plus whatever other impact there will be from this mini- Budget, do not really care whether the figure is 0.7 or 0.07 or 7 per cent.
—It is 0.17.

—I do not think they would really care even if it were 0.17. It is affecting them and they do not like it, particularly as they are coming out of one of the worst droughts from which they have suffered. What is the Government doing to stimulate the economy, to increase employment and to boost business confidence-all elements that the Government asserted this mini-Budget was designed to promote? I suggest that most of it appears to be a sleight of hand.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the easiest way of dealing with this matter is for honourable senators to have a look at page 58 of the mini-Budget and in particular that section relating to the establishment of a community employment program involving a large number of additional outlays. I question a number of these and ask the Government: Why spend $315m on job creation schemes while apparently saving $20m on extensions to the Brisbane Airport, which must be labour intensive, $20m on the rail link and $70m from water resources programs which appear to have been replaced but I am not quite sure in exactly what way. I would like to know whether the $70m which has been allocated for jobs on roads under the Community Employment Program is in addition to normal road funding or instead of normal road funding since it is a favourite trick by governments to try this semi- substitution racket. I point out also that, as far as I can see, the jobs that are likely to be created under the CEP will be almost entirely male occupations. I ask: What is the point of all this if Medicare will cost the number of jobs in the health care industry that it has been suggested it will cost?

This mini-Budget purports to save the country less than $0.5 billion in 1983-84 and something over $1.3 billion in 1984-85. In the meantime, it has reduced the spending power of the average Australian family, caused chaos in the health care industry, offered a well-intentioned but short term job creation scheme designed primarily for males, and broken a number of election promises, including one relating to the Alice Springs-Darwin railway. A previous speaker suggested that this mini-Budget directs the limited funds available from the Government from the wealthy to the needy. I suggest that in many respects it does not. In fact, it directs assistance to the needy by taking it away from those who need it only slightly less. I find it hardly an egalitarian document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) spoke of the absolute cheek of the Opposition in proposing for discussion a matter of public importance of this nature after the disastrous effects of seven years of Fraser Government in Australia. Initially, I will not be quite so harsh. I will not talk about the absolute cheek of the Opposition. But I cannot agree with most aspects of Senator Messner's matter of public importance. I say at the outset that one part of the terms of the matter proposed for discussion with which I cannot agree is the reference to the Government's mini-Budget. An economic statement was brought down in the House of Representatives last Thursday night. It was not a mini-Budget. I will not have any real hassle if the Opposition wants to talk about it as a mini-Budget. ( Quorum formed). I am surprised that such a mild mannered person as I am should have a quorum called against me. As I say, it was not a mini-Budget. On the day after the economic statement was brought down, the editorial of the Australian Financial Review stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The statement last night by the Treasurer, Mr Keating, fell far short of a mini -budget. The clear message of the statement-
I emphasise the word 'statement'-
was one of caution and reassurance.

I also do not agree with the Opposition's statement that it will result in a ' disastrous impact on family incomes'. A continuation of the previous Government' s policies-that is, the Fraser Government's policies-would have been disastrous. Those policies have led Australia into the economic morass which was inherited by the present Government.

I will put last Thursday's economic statement into perspective. In the March election, the Australian Labor Party was overwhelmingly elected to govern to this nation. There were many reasons for this. I will mention two of the principal reasons. One reason was the Labor Party's excellent policies, and the other reason was the disastrous policies of the previous Government. Mr Peacock, the Leader of the Opposition, in the House of Representatives, fully acknowledged this point. Last weekend he stated:
We were dumped on the fifth of March, absolutely dumped.

This is what happened: The previous Government had disastrous policies and it was thrown out of office. When the Labor Party was elected to government, it found that it had inherited massive unemployment. As Senator Crowley mentioned, over 700,000 people in Australia are out of work. Over one quarter of people in the 15 to 19 year age group is unemployed. Overall, over 10 per cent of the work force is out of work. If that state of affairs did not have some impact on family incomes, I do not know what would have an effect on family incomes. The family incomes of all of the 700,000 people out of work were affected. Yet the Opposition has the cheek-to use the word used by Senator Grimes earlier this afternoon-to speak of 'a disastrous impact on family incomes'. The policies of the previous Government had a disastrous impact on family incomes during the seven years that it was in government.

What else did the Hawke Government inherit when it took office after the March election? It inherited an unacceptable level of inflation of over 11 per cent. In the seven years that I spent in Opposition, year after year I would see a Budget handed down, in which the previous government would say: 'We will get inflation down and, as we get inflation down, employment prospects will increase '. What happened during those seven years? Inflation remained high and unemployment grew worse and worse.

What else did we inherit? We inherited high interest rates. When I entered this Parliament in 1975 when we were in Opposition, interest rates were well under double digit figures. Yet interest rates on home loans ranged from 12.5 per cent -the lowest rate that one could obtain-to over 20 per cent, when we took office. This was the result of the previous Government's initiatives or, perhaps I should say, lack of initiatives.

What does the Opposition expect the Labor Party to do, given the mess with which it was left? The Labor Party has no intention of sitting back and hoping that the problems will go away. This was the approach of the Liberal-National Party coalition. It had an ostrich-like approach which resulted in Australians being confronted by economic disaster over the period it was in government, culminating in its defeat earlier this year. The Labor Government does not intend to sit back. It intends to act swiftly and decisively to ensure that the Australian economy returns to an even keel. Some decisions that we must take, given the mess that we inherited, will be unpalatable, but we were given a job to do and we will not shirk the responsibility given to us by the Australian electorate.

The economic statement was well accepted despite the pessimism shown to it by Opposition senators. Senator Crowley quoted from the Adelaide Advertiser. She said that it was not a radical journal. Similarly, I will quote from the Courier -Mail, which equally is not a radical journal. On the day after the economic statement was brought down, amongst other things, the editorial, in relation to the statement, stated:
It is, within the bounds of ALP policy and Treasury advice, a responsible document.
It recognises the enormity of the problems faced by the Australian economy. It seeks, as Mr Keating said, to share 'the equality of sacrifice'.
The article goes on:
The Government holds little hope for a quick recovery.
