This is true. We made a statement during the election campaign that we were not promising immediate recovery. We were not promising that things would get better overnight. We realise this and the Courier-Mail reaffirms it. The article goes on:
It believes that if there is to be an improvement, the public sector must lead the way. It has boosted housing, trimmed some other spending, and pinned its hopes on job creation schemes.

When the economic statement was introduced the other night we were acting in a decisive and responsible way. In the MPI brought forward by the Opposition home construction is mentioned. Let us look at the Government's record on home construction. Figures show that over the past years the state of home construction in Australia has plummeted. In the current financial year it is expected that 106,000-(Quorum formed). It is amazing that the Opposition, through Senator Messner, has introduced a matter of public importance; yet it continually tries to frustrate those on this side of the chamber by calling quorums. It is worth while mentioning that one person who has spoken in this debate and who has not been interrupted by the calling of a quorum is Senator Messner.

I was mentioning home construction. During the current financial year 106,000 dwellings will be constructed in Australia. This is the lowest number of constructions since the 1962-63 year. That compares with 132,300 dwellings constructed in 1981-82 and 150,000 dwellings constructed in 1980-81. Labor will increase the housing construction rate to 130,000 to 135,000 dwellings a day. This will increase employment not only in the housing industry but also in related industries. I could mention our housing package but I will not be able to because the time available to me has been reduced by the calling of two quorums. For those who are interested, our housing package was well set out in the economic statement which some members of the Opposition who have spoken this afternoon have not even bothered to read.

Health was mentioned by the Opposition in the MPI. Again, I will not have the opportunity to go through all those aspects of health changes I would like to mention. But most of us who have been senators for a number of years can remember the extensive changes to health arrangements that were made by the previous Government so that in the end nobody knew where they really stood. In the time I was in Opposition-for seven years-there were six changes. One year it was delightful; there was not any change at all. But in each other year a change was brought in. Despite the fact that at one stage Mr Fraser said he would retain Medibank, all he retained was a messy health insurance system. I repeat Senator Grimes's question: What would the Opposition have done, given what we have inherited? Given the economic conditions that prevailed after seven years of Fraserism, what would the Opposition have done? The MPI talks about the disastrous impact on family incomes. What would have been disastrous would have been a continuation of the extraordinarily inept Government of the past seven years. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-During Senator Colston's remarks the point was made that the Opposition had been calling quorums on every speaker and that I was the only person who did not have quorums called while I was speaking. I would just like to point out that that is not so. Senator Grimes, Senator Haines and Senator Hamer did not have quorums called while they were speaking. In fact, the first person to call a quorum was the Government Whip who saw fit to do so when Senator Martin was speaking.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button) agreed to:

Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am making this statement on behalf of Senator Grimes. The Government has made the following decisions in respect of Medicare. Medicare will commence on 1 February 1984. The payment of medical benefits will be administered by the Health Insurance Commission, which currently runs Medibank Private. Medibank Private will be able to offer the same range of additional private cover as the other private health funds will be offering. This is to cover private treatment in public hospitals, private hospital treatment and ancillary cover for items such as dentists, physiotherapists and chiropodists.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Health will retain overall responsibility for detection and investigation of doctor fraud and overservicing, using information supplied by Medicare, and overall policy direction. Medicare is a major social program of this Government. It will ensure basic medical and hospital cover for all Australians and will not leave two million Australians without any health cover, as the current inadequate private insurance system does. The Government has chosen the Health Insurance Commission to run Medicare because it is the only health fund with a nation-wide network of cash payment centres that will provide quick and efficient service to the public. By using the Health Insurance Commission we will avoid the waste and duplication involved in having 70 different private funds making Medicare payments. The Health Insurance Commission has a proven record in health insurance, including the successful implementation of Medibank in 1975. By having one paying agency Medicare can ensure confidentiality of patient records and can provide better controls to prevent fraudulent payments and better information for the detection of medifraud.

The Government is concerned at the potential employment consequences of this decision, and we are taking several measures to ensure that no current health fund staff is disadvantaged. The HIC has been requested to offer preference in clerical employment to current fund staff. Discussions have already commenced between my Department and the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations on the matter of employment preference. We will be discussing the changeover to Medicare with the trade unions involved in the private health insurance industry . I have begun discussions with the State Health Ministers on their offering employment preference in the clerical areas of the State health systems. These measures combined with the 20 per cent annual turnover in fund staff will minimise the net employment effect of Medicare.

We welcome the commitment of the private funds to Medicare, as exemplified by their bid to run it. Though it has not been possible to accept their offer we believe that co-operation between the funds and government will ensure an improved, cheaper health insurance cover and guarantee the interests of their employees.

Staff currently employed in direct billing activities within the Health Department will all be offered continuity of employment in the Health Insurance Commission. There will be no relocation of staff employed in the regional processing centres of the Health Department. I am also aware that there are local health funds in some regions which are significant local employers. I have requested the HIC to enter into discussions with these funds to ensure that the service provided to local communities is continued. This is the first step in the restoration of a simple, equitable and cost efficient health plan for all Australians. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President--
—If you have to seek leave, you will be in trouble.

—I certainly do not have to seek leave. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) moved a motion and I am speaking to that motion. In the last few days Dr Klugman has said it all and I believe that you, Mr Deputy President, while speaking in a debate earlier this afternoon, drew attention to his comments. He said then that Medicare should not be proceeded with. He said that it provided nothing for the poor that they did not have now. He cast some considerable doubts on what it will mean for people in Australia. The Opposition is concerned that, if he is right, the Government is pursuing another sterile line of activity. The argument that state monopoly will produce better outcomes is at least speculative, and the assumption that moving to a state monopoly in health ensures the public will be better off remains to be proven. To replace the existing system may not help Australians in their search for more certain health insurance cover. Our concern is how the new arrangements will affect the people of Australia. For example, we are concerned- I think Senator Bjelke-Petersen made this point in a question this morning-that all Queenslanders, who at present do not need to take out health insurance, will have to pay more under the system which the Australian Labor Party is proposing. We are concerned that Australians will lose the tax rebate which they have enjoyed.

SPEECH.PARA: We recently considered in this place the annual report on the operation of the health insurance funds in Australia. That report sets down for the Parliament an account of health funds which are well run, well operated, are considerable employers, carry out a major function in protecting people and take a major part in the co-payment of their medical costs. As I recall the report, it set down that more than $1,000m of contributors' money was paid out last year by way of benefits to those who were in hospital or had incurred medical fees. It sets out that the funds have more than $120m in fixed assets-buildings and equipment- which belong to the contributors. I can see nothing in this statement which tells me how those assets are to be protected or what is to happen to them, and how the interests of contributors to health insurance funds are to be protected under the new arrangements which will come in when the Government establishes and starts to operate Medicare, as it has a right to do. Because Medibank was not included in the report on the health insurance funds, the report did not set out that Medibank, which has been given the carriage of this new scheme by the Government, has been insolvent for the last several years in several States. It should not escape notice that the Government is entrusting its new scheme to a health fund which in at least four States of Australia could not even operate profitably. With all the advantages that it had as a government-backed, government-supported and, at one stage, government-subsidised scheme, it was still not operating profitably; it was operating at a loss; it was technically insolvent in several States of Australia. That is something which would concern people, because we have to know that the Health Insurance Commission can do this job and that Medibank is in fact capable of fulfilling the hope which the Government has placed in it.

This statement brings home once more what Australians are going to lose, what they have lost; in particular that they have lost, in direct abrogation of an election promise, the rebate on health insurance premiums they enjoy today. Australians today can claim as a tax rebate some of the amounts of money they pay for health insurance. Before the election the Labor Party led the Australian people to believe that they would conttinue to enjoy the right to claim that rebate until Medicare was introduced. Last Thursday that right, promised to them in the election by the Hawke Government and the Labor Party, was withdrawn. It is just one of a number of broken promises which already characterise this Government. It is unnecessary, because if in fact the Government wishes to introduce Medicare in six or nine months why does it have to penalise Australian families an extra $4 a week when it promised it would not do so?

I will not redebate the economic statement of last week. The ministerial statement that has just been made is interesting because it means that Labor, at the time it is preaching financial restraint and the generation of employment, is to increase the deficit immediately by an amount of $40m to $50m as a result of expenditure on Medibank, and eventually by, say, $400m. Although Senator Button, on behalf of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), has made some reassuring noises, there is no guarantee about the employment of those people who work for the private health funds. Medicare will not come into operation for another six, seven or eight months, or however long it is going to be. What is an employee of a private health fund to do in the meantime? Is he or she to stay with that fund while it continues to do its job for the Australian people whom it has insured, or is he or she to cut and run and join the new Health Insurance Commission? In any event, every employee of the funds knows that the jobs available and being offered are fewer than the number of people who will want jobs and who are presently working for the private health funds.

So, we have extra expenditure, an increase in the deficit, diminished employment and increased immediate cost. We have the breaking of a specific election pledge to the Australian people. We now have the information that the Labor Party has given the monoply for the operation of the new scheme to a Health Insurance Commission which has been operating unsuccessfully in most States of Australia. We will look to see just how effectively the scheme can be put into operation. We want effective health care cover for all Australians. If this can be achieved, we will be well satisfied. But the statement raises more questions than it answers. It is another example of the fact that this Government cannot keep its word, and it offers no comfort to the many employees of health insurance funds who at present face a very uncertain future.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-During the debate on the matter of public importance a short time ago, I made some statements towards the end of my speech about the number of honourable senators whose speeches had been interrupted when quorums were called. It is quite in order for any honourable senator to draw the state of the House to the attention of the Chair. Normally in this chamber that is done only rarely but there has certainly been open warfare this afternoon. That open warfare started from the Opposition benches.
—Not so.

—It is so. That is the point that I want to make. When I sought leave a short time ago to make a personal explanation on this matter I was refused leave but I told Senator Messner across the chamber, I must confess in a disorderly way, Mr Deputy President--
—Your remarks were not audible to the Chair, Senator.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I made the comment that the quorum was first called when Senator Grimes was speaking. That was denied but that is in fact so. I wish to indicate what happened this afternoon. The first person to speak in the debate on the matter of public importance was Senator Messner. He was heard in relative silence and was not interrupted. The second person to speak was the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes. He had been speaking for only a short time when Senator Kilgariff drew the attention of the occupant of the Chair, who at the time was Senator Sibraa, to the state of the House, whereupon a quorum was then called. So the action was initiated from the Opposition benches. The next person to speak was Senator Martin. A quorum was called when she was speaking. I do not know why but I should imagine it was in response to the fact that a quorum was called during Senator Grimes's speech. The next person to speak was Senator Crowley who, if I remember correctly, was twice interrupted. She was followed by Senator Hamer. At that stage the Government did not continue what had happened all afternoon. Senator Hamer was not interrupted and neither was Senator Haines. I was the next person to speak and I was interrupted twice. The point that I really want to make is that it was intimated earlier that the action commenced on this side of the chamber. The action did not commence on this side; it commenced on the Opposition side when Senator Kilgariff drew Senator Sibraa's attention to the state of the House while Senator Grimes was speaking.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Mason) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to remove provisions for deductions from taxable income in respect of the removal of indigenous trees.
Bill presented by Senator Mason, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to remove from the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 the provision of an income tax deduction for the destruction and removal of indigenous timber.
This is in line with a recommendation of the report of the Committee of Inquiry into the National Estate of 1974, which was re-iterated in the Australian Heritage Commission Report of 1982.
The Committee of Inquiry made the following observation:

'Whilst the agricultural and postoral potential of Australia may not yet have reached a stage of full exploitation, it has reached the stage where the extension of it to new places may not be of any lasting value to the community. In some cases, it may cause considerable irreversible harm. Without proper land use surveys and planning it cannot be said that there is no land which should not be cleared or re-cleared for the purpose of primary industry. However, it is one thing for the community to allow a farmer to fell trees and to drain swamps, quite another for the community to encourage him to do so by giving him special tax concessions.'
The subject was raised again very recently in the other place when the member for Fraser asked the following question of the Minister for Finance on 18 May 1983:

Mr Fry: I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. In view of the fact that in less than 200 years the European occupants of Australia have succeeded in destroying about two-thirds of our natural forests, including most of the natural habitats of koala bears, which are important to our tourist industry, will the Minister undertake to review the guidelines for the taxation deduction presently allowed for the clearing of natural forests which I believe provides an undesirable incentive for the continued destruction of our forests?

Mr Dawkins: I thank the honourable member for his question. He will be aware that the last Labor Government did act to deal with the taxation treatment of land clearing. There is an important question of not wanting to discourage the further development of agricultural land in this country, but at the same time, not providing a taxation incentive for the indiscriminate and wanton destruction of important parts of the Australian bushland. I think they are important questions that have to be addressed. The honourable member quite rightly drew attention to the fact that the taxation system through the allowances for these kinds of expenditures does have an effect on the rate and extent of clearing on particuar properties. As I indicated before, the last Labor Government did act to ensure that a balance was returned to the taxation impact of these sorts of actions. In the light of the honourable member's question, I would be happy to see whether further action is required to prevent the sorts of circumstances about which he is talking.

The woodland area of Australia is found almost exclusively in the coastal strip which is about 300 km in width. This area also supports 99% of the population and provides the water catchment area for almost all rainfall on the continent.

Australia has 42 million hectares of forest land which is, as the member for Fraser pointed out, only one third of the forested area existing before European settlement of this country. 21% of this forest is privately owned. Much of this privately owned forest is in the form of corridors of land between tracts of publicly owned forest such as state forests, or national parks. In some cases, the only reasons for clearing these corridors of forest are economic ones, for short-term monetary gain from this income tax deduction. Obviously, the clearing of forests for this reason is not in the best interests of the country.

There are many compelling reasons for strict controls on the clearing of indigenous forests. Indiscriminate clearing leads to erosion and leaching of soil and severely depletes the natural habitat of many species of native fauna, including endangered species.
The most obvious and easily introduced control is that proposed by this amendment to the Income Tax Assessment Act.
I urge all honourable senators to support this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Mr President, by introducing this Bill the Government is honouring an undertaking given during the recent election campaign to review the provisions of the parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Scheme. The changes to the scheme contained in the Bill were foreshadowed by the Prime Minister in his statement of 28 March.
The Bill provides for three changes in the Scheme.

The first change relates to commutation. In future, a retiring senator or member will be permitted to convert no more than one-half of his or her retiring allowance to a lump sum benefit. This contrasts with the present arrangements under which a retiring senator or member may convert the whole of the retiring allowance to a lump sum. The Government believes commutation of the whole retiring allowance conflicts with the basic purpose of the Scheme which is to ensure income maintenance in retirement. Of course, senators and members who elect to commute in future will be affected by the changes to the income tax arrangements announced by the Treasurer in the economic statement on 19 May.

The second change relates to spouse's benefits. Under the law as it stands, commutation of the senator's or member's retiring allowance does not affect the amount of the annuity payable to the surviving spouse because the spouse's annuity is calculated as if the former senator or member had not commuted his or her retiring allowance. The Government considers that it is more appropriate to relate the spouse's annuity to the senator's or member's residual pension and not the pension that would have been payable had the senator or member not commuted. Consequently, the Bill provides that, for senators and members retiring after the date on which the amendments come into operation, the surviving spouse will receive five-sixths of the residual retiring allowance that would have been payable to the former senator or member. Special provisions have been included in the Bill to ensure that the spouse of a senator or member who commuted under the existing provisions will not be disadvantaged by the new arrangements.

The third change contained in the Bill will impose restrictions on the payment of a parliamentary retiring allowance or annuity to a person who is in receipt of salary as the holder of an office of profit under the crown or a pension arising from the holding of such an office. Where the former senator or member or the spouse of a former senator or member receives such a salary or pension, the parliamentary retiring allowance or annuity will be reduced by the lesser of the amount of that salary or pension, or one-half of the parliamentary retiring allowance or annuity disregarding any commutation. For the purpose of this provision, former senators and members and their spouses will be required to give notice of taking up an office of profit under the Crown and provide information about any salary or pension they derive from such an office. The restrictions will only apply to a senator or member who retires from the parliament after the date on which these amendments come into force, and the spouse of such a senator or member. The existing provisions will continue to apply to those senators and members who have already retired from the Parliament and the spouses of such senators and members.
The Australian Government Actuary has advised that he expects the net effect of these three changes will be a reduction in the overall cost of the Scheme.
The Bill also contains a number of consequential and other technical amendments .
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Taxation (Interest on Overpayments) Bill which gives effect to a decision of the former Government. In fact an announcement was made in the last Budget Speech that the penalties for late payment would be increased from 10 per cent to 20 per cent. A strong case clearly existed, in our minds, for an increase in the penalty rate for late payment. The relatively low amount meant that the opportunity for non-payment was exploited, particularly in large tax avoidance arrangements. The then Government decided to increase the penalty rate and to abolish the 50-50 rule which had acted as an incentive for indefinite dispute regarding outstanding tax liabilities. It was considered by the former Government that if the taxpayer in dispute with the Commissioner of Taxation won his case he should receive some interest on the amount of tax refunded to him. We therefore support the Bill which has been introduced by the Government and we wish it a speedy passage.

Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, on behalf of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) I wish to move an amendment to clause 12. The request amendment has been circulated. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 7, clause 12, line 37, at the end of the clause add the words 'in respect of any period in relation to which the agreement, arrangement or indication, as the case may be, applies'.

It is desired that the Committee agree to the request for the amendment to clause 12 which has been circulated on behalf of the Government. The Government' s attention has been drawn to a problem that exists with clause 12 as originally proposed. As was pointed out in the second reading speech, the Bill provides that, where an amount paid under a so-called 50-50 arrangement of the kind formerly entered into by the Commissioner of Taxation is ultimately refunded, the refund is to be paid to the taxpayer free of interest. That is the effect of clause 12 of the Bill.

In its present form the clause provides that a taxpayer who entered into a 50- 50 arrangement with the Commissioner in respect of a particular amount of disputed tax is not to be eligible to receive interest in respect of any amount paid in accordance with the arrangement. On further examination the Government has decided that, where one of these old 50-50 arrangements has run its course, it is appropriate that any amount previously paid under the arrangement should carry interest, but only from the time when the arrangement comes to an end. This means that taxpayers who paid disputed tax under such an arrangement and those who pay disputed amounts in the future without the benefit of a '50-50' arrangement will be on an equal footing as regards the receipt of interest on amounts ultimately refunded as a result of a successful objection or appeal. I seek the Committee's agreement to the making of this request to give effect to the Government's decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the request made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and does not oppose the decision of the Government to seek the request in this instance.

To His Excellency the Governor-General

upon which Senator Peter Rae had moved by way of amendment:

', but the Senate is of the opinion-
(a) that the program outlined in the Governor-General's speech will result in higher unemployment and represents a callous disregard of the needs of the Australian people, and
(b) that the Governor-General's speech fails to identify a legislative program for the implementation of the policies promised by the Government during the recent election campaign, for instance-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some two weeks ago, I had just commenced to speak in the Address-in-Reply debate when the debate was interrupted. Since then many things have happened. We have seen the tabling of the economic papers and the presentation of the mini-Budget. These developments, although containing some good elements, have caused concern to the nation. As a Liberal senator for the Northern Territory, I am particularly concerned about the Alice Springs-Darwin railway. This matter has been debated throughout the nation and has been a topic of major concern for a long period. The Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Paul Everingham, has made a desperate bid to save this project which is of immense value not only to the Northern Territory but also to Australia. One of his latest moves has been to endeavour, with the Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly , Mr Collins, to bring a delegation to see the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in order to discuss this matter. I believe that nothing has been achieved in that aspect to this point.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to recall one or two aspects of this matter. I indicated in the adjournment debate last night that the Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to build the railway. On 22 April, Senator Gietzelt stated:
. . . no steps will be taken that will curtail that election commitment.

That is recorded in Hansard. Yet, last Thursday night, the Government broke that promise. Despite what Senator Gietzelt has said in the Senate today, he misled the Senate and has continued to do so. Yesterday he said that it was an established practice for States to fund railway projects in Australia jointly. Yet, today in Question Time, he stated:
I also remind the honourable senator that the Commonwealth has already built the Tarcoola-Alice Springs section of 830 kilometres, at no cost to the Northern Territory.

He also admitted that the Commonwealth fully funded the east-west trans- continental railway. Only one small section was not funded by the Federal Government. This was an internal railway from Kalgoorlie to Perth. How can the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) maintain that the joint funding of such projects is an established practice? It has been suggested by the Federal Government that the Northern Territory should fund 40 per cent, some $280m, of the railway project from Alice Springs to Darwin. The Minister outlined the projects where there has been no joint funding by referring to the Tarcoola-Alice Springs line and the line from Port Augusta to Western Australia. The Government is desperately trying to wriggle out not only of an election commitment, but also of a guarantee that the Minister gave on 22 April, well after the possible size of the deficit was well known. The Minister cannot hide behind the excuse of the deficit when a guarantee to build the railway was given after the level of the deficit was known.
I think the most sinister aspect of Senator Gietzelt's approach is his insistence:
At no stage did the Government withdraw its support for the building of the Alice Springs-Darwin railway.

That is nonsense. The Government has made an offer which it knows the Northern Territory cannot possibly afford. How can the people of the Northern Territory- every man, woman and child-afford $20 a week? If the Government does not fully fund the building of the railway, it will not go ahead. The responsibility for this very important national project falls squarely at the feet of the Commonwealth. How can the Minister say that the Federal Government has not withdrawn support? Of course it has.

By continually referring to levels of per capita grants, the Government is mounting its own case for hostility towards the Territory. One has to remember when referring to this level of per capita grants from the Commonwealth Government to the Northern Territory that this results through the recommendations of the Commonwealth Grants Commission. That independent authority reviews the situation. I remind the Senate of the considerable support that the mendicant States have received. The Commission has made recommendations as to the funding that should be sufficient to meet the needs of the Northern Territory. I remind honourable senators also that the Territory has a limited population of 150,000 to 160,000 people. However, that population is growing more rapidly than the number of people in any other part of Australia. Many of the people in that number have little or no income. I refer in particular to the Aboriginal component in the Northern Territory which would account for between one-fifth and one-quarter of the population. That is an element of the problem. In the memorandum of understanding between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory which was arranged when the Territory accepted responsibility for self -government, there is a clause which says that, if the Grants Commission finds that there is reason for specific or special funding in some areas, those areas are funded. So let us have no nonsense about this level of per capita grant funding.

Last week in the mini-Budget it was said that some $350m has been put aside to be spent on the creation of jobs. Unfortunately any jobs so created must be looked upon as artificial. The money is withdrawn from projects such as the railway project which create real and lasting jobs. The railway project creates some 1,250 jobs directly. Goodness knows how many jobs would be created indirectly if the project were complete. The steel industry in South Australia is in a very sorry plight. It would have orders for some 150,000 tonnes of steel for that rail project while billions of tonnes of concrete would be needed for sleepers and bridges. There is vast potential in the tourist industry and in trade and commerce. I urge every honourable senator to take more interest in this project because it is most essential to give impetus to the industries that will bring development to the north and assist to provide a much more adequate defence of our northern coastline than we have ever had before.

The development of uranium is absolutely vital for Australia. I know that some honourable senators on the other side are concerned about this matter. At the close of my speech, I would like to table statistics showing the number of nuclear plants that are operating in the world now and those that are under construction. Of course, many more are on the drawing board. Note that many of these nuclear power plants in the world are in Third World countries. This must be the form of energy for these people in the future, to allow their living standards to rise and to approach parity with ours. In the Northern Territory we now see this depressed situation. Koongarra and Jabiluka, million dollar investments with thousands of jobs, are ready to go.

The most ridiculous aspect of the situation is that while the Commonwealth Government says that the Territory must help to fund projects such as the construction of the Alice Springs-Darwin railroad, that it must do this and that , this major industry-a source of development which could bring a large amount of funds into the Northern Territory which would allow it perhaps to fund such projects-has its hands tied behind its back. What a ridiculous situation. I say that the Commonwealth should allow uranium to be sold to the markets that are now very apparent in the world. Let us have no nonsense about there not being markets for uranium. There are markets. As we saw the other day, South Korea has gone to Canada for uranium.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has gone to water.

—It has gone to water, quite correctly, because it will not buy Australian uranium. It is now looking to Canada. A vast amount of money could have come into Australia. I believe in the idea put forward by the Chief Minister for the Northern Territory, Mr Everingham, regarding the sale of uranium to France. He said that Australia, by selling to world markets for uranium for nuclear energy, would have much more influence on other countries. For instance, if Australia sold uranium to the French, it could persuade them to stop nuclear testing in the South Pacific. By supplying Australian uranium to other countries we would have more influence on them. If we supply uranium to France, we would have much more opportunity to say: 'Fair go, cut out the tests' . I think we would have much more chance.

SPEECH.PARA: Pancontenintal and Denison mines have markets, as do Jabiru and Ranger. They are now producing uranium at economic prices. I believe that markets are available now, even though they may be depressed. Prices will certainly increase in the next decade, but those prices are now economic. Figures issued by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development show that by 1985, 55 per cent of electricity in France will be provided by nuclear power. The figure for other European countries is 20 to 40 per cent. I also believe that, as the Federal Government has indicated its concern for Aboriginal people and said that they should be consulted and should be part of the consensus, it should listen to the wishes of the Aboriginal groups. No matter what is said here or in other places, it is the intent of Aboriginal groups in the Arnhem Land area to allow the development and sale of uranium. This has been said quite publicly by the Northern Land Council and by the traditional owners. They want to have uranium developed because they wish to see royalties come their way. Surely one way these people can be assisted materially in upgrading their living standards is by royalties coming to them.

I refer briefly to the paragraph in the Governor-General's speech to a committee that is to be set up to examine major airports in Australia. I do not decry that move at all. I think that Australia is in need of a complete review of its requirements for the development of airports, not only the major airports in Australia but also the lesser ones. The aircraft industry in Australia is developing very rapidly. I hope that Darwin Airport will be looked upon as a major airport. The international terminal there, the gateway to Australia-it sounds odd, but it is still amazingly so-is still in the Worl War II hangar, modified year by year in an effort to bring some sort of semblance of a suitable gateway to the north. Of course this is ridiculous. What a shock people travelling from Singapore, which has a most sophisticated terminal, get when they arrive in a hangar in the north of Australia. As a front door to Australia it gives Australia a bad image.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should have done something about it with Fraser. Fraser had seven years to fix it up.

—There is an interjection: 'Why did not the previous Government do it?' Well, Senator, I hope that instead of making such remarks you do a little homework. The plan for the international airport in Darwin has been brought to the stage where it is to go before the Joint Committee on Public Works. The point I am now making is that I hope that the Government will rectify this situation and allow the development to take place. For people to come in from overseas and to be handled by Customs in such a terminal is really appalling. It takes two hours at times for people to be processed.

SPEECH.PARA: I have heard from the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) in the last week. I refer here to the network of the Australian Broadcasting Commission throughout the outback of Australia. Honourable senators might remember that when Cyclone Tracy struck in the north Radio Australia was blown apart. At that time the Government had plans to set up inland transmitters so that the people of the outback could receive the ABC as do the people of the more heavily populated areas now. According to the original plan, before the inland transmitters went to Shepparton, they were going to beam out from Coffs Harbour through the outback, bringing some semblance of reasonable communications to those people. I notice that in the last 18 months to two years there has been a new plan for the people of the outback. These inland transmitters will not be placed at Cox Peninsula, but a series of transmitters down the centre of the country-at Katherine, Tennant Creek and Alice Springs-will beam out like an umbella to cover all the people of the outback. I would have thought that the people opposite who apparently wish to object-at least they are trying to interject now -had a little more sympathy for these people. Obviously they have not. As I understand it, this type of umbrella communication is going to continue. I commend the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) for that. He has advised me that it will continue. I look forward to developments in the next year.

Another matter that the people of the outback are concerned about was referred to in the Governor-General's Speech. It was indicated that, in accordance with a plank of the Labor Party platform, legislation would be prepared to bring about one vote one value in elections.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is democracy.

—It is democracy depending on where one lives. To the people of the outback one vote one value means that there will be less representation for them, the rural community. There will be a concentration of power in big cities and the contribution of rural communities to the economic health of the country will be ignored. Representation of those who live in the outback will become more difficult because there will be fewer people to do it. Outback communities will be left without proper representation, or at least their representation will be whittled down.
—Because you blokes are not competent to do it.
—Order! There are too many interjections.
—Mr President, I do not mind the interjections, because this debate is on the air.
—You might not, but I do.

—The interjections do not concern me. They merely indicate to the people of Australia who are listening to the debate on the radio now that there is a lack of sympathy for the people of the outback in the policies which have been enunciated by the Labor Party. This lack of sympathy has been clearly indicated. The knocking of the railway link from Alice Springs to Darwin is a national calamity. If the present Government will not fund this most vital link, and if it will not fund development, research, defence and so on, I can say to Australians today, after looking at the mini-Budget, that they will not have to wait long for the funding; they will have to wait only three years.

—Order! Before calling Senator Richardson I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that it is Senator Richardson's first speech in the Senate, and I ask all honourable senators to accord him the usual courtesies .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. I rise for the first time in the Senate to speak to the motion for the Address-in-Reply. Mr President, may I take this opportunity to congratulate you on your elevation to your new position. I am sure that your wisdom and experience will be appreciated by all honourable senators over the course of this Parliament. As I have known you over many years, you may rest assured that I will draw upon that bank of wisdom and experience as often as I am permitted.

SPEECH.PARA: The rejection of Supply by the Senate in 1975 finally debunked all of the myths about this being a States House. The systematic and ruthless bringing to heel of the Senate indians by the chiefs in the Liberal and National Parties, while chilling to recall, is nevertheless instructive for it showed that rigid party loyalty and discipline were the important principles in this place. For my part, I do not quibble with this, provided that it is acknowledged by all and provided that I am forced to witness and endure no more of those turgid diatribes about States rights from the mouths of those who dealt that principle such a devastating death blow only seven years ago.

In the premature election that followed Kerr's act of political banditry in sacking the Whitlam Government, we in the Labor Party watched our support slump to an all time low and saw the dreams, the confidence and the hopes of our long- awaited triumph in 1972 all but obliterated. But it was in those desperate hours , with morale low, with our shell-shocked party wondering just what could happen next, that we were able to demonstrate the rekindling of resilience and spirit which today leaves us as the dominant political force in the nation.

Within six months of our most depressing defeat the flag of Labor was once again hoisted over Australia's most populous and prosperous State-New South Wales. But while Neville Wran had achieved what many believed to be impossible he had incurred the wrath, indeed the undying enmity, of Malcolm Fraser. Both Neville Wran and the electors of New South Wales had displayed an impertinence in that they had dared to disagree, and for Malcolm Fraser this impertinence was too horrible to contemplate.

In the seven years of Liberal-National Party Government the States bore the brunt of the Budget cutbacks. But no State suffered more than New South Wales, the State I represent in this chamber. The Fraser Government deprived New South Wales of its rights under the Commonwealth Grants Commission and discriminated against New South Wales in its infrastructure borrowings. The reason for the Fraser Government's attack on New South Wales was clear. New South Wales would be the base for the revival of the Australian Labor Party and the eventual electoral defeat of the Fraser Government. At least in seven years it got something right. The Fraser Government's unsuccessful attempts to balance the Budget concentrated the cuts in one area, in payments to the States. The champions of States rights in this place have failed to chronicle this phenomenon, yet even a cursory examination of the facts makes it clear. In the seven years from 1975-76 to 1982-83 Federal outlays increased by 115 per cent, while payments to the States from the Federal Budget rose by only 81 per cent.

The Fraser Government hoped that public resentment for these cuts would be focused on State governments rather than itself. Savage cuts in specific purpose payments to all the States occurred in the areas of pre-school and child care and welfare housing. Schemes for upgrading urban public transport, sewerage and hospitals development introduced by the Whitlam Government were abandoned altogether. Payments to the States from the Federal Budget fell in real terms during the seven years of the Fraser Government. However, the Fraser Government took particular steps to disadvantage the New South Wales Government, which from May 1976 was the only Labor Government to serve continuously for the remainder of the Fraser Government's term.

There are many cases of this discrimination, among them the following two blatant ones. The first case was in June 1981, when the Commonwealth Grants Commission recommended that New South Wales should receive a larger share of the general revenue payments to the States. If that recommendation had been accepted New South Wales would have received an extra $140m in 1982-83. The Government then asked for a second report by the Grants Commission. Again the Grants Commission recommended an increased share of the grant to go to New South Wales. The second report recommended a smaller increase for New South Wales because of the significant rise in State revenue from the property boom in 1980-81. Two successive inquiries by the Grants Commission recommended significant increases in the share of Federal general purpose revenue funds paid to New South Wales but the end result was that the New South Wales share of general purpose revenue funds was reduced by $2m. The hostility of the Federal Government to a successful Labor government in New South Wales was such that by convoluted logic two Grants Commission recommendations for an increase in the New South Wales share in Federal general purpose grants were translated into a reduction.

The second case was in 1978, when the Federal Government launched its infrastructure borrowing program. The purpose of the program was to allow the States to borrow to provide infrastructure for major industrial developments such as railway lines for coal transport, port developments for the export of coal and minerals and power stations for new power consuming industries. In a Press conference on 4 December 1979 Mr Fraser criticised New South Wales for not constructing power stations at what he considered a satisfactory rate. He claimed that one aluminium smelter could not be sited in New South Wales because of the lack of power. In 1980 New South Wales submitted a detailed program for a further acceleration to its power stations construction bid. This proposal was rejected at the Premiers' Conference in June 1980 on the ground that the proposal had been submitted late. Yet Victoria and Western Australia had submitted less detailed plans for power stations later than New South Wales. Both the West Australian and Victorian proposals from the then Liberal governments were approved. At the same meeting approval was given for borrowings for new railway lines in Queensland despite the fact that no formal proposal at all had been made by Queensland to the Loan Council.

Under a Hawke Labor Government these tawdry, mean examples of political point- scoring will be, like the Fraser Government's claim to being a good economic manager, a thing of the past. No Australian will be discriminated against merely because a particular State government is of a different persuasion from our own.

The strategy of the Fraser Government was to impose financial pressure on New South Wales and then hope that this would turn voters away from the Federal Labor Party. This is best illustrated by advertisements in Sydney newspapers, for example, the Daily Mirror on 3 March 1983, two days before the former Government's eventual defeat. The advertisement referred to New South Wales taxes and ended with the exhortation: 'Don't let Hawke's Labor Government bankrupt Australia'. If Bob Hawke and Paul Keating can match Neville Wran in the field of financial management, they will have served Australia well.

Despite the Fraser Government's shabby treatment of New South Wales, the Wran Government can proclaim a Budget deficit per capita of just $104.31. This is in stark contrast to that of Queensland where the Budget deficit per capita is a staggering $452.88-four and a half times greater than that of New South Wales.

The last election was won by the Australian Labor Party on the issue of unemployment. This Government will sink or swim on its performance in providing jobs. It is worth examining why the Fraser Government's record in unemployment finally proved its undoing. On 11 October 1982, Mr Peacock, the prodigal son, was welcomed back to the Ministry as the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Since that time more people have lost their jobs than in any other period of Australia's history, including the Depression. Under Mr Peacock's term as Minister for Industry and Commerce, in just six months a further 225,000 people lost their jobs and unemployment rose by 3.1 per cent. In the past 12 months 96, 000 jobs were lost in manufacturing industries and nearly 9,000 were lost in construction industries. How did the Liberal Party reward the Minister who presided over that disaster? It made him its leader.

The task before this Government is clear. It must not only stop this process of rapid decline for Australian industries but also reverse it. The most alarming feature is that many of these lost jobs may never be recreated. Without sound manufacturing industries Australia will have no base for recovery once the recession is over. Without industry Australia would be at the mercy of world forces and transnational companies. The answers to the problems faced by Australian industries are not simple. But for us to sit idly by and let our industries disappear in the name of economic rationalisation is a crime-an organised crime-against the Australian people.

What industry needs-in fact, this was stated at the National Economic Summit Conference-is not an increase in protection but a moratorium on the phasing down of protection for Australian industries. The Government's position on this question was stated quite clearly by the Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, when he delivered Labor's policy speech at the Sydney Opera House on 16 February this year. He said:
We cannot satisfactorily rebuild our work force unless at the same time we rebuild our manufacturing base.
This requires both measures to deal with the immediate crisis, and measures for long term reconstruction.
Until this crisis is overcome, there will be no reduction of existing protection levels.

Futhermore, the conclusion drawn from the investigation of the Crawford Study Group on Structural Adjustment in Australia is that the phasing out of protection cannot take place during a recession. These schemes can be introduced only during periods of growth, when people who lose their jobs have the opportunity of finding alternative employment. Even then, according to the Crawford Committee, these schemes can only occur when a package of assistance measures are in place and working.

In the area of industry protection Australia is still in the learning process. Industries in other countries enjoy sophisticated, specialised assistance and protection schemes which place Australian industries at a decided disadvantage. Australia needs to examine these options and it needs to examine them now. We need to consider strengthening the anti-dumping legislation. The dumping of cheap, imported goods on to Australian markets is currently crippling Australia' s manufacturers who cannot possibly compete. Honourable senators would be aware that the Government is taking the lead in this area with the amendments to the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975, which go a long way to alleviating this problem.

We need to conduct a full review of developing country preference status, examining both the countries receiving the preferences and the grounds by which these preferences have been granted. At present there are 170 countries receiving developing country preferences. While it is true that all these countries in some form or another are still developing, it is ludicrous to suggest that all countries on the list are developing in all industries. For example, South Korea's steel products are still afforded developing country preference assistance when South Korea's steel industry is far more technologically advanced and far more efficient than our own steel industry.

We need also to examine the whole area of government purchasing. Under Fraser the Australian Government would not guarantee Australian manufacturers preferences in government purchases. Under Fraser the Australian Government turned its back on Australian industries. The obvious motive was to increase Fraser's own prestige amongst our trading nations. But where did that get us? In the last year alone 96,000 jobs were lost in manufacturing and more losses are pending. The policy of Australian industry preference in government purchasing must be reinstated now and must incorporate all government departments and all statutory corporations such as Telecom Australia.

Besides these relatively unexplored areas of assistance to industry, we must also fully examine the more orthodox measures of assistance such as tariffs, quota system and subsidies. In the present economic climate where Australian industries are under their heaviest assault since the Depression, we must not be afraid to increase short term tariff production to our industries if the situation warrants it. This plea comes from employers and employees alike. It should not be besmirched or belittled for it is a noble plea which expresses the pride of all those generations who have been conditioned to believe that the right to work is among the most basic rights of all Australians.

If real assistance is not forthcoming to Australian industries, their rapid decline will be accelerated. If protection and assistance levels are lowered, it will lead to a substantial loss of jobs amongst our manufacturing industries; it will lead to the creation of large depressed regions; it will lead to massive increases in Australia's social welfare payments; and it will lead to a community divided between those people with jobs against those without.

Supporters of lower protection argue that greater opportunities will arise to other Australian industries. Mr Anthony, shadow Minister for Trade, in a speech made to the Australian-British Trade Association on 20 April, this year, stated that, in Australia's case:
Increased protection will limit the potential for increasing the standard of living of its people.

I ask him: What are the standards of living like for people in areas such as Wollongong, Newcastle or Whyalla who have lost their livelihoods as a result of those policies? What are the standards of living like for the 707,000 people who no longer have jobs, no longer have hope or opportunity and now face life on a dole queue? Such is the legacy that Fraser and Anthony have left behind!

Lower protection or economic rationalisation may have some validity and even applicability to Australia, if it were a global trend-if the rest of the world's nations were genuinely reducing importing restrictions or if the major industrial nations were embarking earnestly upon a free trade policy. The fact is that most countries are moving towards increased protection for their domestic industries. In the steel industry, for example, since 1975, the European Economic Community's aid payments to its steel industries amount to $ A30 billion or $A45 per tonne of raw steel alone. The EEC has also introduced a system of import quotas, protecting its industries even further. On the other side of the ledger, the EEC under its common agricultural policy is excluding all Australia's rural products.

In the United States of America, the steel industry has benefited from regulations that limit exports to low proportions of the United States market. For example, the EEC is limited to supplying only 5.75 per cent of the United States steel market. American steel producers also enjoy substantial depreciation tax provisions. In Australia, while we contemplate protection for our steel industries, 15,263 jobs have been lost already and a further 13,000 jobs are under threat.

If Labor is to fulfil its election promise to maintain a viabile and efficient steel industry, it will need to give this question urgent and positive consideration. The first line of the Labor Party's national economic platform reads:
Labor believes the ultimate aim of economic policy is to promote the well-being of the people.

I am committed to this proposition. The destruction of Australia's manufacturing industries is not for the well being of the people. And to consider seriously substantially reduced protection measures as an option at the present time, in the present climate, is to jettison the future of too many Australians, young and old, who look to the Australian Labor Party and Bob Hawke as their saviours, not their executioners.

I now wish to direct my attention to the area of electoral reform which is of particular concern to me. As a former General Secretary of the New South Wales Branch of the Labor Party and the campaign director for both Federal and State elections for the last seven years, I am acutely aware of the need for reform of our current electoral procedures and practices.

For parliamentary democracy to function effectively, viable and healthy political parties are essential. To achieve this, political parties need to have sufficient resources available to them. The cold reality is that it is becoming more and more impossible for political parties to finance their campaign obligations and still retain their integrity.

Parties are estimated to have spent between $7m and $8m on electronic media coverage alone in the last election. To pretend that we can cope with that by collecting donations from loyal supporters is to refuse to face facts honestly. Even our conservative opponents, who enjoy considerable financial advantages over the Australian Labour Party, are starting to feel the pinch of campaign financing. Honourable senators should just ask the New South Wales branch of the Liberal party-I might say it is now asking for public funds from the New South Wales Government-which is in the process of eliminating a $2m debt or the National Party of Western Australia, which has now gone into receivership, whether they need funds to remain viable political units.

Why, then, should public money be used to finance political parties in election campaigns? The answer is, simply, to prevent even the possibility or appearance of governments being bought by those who make large, and mostly secret, contributions to party funds. There can be no issue more central to our system of government. We destroy the integrity of our political parties we destroy democracy. Public funding should be available to all political parties and independents who poll enough votes to demonstrate a significant level of public support. It is important that public funding must not be brought into disrepute- perhaps irreparable disrepute-by the electorate perceiving that public funds were being made available to what might best be termed ratbag candidates or fringe parties. Therefore, the threshold for public assistance needs to be high enough to ensure that those political parties which are anathema to the overwhelming majority of electors are not the recipients of public funds.

The public funds should be made available to the parties for the conduct of their election campaigns, both in regard to the costly media campaigns and for essential campaign material; for the conduct of by-election and referenda campaigns; for research into specific policy issues and electoral behaviour; for education of rank and file party members and for the general public; and for the general running of party organisations. It is apparent from these views that I see public funding as being more than just for elections. The people of Australia are entitled to more than just a cursory look at alternative policies in the climate of a frantic four-week election campaign. As a society we must ensure that the level of understanding of our people is elevated and that parties have the major role to play in that process. The financial cost in that context becomes almost insignificant.

To administer and oversee public funding an independent electoral funds commission needs to be established. One of the major tasks of this new commission would be to ensure that the closest scrutiny is kept on the disbursement and expenditure of public money. The recipients of public assistance must fully account for all expenditure and it should be within the commission's role to ensure that no public money has been misappropriated and that all funds that have been disbursed have been expended properly, according to the guidelines of the Act. A further and most crucial aspect of public funding is that ceilings should be established on both the maximum amount of media time that can be used by a particular party and on the total amount expended by any one party during a campaign. Public funding must not only guarantee equity in terms of the resources available to political parties but also ensure that massive financial or organisational resources cannot buy political power in the democratic Australian context, so that equity in terms of influence is also maintained.

Another important area of electoral reform is the disclosure of all campaign funds and donations. At present we have the disturbing situation in which we do not know how much is spent on campaigning by the political parties. Nor do we know from where those funds come. No society that prides itself on the right of its people to make a genuine choice can tolerate such a situation. No proper choice can be made without such basic information. We can judge a lot about a party if we know where the money comes from. At present, without full public accounting, we do not know the source of the money being donated to the parties. When we consider that in the last election expenditure was approximately $12m-$ 10m of which was spent, I might say, by our conservative opponents-we are talking about the possibility of a lot of influence being bought.

I am a great believer in altruism, but I also believe that quite a few people who make big donations do so in the hope that they have bought influence for the future. Public disclosure of campaign donations has met with vehement opposition from the conservative parties on the spurious ground that it is an invasion of civil liberties. I believe that the people of Australia have a right to know where the campaign funds emanate. As we are all well aware, in the past the Liberal and National parties have been the recipients of some very large undisclosed donations. We can only speculate on what, or whom, those donations bought. It would be interesting to see whether any correlation exists between where that money came from and the policy directions taken by the former Government. I suggest that by their reluctance to disclose these sources they give at least the impression that they have something to hide.

I now turn to other areas of electoral reform which directly affect all honourable senators. The evidence for much needed overhaul of electoral laws is overwhelming. One merely has to look at the informal Senate vote in my home State of New South Wales for the past decade. Since 1974, when 73 candidates stood and the informal vote was 12.3 per cent, in four elections the best result was 9.4 per cent in 1980, and the informal vote was back to 11 per cent in 1983. A total of 341,787 New South Wales electors cast an informal vote in the last election. They were, by no fault of their own, disenfranchised. We had the case in the 1974 election in the electorate of Sydney where the Senate informal vote was a staggering 20.2 per cent. One in five voters was effectively denied his right to vote. In the last election, in the electorate of Port Adelaide, the Senate informal vote was 14.1 per cent and in the electorate of Lalor it was an astounding 16.3 per cent. In the last election for the Senate, 872,626 people, almost a million Australians, cast an informal vote. This situation strikes at the very heart of democracy and must be remedied as a matter of urgency.

The first remedy to be looked at-or should be looked at-is optional preferential voting. This system allows for an elector to vote for a proportion of the number of candidates seeking election and still have the vote declared formal. This system would mean a voter could, in a half Senate election, vote for as few as three candidates, instead of having to vote for 60 or 70 candidates-a daunting task for a college professor, but an impossibility for a very large section of our community. It will free the great multitude of voters, up to 95 per cent of electors, who vote for the major parties-I include the Australian Democrats, of course, as a major party-of the burden and pressure of voting for 60 or 70 candidates. The ethnic and Aboriginal communities, the aged, the sick and the less educated, for the first time can be given a real chance to participate in our democracy.

Those who doubt that this system enables many more voters to cast a formal vote need merely to examine the election figures for the New South Wales Legislative Council since optional preferential voting was introduced. In 1981, when 45 candidates stood for election for the Legislative Council, the informal vote was just over 4 per cent-in stark contrast to the Senate figures which I previously outlined. In past years the Senate ticket, particularly in New South Wales, has been flooded by peripheral or fringe candidates. In some instances many used their candidature for cheap publicity reasons, as was evidenced by a rock star and a disk jockey running in some of those elections. It is obvious that many candidates or groups are merely joke candidates without any broad community support or serious intent in regard to winning votes. But, by cluttering up the ticket, they cause thousands of ordinary Australians, with a genuine concern for the future of their country, to vote informally.

The whole question of Senate candidature needs to be overhauled. We must examine a system whereby candidates seeking election to the Senate need to be nominated for that position by a certain number of qualified electors in a majority of the Federal seats within that State. This effectively means that candidates must be able to show that they have some electoral support throughout the State they hope to represent. Secondly, we should raise the deposit from the paltry $200 to a level which would impose a more appropriate financial penalty if the deposit was forfeited. These two measures should guarantee that candidates for the Senate are genuine candidates who would be taking the election seriously and would have some community support.

Any system of voting which disenfranchises one in 10 electors is in need of drastic overhaul. I trust that these suggestions are given serious consideration by the Joint Committee on Electoral Reform, on which I have the privilege to serve. It is reassuring that my sentiments on and my eagerness for, electoral reform are not just shared by honourable senators on this side of the chamber. Senator Chaney, the Leader of the Opposition, who was then the Minister for Administrative Services and thus responsible for electoral matters in this House on 6 June 1979 stated:

I emphasise that it is part of the general view of the Government that not only Aboriginals but also other disadvantaged people in the community, disadvantaged in the sense that they are less able than others to take advantage of the electoral laws which exist to safeguard their rights to vote should be assisted in regard to this matter.
It is part of our general thrust to assist all of those disadvantaged groups . . . It is important that they have some say in who should govern the country, or indeed their State.

However, while Senator Chaney and the Government in which he served did nothing whatsoever to give effect to those noble sentiments, this Government will ensure that much needed reforms do take place. While I do not wish to make a habit of quoting Senator Chaney, I will also quote from his maiden speech delivered on 25 September 1974, which gave me some inspiration. He said:
We have still to learn to use the right rhetoric for the '70s--
He was referring to the Liberal Party--

the words that will inspire people. Perhaps we will not ever learn to use that rhetoric. I hope that the people of Australia are becoming suspicious of rhetoric and clever debating, and that in the next election there will be a more realistic assessment of what is being offered to the Australian people.

I can assure Senator Chaney that, in the last election, that more realistic assessment was made. I hope, in the interests of parliamentary democracy, that his party, having failed to come to grips with the rhetoric of the 1970s, will have better luck with the rhetoric of the 1980s. So far there is no sign of this occurring.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before calling Senator Boswell, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that this is Senator Boswell's first speech in the Senate. I ask all honourable senators to accord him the normal courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pride that I stand before this chamber tonight to make my first contribution as the only member of the Opposition who gained a new place in this Parliament. I am aware of my responsibilities to the people of Queensland and Australia and I give notice now that I will be one of the strongest advocates to protect the rights of my State, given under the Constitution. My party believes in a federal system of government and I will fight tooth and nail to make sure that Queensland's rights are not subjugated to a centralist Australian Labor Party Government trying to base all power in Canberra. No person achieves the honour of gaining representation to this House without a party structure behind him. I acknowledge my debt to my party and the trust placed in me to represent Queensland and Queenslanders.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Party of Australia can trace its origins back to 1893 when the circumstances of the day demonstrated the need for a party to look after the political needs of the small businessman, the struggling settler and the people who wanted jobs. That need is as relevant today as it was 90 years ago. The results of the recent Victorian by-election prove that this party is in the ascendancy. I will state now that after the next Federal election we will have at least one more senator from Victoria and another one from Queensland occupying the National Party benches of this chamber. The National Party supports the private enterprise philosophy in that it encourages people to run their own businesses. The National Party, however, will not and does not support the argument that the market must find its own level, the big must get bigger and the small must wither and die. My party wishes to see private enterprise flourish and grow with all Australians enjoying the benefits which this creates. It believes that the growth of private enterprise creates real and lasting jobs, not the artificial jobs which this Government is promoting and which will disappear as soon as the public funding runs out.

The National Party is a party of achievement-achievement for Australia. Its history is highlighted by great individuals-people such as McEwen, Fadden and Joh Bjelke-Petersen. I take my place with pride, yet with humility. I pay tribute to the lady who sits on my left, Senator Florence Bjelke-Petersen. When she was elected to this chamber three years ago she was greeted with caution, to say the least. She has proved in Queensland that she is the most popular member of Federal Parliament because of her tireless work in the electorate. I wish to place on record my thanks to the retail industry of Queensland for its support during the election campaign. I also thank the fishing industry and all other groups of small business people who had faith in me and believe that I can represent their interests in Federal Parliament. I gave them my assurance that I will be fighting for their cause and meant it.

Two weeks ago this chamber heard a speech by Senator Crowley who used as her theme the international socialists' song Bread and Roses. As I listened it was my view that, in truth, both sides of the chamber wanted the same thing for the people of Australia. The difference was in the way this could be achieved. The National Party in Queensland in a tangible way has provided policies to enable people to have 'bread'. The bible on which I took an oath of allegiance only the other day states that man cannot live by bread alone. The National Party deliberately aims at policies which give the opportunity for people to have bread and for roses to bloom. The National Party is the party that has been able to offer the people of Queensland the lowest taxes of any State in Australia. State taxes are some 50 per cent higher in New South Wales and some 70 per cent higher in Victoria. My party believes that the Federal system of taxation is antiquated and needs a complete review. A more equitable system needs to be introduced based on providing initiatives and not penalising effort. Surely people who create jobs do not deserve to be penalised.

The Queensland Government was the first in Australia to take the courageous step to abolish death taxes, thus forcing every other government to follow suit. This was a National Party initiative and one that probably has done more for the rural industry than any other policy. In the past we saw the family farm being sold off or large parts of it being hived off to meet probate duties. It was a vindictive tax because it took away a man's life work from his family after he had paid tax all his life. It absolutely astounds me to hear that some sections of the Cain Government want it reintroduced. I told the people about this when I campaigned in Warrnambool. It probably had something to do with the low that the Labor Party received-it came in last. The National Party certainly deserved to win Warrnambool. The National's State taxation policies have ensured that slowly , but surely, the exemption level of payroll tax is being raised, thus helping small business to create more jobs and employ more people.

These are the basic bread policies initiated by the Bjelke-Petersen-led Government and what a proud record he has to stand on when he faces the people in the next State election. I guarantee that he will increase his majority. It should be noted too that 1,000 people are coming to Queensland every week. Queensland's interstate gain is almost equal to the number of people fleeing from the socialist governments of Victoria and New South Wales. People are marching to Queensland because they know that a National Party-led Government will provide them and their families with jobs. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that 28,000 people gave employment as the reason for moving to Queensland. Indeed, Quensland's job creation record is the one bright spot in Australia's employment statistics. For the period of the wage pause, Queensland, with only 16 per cent of Australia's population, created 28 per cent of Australia's jobs.

The State Government is trying hard to create employment. But it is being frustrated by the Federal Government's policy to turn away foreign investment. This Labor Government should be honest with the unemployed and tell them how many jobs the Foreign Investment Review Board has spiked in just the last seven weeks. I shudder every time I hear that the Labor Government has shelved another project. How can it say that it is looking after north Queensland when it has shelved the Townsville domestic terminal project and refuses to honour a commitment of the former Government to fund a feasibility study for the Bradfield scheme, a scheme which could have tremendous implications for north Queensland and for Australia as a whole?
