That scheme could provide Australia with another Darling Downs and if it was feasible it would provide many more jobs for the unemployed of north Queensland. Furthermore, it has become well known in Cairns, which faces a serious unemployment problem, that the construction schedule for five naval patrol boats is to be slowed down.

The people of Queensland are fast becoming disillusioned. They cannot complain because this Government has abolished specific ministerial responsibilities for northern development and there is no Federal Minister with an electorate north of Brisbane and only one in Queensland. How one Minister can look after the total needs of Queensland is beyond me. Even the Australian Labor Party in Queensland, according to media reports, is disillusioned with the Hawke Labor Government. Mr Hawke has left our colleague Senator Reynolds way out on a limb because he has given her no answers for the people of north Queensland. She is going to have to do some fast footwork when I go to north Queensland and explain how this Government is treating the people there. Last year 50,000 people came to Queensland. They came because they believed a private enterprise government could provide them with a better chance of employment and a better chance of owning their own home. Far more importantly, they came because Queensland could provide far more opportunities for a stable future for their children. This is what we must be talking about in both chambers-the creation of a better future for all Australians.

When we talk about creating new jobs and better opportunities, we must talk about small business. Small business is becoming a section of the vote that all parties are wooing. I can honestly say that I understand the problems of small business. I established my own business on 18 years of sheer drive and initiative. That business ended up employing 10 people out of one man's initiative. That is the type of small business that creates jobs. As I look toward the Government benches, I see union representatives and academics. There is no one there who really understands small business. The National Party, particularly in Queensland, is helping small business deliberately to create new jobs. That is why I can say the National Party has more in common with the worker and any other party represented in this chamber. It is a party of self- made people who, every time they make something, also provide more opportunities for working men and women.

In Queensland some 500,000 people are involved in small business. The Senate will have heard many times the following facts, but they warrant repeating: Small business enterprises employ over 50 per cent of the total work force; collectively, small businesses with up to 10 employees contribute more than half of the profit of the business sector; and small business contributes more in tax revenue than big business, including most of the resource development sector. Small business is an under-represented section in and outside parliament. It was not considered important enough for the National Economic Summit Conference. More needs to be done in future to weld this section of business into a recognised organisation. Small business ultimately must develop as much clout as the Australian Council of Trade Unions and be as effective as the National Farmers' Federation. My party will be working with all the vigor and force that it can muster to achieve this.

The small business section needs a tax system that will not bankrupt small operators. The taxation system, as it now stands, takes everything made this year and, through provisional tax, most of what the Australian Taxation Office thinks is going to be made 'next year'. Small business needs the implementation of an education scheme whereby the small operator can learn the principles of business management such as the control of overheads and the relation of sales to profit and profit to overheads. So many times we see excellent tradesmen and people with various skills establish their own businesses and fail because they have not got the faintest idea of business management. Generally, they lose their homes and any other assets they have built up. It needs the funding for three years of a federal small business organisation which can report and represent the needs of small business to the Government. The Queensland State Government has established such an organisation-the Small Business Development Corporation. It knows the contribution that small business makes to Queensland. Since 1893 the National Party, as I said earlier, has helped small business. It is still helping this important group.

Last year my party rejected out of hand moves to deregulate trading hours. It knew the devastating effect that this would have on small retailers and on the family unit. Parents would have to work on weekends and thus their children would be unable to enjoy the company of their parents on Sunday-to go to church or just have a family day together. The Premier has promised that in the next parliamentary session a Bill will be introduced to protect tenants from unscrupulous practices in retail shop leases; and, of course, everyone in Queensland knows that what Joh says, he does. My party wants to ensure that small business can continue to be the nation's leading employer and give the bread that is basic to life.

It is clear that Labor State governments, and probably the Hawke Government too , do not understand small business. They talk about it and make promises but they do not act; not one Labor State government has legislated on shopping centre leases. They promised to do it. In Queensland, the Government is strong and positive-it acts and carries out its promises. The Labor Party promises tax cuts, lower petrol prices, but fails to deliver. It works to a plan. It is to promise and renege. Premiers Wran, Cain, Bannon and Burke did it. So did Mr Hawke. I repeat: The National Party-led Government promises only what it can deliver. There are no illusions and no deceptions.

I now wish to talk about roses. All people have holidays and Queensland is blooming as the best place to holiday. In 1982, 33,000 Americans alone visited Queensland, the majority coming in via Townsville. The Gold Coast attracted 81, 000 overseas visitors. The tourist industry is now worth $1.7m to Queensland's economy. Its growth rate is 7.4 per cent compared with the national average of 1 .6 per cent. This exceptional growth rate in Queensland's tourist industry did not just happen; it was a result of a State government initiative to set up the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation-an efficient, independent body to promote Queensland. It is doing a magnificent job. The tourist industry leads the way for job creation. Many more jobs could be made, however, if penalty rates were abolished. In Queensland alone it is estimated that 10,000 extra jobs could be created. The ALP and the unions acknowledge that tourism is one of the few industries that has any real job growth. There should be a new tourist award to cover the industry and wages should be restructured to enable penalty payments to be abolished. This is National Party policy.

The National Party-led Government has given jobs and hope to thousands of Australians, in contrast to this Government that was elected on the promise of creating 500,000 jobs. Until 19 May, I had not seen one initiative or piece of legislation that would create one job, let alone half a million. What the electorate got was cosmetic jobs-jobs which will last for six months. This country needs a private enterprise-led recovery, not public sector pump priming. Where was the help for small business and industry? They were ignored! The primary producers were the ones who had to pick up one third of the recovery tab . This Government's priorities are not recovery and jobs. Let us look at its record: Stopping the Tasmanian dam; vetoing finance for development on the Gold Coast; shelving the Townsville domestic airport development; and slowing down construction of the five patrol boats being built in Cairns.

I now want to mention the proposed Sex Discrimination Bill. The subject of this Bill and its interpretation is putting women against women, Christians against alternative religions and family against family. In other words, it is developing into an ugly and unnecessary struggle in the Australian community. It has the capacity to be the most divisive subject debated in this Parliament since the abortion matter. Consultation and consensus supposedly are the Hawke Labor Government's modus operandi. I call upon Senator Susan Ryan and the Hawke Labor Government to drop this Bill as it is dividing the community. There is no consensus. There is only confrontation. Evidence of the opposition to this Bill may be ascertained by the thousands of petitions coming to both chambers and requesting the Government not to proceed with the Bill.

In conclusion, as a Queensland senator, I will do all in my power to aid the growth and development of this nation as a whole-Queensland in particular-so that the vision of bread and roses will be obtainable by all Australians. My special interest will be, however, small business. This is the industry which, if allowed, will provide bread and roses for more than half Australia's work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before calling Senator Maguire, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that this is Senator Maguire's first speech in the Senate. I ask all honourable senators to accord him the normal courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great pleasure in supporting the motion. I am aware of the great honour conferred upon me by the electors of South Australia on 5 March. I am aware of my great responsibility to the people of South Australia and intend to serve them in full through the national Parliament. Mr President, I congratulate you on your elevation to the Senate's highest office and look forward to serving here with your guidance.

SPEECH.PARA: It was the intention of the Founding Fathers at the original constitutional conventions to establish a national upper House of parliament to protect the smaller States. It was also their intention to establish a House of review. Those intentions eventually became reality in the Senate. As the Australian political system evolved, the Senate became more of a party House; less emphasis was given to its role as a forum for the States. The successful 1977 referendum on the filling of Senate casual vacancies endorsed the role of parties in the Constitution. That referendum provided that casual vacancies be filled by persons from the same political party as those formerly occupying seats. Since 1979 it has been the policy of the Australian Labor Party to reform rather than abolish the Senate. Labor's policy to expand and develop the very valuable committee system of the Senate is worthy of support.

It is an honour to be elected to the Senate as a member of the Australian Labor Party. I thank the many members of branches and trade unions affiliated with the Labor Party who supported me. I wish also to thank my family for their strong support and I acknowledge their sacrifices over the years.

The Australian Labor Party is the longest established political party in Australia. It is the democratic socialist party in Australia which stands for equity and social justice. I am proud to have the opportunity to uphold those principles in this place.

I am the thirtieth Labor senator from South Australia since the Senate was first elected 82 years ago. My predecessors have in general been long-serving members of this place and have represented the community well. I am encouraged by the longevity of my predecessors and by their contributions here. The twenty- sixth ALP senator from South Australia was Geoff McLaren. Senator McLaren was elected in 1970 and was a member of this place for almost 12 years. It is worth noting that he defeated the now South Australian Premier, John Bannon, in the ALP pre-selection for the 1970 Senate team. Senator Mclaren always took up a challenge. He was a tireless worker for South Australia and the Labor movement. In particular, he was a hard working representative of the country people of South Australia from his office in Murray Bridge. I believe that the Murray Bridge Post Office is now a much quieter place with his going. I wish Geoff McLaren and his wife Beryl well in their retirement, and I am sure that all other honourable senators join with me. I am delighted to see Senator Crowley here as the first Labor woman in Canberra from South Australia. I regret that Brian Keneally, the other member of our Senate team, was not elected.

I welcome and applaud the election of the first Federal Labor Government in over seven years. In South Australia we gained the division of Kingston and the Labor Party now holds seven of the 11 electorates. If all States matched this proportion of seats the ALP majority would be very comfortable indeed. It is worth noting that while Labor was in Opposition my State elected a majority of ALP members.

In many areas South Australia has been a pioneering State. In 1840 it innovated in the area of local government when the Adelaide municipality was incorporated- the first in Australia. In 1858 the Real Property Act came into effect. That Act broke from past practice and embodied Torrens's principles of property conveyancing. As a consequence there is great simplicity in land titling in South Australia that is the envy of many other places. In 1876 South Australia was the first State to give legal recognition to trade unions. Before that time the bodies representing industrial workers had an uncertain role. In view of this enlightened attitude to trade unions it is no coincidence that my State for many years has had the lowest rate of industrial disputation in Australia.

In 1910 the first majority Labor Government in the world was elected in South Australia under the leadership of John Verran. That was a real milestone which was to be marked later in many other places in the world. In 1975 the Independent Electoral Districts Boundaries Commission was established, taking the drawing of State electoral boundaries out of the hands of governments. Both the Liberal Party and the Labor Party have won elections on boundaries drawn by the Independent Commission. Now my State has the electoral system which is possibly the most responsive to community choice. It was evident at the recent Constitutional Convention that the debate over the drawing of electoral boundaries still rages elsewhere in Australia.

In recent years South Australia has borne the brunt of the economic problems facing Australia. The severity of the State's economic difficulties is linked to its high reliance upon manufacturing. It is that sector of the economy which has experienced the greatest pressures. Problems in South Australia have been more intense because relatively few industries dominate the manufacturing sector there. The industrial structure is heavily dependent upon motor vehicle manufacturing, steel making and white goods. The particular problems of those industries are very evident and have been reflected in massive numbers of retrenchments. If and when the General Motors-Holden's Ltd plant at Woodville closes, people living in the surrounding suburbs will be crippled economically. The area is already hard hit by the recession, with 1,300 people a day having contact with the local social security office.

For almost every month in recent years South Australia, unfortunately, has had the highest or second highest unemployment rate of any State. Indeed, for 23 consecutive months in 1980 and 1981 South Australia had the highest jobless rate .

Clearly the economic difficulties there have not just been the result of temporary factors. The monthly tallies of unemployment figures cannot express the despair, lack of dignity and social in- justice which are the human stories behind the loss of a job. Even those who still have jobs are facing the worry and uncertainty that by the end of the week they too may join the ranks of the unemployed. In Australia there can be no social justice before there is a return to full employment. In those parts of Australia where jobs have been harder to come by the goal of full employment would be achieved more readily with special assistance from the national Government. That would be one way to begin ridding Australia of inequalities of a spatial nature.

A regional policy needs to be developed to supplement the Government's main thrust, to achieve economic recovery. In the past, it seems that economic policy in Australia has been based on conditions in the largest capital cities, conditions which may not be as severe as elsewhere. Sales tax has been increased sharply in recent years, with little attention being given to the distribution among the States of the industries which are taxed.

Regional policies and regional programs are needed so that many more jobs can be created in the most disadvantaged parts of Australia. The standard argument against the development of regional policy in this country goes that there is no real difference in economic conditions throughout Australia. That argument must now be seriously questioned. It appears that Australia has become divided into an economic centre and outlying areas, which share less in the benefits. At the periphery are States such as South Australia and Tasmania. Both should be seen as regions for the development of special assistance programs. I am aware that the mover of this Address-in-Reply would argue that that should also be the case for north Queensland. The announcement of new regional policies by the ALP earlier this year is an important beginning.

The formulation of regional policy could be served by the development of new government machinery. At present, the highly respected Commonwealth Grants Commission tries to take into account the special needs of each State in the delivery of government services. The Grants Commission uses long-established guidelines in allocating finance. Since the 1930s there has been an attempt here to ensure that adequate resources are available to all State governments. But, half a century later, public policy still is really only about resources available to governments. Each State's distribution of private sector resources is not taken into account in developing economic policy. This is surprising, given that the private sector is the major part of the economic system. Little account is taken if a State is suffering from large scale closures in industries . Until the special needs of industries in certain areas are identified on a comprehensive basis the underlying economic problems of a region will not be addressed. I emphasise this need for comprehensive studies of regional industries. The potential for growth in each region should be studied too. Appropriate policies should include the relocation of some Commonwealth Government employment to areas suffering the most severe job crises.

Labor now faces the challenge of reversing the inequalities imposed on the community in recent years. In view of budgetary constraints that, of course, must be a longer term task. Government actions in recent years had a regressive effect on the distribution of income and wealth. The thrust of some measures tended to overlook the needs of the most disadvantaged Australians. For example, funds allocated for Aboriginal programs were almost halved in real terms. Taxpayers on low incomes suffered a decline in disposable income under the effects of tax changes yet, inexplicably, people earning high incomes enjoyed a strong increase in disposable income. One of the greatest inequities was that interest rates rose to record levels with crippling effects on young home buyers .

Regressive policies should not be allowed to persist and must be reversed. Priority should be given to making the taxation system more progressive, including the reduction of the relative burden of sales tax and other hidden taxes.

The Governor-General's Speech referred to a wide range of proposals and legislation to enhance the quality of government in Australia and to strengthen the foundations of parliamentary democracy. The Governor-General referred to legislation to ensure that the principle of one vote one value is clearly established. It was also indicated that there would be moves for the public funding of elections and measures to reduce informal voting through the development of simpler voting procedures. It is pleasing to note that there is momentum at last in the areas of electoral and constitutional reform by a Commonwealth government. It is long overdue. Australia once was a real innovator in these fields and was a world leader. Sadly, we fell behind because of government inaction and community complacency. Australia now has a very long way to go if it is to match the reforms being implemented elsewhere. There is a pressing need to do so because we have one of the most complex voting systems in the world.

A number of major electoral reforms occurred in Australia in the nineteenth century and early twentieth century. In 1856 Victoria and South Australia introduced secret electoral ballots, a world first and a radical departure from previous voting methods. They became known as the Australian ballot, and secret ballots still are described in this way in some countries. In 1894, South Australia legislated for voting rights for women. It was not a world first, but South Australia was among the world leaders. When the Federal electoral boundaries were first drawn they basically reflected the principle of one vote one value. At the time few electoral systems in the world did so. There were even moves early in this century to allow the use of voting machines in Australia. In 1908 the South Australian electoral Act was amended to provide that such machines could be used. It is a matter of interest that that section still exists in the Act.

The Commonwealth electoral system has tended to become more complicated and, probably, less equitable in its effect since World War I. Following the formulation of the Country Party, preferential voting was introduced to avoid splitting the conservative vote. In 1934 full preferentail voting was applied for Senate elections, the basic cause of today's high level of informal votes. Later, the first legislation was passed requiring that rural Federal electorates should have a lower enrolment that others.

Not all electors are able to cast a valid vote because they are frustrated and defeated by our electoral system. The system should be there to help them express their choice effectively. In my State this year the total number of Senate informal votes almost attained one quota. A Senate quota was exceeded by informals in New South Wales and Victoria. That is a real indictment of the system. One could validly ask who are the missing members of this place, as the composition of the Senate may have been different if the informal votes had been lower. Unfortunately, at Senate elections informal votes have become the third largest bloc of votes, after the Australian Labor Party and the conservative coalition. In the electoral division of Lalor, the Senate informal vote was 16.3 per cent; in Reid it was 14.7 per cent; in Blaxland it was 14.2 per cent; and in Port Adelaide it was 14.1 per cent. Within that latter division there was a 27 per cent Senate informal vote at two polling booths. Informals exceeded one in five at other South Australian booths. These shocking findings should not be tolerated in a democracy.

Few informal votes are deliberate, as some commentators would suggest. A close investigation of informal voting in the Adelaide metropolitan area has revealed that it is linked with certain population characteristics. In suburbs where there are many senior citizens, recent migrants from certain countries, or citizens with relatively little schooling, high levels of informal votes can unfortunately be expected with the present voting system. It is appalling that these groups, which are among the most heavily reliant upon the Commonwealth Government for their well-being, through the social security system, are those least able to express their choice because the voting system defeats them. The very people who most need a strong voice at the ballot box are effectively denied a vote by the unnecessarily complex voting system. Possibly, this is one reason why our social security system has fallen behind. The estimated number of two million Australians living in poverty would have been lower with the implementation of more compassionate policies. The thrust of policies might have been different if fewer of the poor were prevented from having a say in who is elected to parliament. The public finance theory assumes the ability to choose between public goods, yet we have a voting system which effectively denies choice to so many.

Another inequality in Australian public life has been the growing disparity between the expenditures of individual parties and groups at elections. It is possible that, per head of population, Australia's elections are now the most expensive in the world. The conservative parties have been relatively well financed and have tended to have a hold on the political system. Electoral success should not be allowed to depend on the amount of money available to fund campaigns. The importance of the establishment of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform cannot be overemphasised. To give early effect to the principle of one vote one value, I hope that the Committee will recommend the scrapping of the requirement that large electorates have a smaller enrolment. If we are to improve the general standing of parliament in the community, a priority must be the reform of the flow of money into politics, and its expenditure. I congratulate the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) on his announcement foreshadowing legislation in this area.

I hope we can have a package of reforms, including not only public funding of elections but also limits on expenditures, the disclosure of the sources of donations and limits to their size. To a varying degree, all such measures are the law in other democracies, particularly in countries such as the United States of America and Canada. Public funding of parties' research activities occurs in a range of countries too. Australia can only benefit if each political party researches policy in more depth. The massive amounts for funding political campaigns are used in the main to buy television and radio time or to finance the production of broadcast material. New policies should be focused on access to television and radio by political groups. Television and radio political commercials as we now know them should be replaced by allocations of time according to a strict and equitable formula. That is the system in some other countries, including Canada. Broadcast time could be allocated in, say, five minute segments, making it harder to sustain fear campaigns. In essence, the allocation of broadcast time on commercial stations in future would be an extension of the present Australian Broadcasting Commission practice. The funding of broadcast time should be the responsibility of the Commonwealth or the joint responsibility of the Government and the stations.

Surely, a basic objective of our electoral system should be to maximise the number of valid votes. The ability to allocate preferences should be a later consideration; that is, after the maximum number of electors have been able to cast a valid vote. The scale of informal voting in Senate elections can be reduced. After all, the majority of informals are cast by electors who cast valid votes in House of Representatives elections. A move to optional preferential voting in the Senate, by simplifying the voting system would reduce the number of informals. To maximise the number of valid votes electors should have only to express a few preferences. The system which has the greatest potential to maximise the number of valid votes is the European list system of voting which operated in South Australia up to 1979 for upper House elections. Under that system, an elector simply had to place the number '1' against a party list to cast a valid vote. In 1979, that reduced informal votes to 4.4 per cent- a smaller percentage than in the lower House elections. That was a remarkable electoral achievement in this country.

Arguments against the list system of voting are weakened by the fact that few electors depart from suggested rankings of candidates on how-to-vote cards under the present system. Research has shown that only 2 per cent or 3 per cent of all voters in mainland States-including Labor, Liberal and Democrats-depart from the order of how-to-vote cards. So while 2 per cent to 3 per cent pick and choose candidates, informal votes by others are forced possibly 5 per cent to 6 per cent higher.

Voter education schemes will help reduce informal voting too. The Australian Labor Party has shown what can be done. In my State, after voter education activities, Senate informals fell by 11,000 in 1980. But it should be the Government's responsibility to carry out voter education rather than that of individual political parties. Voting should be simplified by the identification of parties against candidates' names on ballot papers. This would reduce voter confusion resulting from the growing length of ballot papers. How-to-vote cards should be placed in voting cubicles as in South Australian State elections.

I hope that the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform will be able to examine computerised voting in depth. Modern equipment, including optical scanners, could handle preferential voting with ease. Such equipment now is in widespread use in parts of the United States. The adoption of computerised voting would result in a major simplification of the Australian voting system. In establishing the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, Parliament is taking a major step to foster the further development of our democracy. It is to be hoped that the Committee's recommendations can be supported and given effect at an early date. Democracy needs constant nurturing if it is to survive. A complete overhaul of our electoral system is indeed timely. It offers real hope for increasing participation in our political process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling on Senator Zakharov I draw the attention of all honourable senators to the fact that this will be the first speech made in the Senate by Senator Zakharov. I ask all honourable senators to accord her the normal courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would like, firstly, to congratulate you on your election to the presidency and hope that you will have security of tenure in that office. I have been elected to the Senate at a time when the irrationalities of capitalism have inflicted increasing suffering and humiliation on very large numbers of our fellow Australians and most particularly on the weakest-workers unprotected by trade unions, the aged, the disabled, children and adolescents and all those dependent on social security payments. The level of distress has reached the point where an institution unknown since the Great Depression of the 1930s-the soup kitchen-was re- established in Melbourne and Sydney. The election of the Australian Labor Government has brought the promise of relief for those in greatest need and hope for a better future for all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to thank the people of Victoria who elected five Australian Labor Party candidates to the Senate, particularly my supporters from inside and outside the party, my friends and, above all, my children who helped me in so many ways not just during the campaign but over the years before when they understood that my commitment was not just to them but to others in need, at the personal level in my job as a student counsellor and at a mass level in campaigns in many of which , such as the moratoria, they have joined with me. I am very proud that my three children, now adult, are all committed socialists.

People have asked me why I left my run for parliament so late in life. After the record breaking run recently of my fellow Victorian Cliff Young I would say that late runs can be very successful. But seriously, the question points to a lack of understanding about a woman, or any sole parent, who has children to support. When one is working to support three children and then going home not only to do the domestic jobs-even though the children might share in those jobs- but also to attend to home maintenance and family transport, it leaves little time, and even less money, to become a candidate.

My commitment to social justice, focused now in my commitment to the Australian Labor Party, goes back as far as I can remember. My childhood was spent during the Depression of the 1930s and my father, who was a teacher, spent most of those years out of work, his only income being for piece-rate journalism at tuppence a published line. Some of my most vivid early memories are of men coming to the door to ask for money or food and men in the streets picking up butts, providing second hand tobacco for a cigarette. These memories and talk at home about the rise of facism in Italy and Germany and the Spanish Civil War helped shape my commitment to peace and social justice which has finally brought me to this chamber.

During the early 1950s I worked at a variety of occupations which strengthened my understanding of what it is to be exploited-doubly so if one is female. I returned to study part time as a mother of three young children. Honourable senators may remember that it was a Labor Government which abolished university fees in the 1970s. In the early 1960s I worked at weekends to pay for my studies and care for my family at the same time. When I returned to the work force in 1966 I studied after work to complete my qualifications as a teacher and a psychologist. These experiences have contributed to my support for my party's policies which will help to alleviate educational inequalities in this society.

I am pleased that one of our earliest actions was to abolish the iniquitous student loan scheme and increase Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowances . As a teacher and a student counsellor I have spent the last 16 years in close contact with adolescents and their parents and have seen, over the last seven years, the disastrous effect of the previous Government's policies on the lives of young people. The Opposition and the right wing groups which support it propagandise about support for the family. I have seen, at first hand, the effect on the family of the stresses caused by unemployment and poverty. The economic policies announced by the Governor-General will help the family as well as the individual wage earner or social service beneficiary.

It was with great regret that I left my work as a school counsellor at Montmorency High School. I thank the members of that school community, past and present, for the contribution they have made in experience and support to my professional and political development. Working with my teaching colleagues, with parents and with students in the classroom and in a counselling relationship, has developed my insight and understanding of other people's needs and aspirations and developed skills in facilitating communication and decision making which I am sure will be valuable in my parliamentary work.

To paraphrase the words of the new Australian Ambassador to the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation, there are two specific things I maintain my rage about: One is the events of 11 November 1975; the other is the day that Malcolm Fraser first used the term 'dole bludger'. It is years ago now but the stigma, and even the label, still sticks. Young people in their last year at school say they are not going to apply for benefits because they do not want to be called a 'dole bludger'. Of course that clever piece of immoral rhetoric has had its effects in maintaining the myth amazingly held by many people in spite of all the contrary evidence that the unemployed are to blame if they have not got a job. This is reflected in the self-image of many unemployed, particularly the young whose parents believe they cannot be trying if they cannot find work, but also the older worker who is retrenched. I know one family where the father kept up a facade of freelance work at home for some months until his savings ran out.

The social cost of unemployment is high as well as the economic cost. We need too to take a much closer look at the hidden unemployed who, according to some estimates, equal in number the known unemployed. I refer to those who have given up the search in despair, the students staying unwillingly at school, the spouses of people in employment and those who do not know they are eligible for benefits. The steps the Government is taking in job creation and other areas of the economy will have a multiplier effect socially as well as economically. One person's unhappiness affects family and friends as well. I believe the measures outlined in the Goverment's economic statement last week will help to redistribute the burden of the recession and restore a measure of hope to Australians who are living in poverty. We bear a heavy responsibility to ensure that, in spite of the enormous deficit bequeathed by the previous Government, we take every possible step to reverse the downward economic trend in a responsible and equitable way. A prices and incomes policy can work. If a country like Austria can use a prices and incomes policy to keep both inflation and unemployment below 5 per cent, while maintaining real wages, surely a country as rich in resources as Australia can do as well.

I have been an active unionist in the various jobs I have held in the past and proudly retain my membership of the Victorian Secondary Teachers Association. A look at the published occupations of those on the benches opposite reveals very few who would have that background, which perhaps excuses them in part for their lack of understanding of what unions are about. Of course, it is not the only area in which impoverished experience is shown by many of the Opposition. When one has been a process worker, a waitress, or a mail sorter as I have, one understands very well, for example, that, when prices of necessities continue to rise, a wage freeze is a wage cut and that, when one is poor, being asked to take a cut in real wages means something very different from a doctor or a lawyer forgoing a rise in fees or a company director an increase in remuneration . From my own experience and that of my former clients, I know what it is like to be poor and powerless. I am well aware that many in our community have been brought to the depths of poverty by the callous policies of the previous Government. I am resolved to keep close contact with the disadvantaged in my own State. I have chosen to set up my electoral office in a regional shopping centre well served by public transport. I hope to act as both a resource and an advocate for those in need, particularly for a very large group in the community which remains relatively disadvantaged in spite of major gains in recent years. I refer to women.

During the election campaign, I was impressed by the number of women who, even in that very short period, contacted me to find out my position on issues such as discrimination and sexual harassment or to voice concerns which they felt unable to raise with a male. Of course, women, whose unpaid domestic labour underwrites the whole economy, are also being especially hard hit in the Australian labour market. The second addendum to the information paper on the economy, prepared for the recent National Economic Summit Conference, shows that in every age group a larger percentage of the female labour force is unemployed than is the case for the male labour force. Teenage girls suffer an unemployment rate that is currently higher than for every other age and sex group for which the Bureau of Statistics collects information.

Long standing and deeply embedded discriminatory practices at all levels of Australian society are responsible for the weak employment position of Australian women and for their lack of political and economic power. Yet there are groups in the community who apparently wish to perpetuate such powerlessness with its accompanying daily indignities and frustrations. These groups are petitioning the Government not to ratify the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women. Contrary to claims made in this place a short time ago, the majority of those who have actually read the Convention would, I am sure, support it. I intend to deal more fully with this matter in the near future.

It seems to me to be beyond the powers of understanding of such forces of reaction in this country that there might be a connection between teenage unemployment and the epidemic of teenage prostiution in the capital cities, for example. Sexual harassment continues to be one of the worst practices restricting womens ability to find and keep jobs they want. The Working Women's Centre in Victoria and the various State equal opportunity commissions continue to report a constant stream of complaints from women workers concerning sexual harassment. The South Australian equal opportunity commissioner has detailed how the frequency of this form of women's oppression increases as unemployment increases, and women fear to lose their jobs if they complain. I am pleased that the Government's sex discrimination Bill, foreshadowed in our election policy, is to be introduced during this session. I commend Senator Ryan, on whose private member's Bill it is based, for her perseverance in working for equal rights for the sexes. I emphasise that this Bill will redress discrimination against men as well as women. It will be welcomed by those who suffer discrimination. I hope that this Bill will be followed by further legislation implementing affirmative action and the prohibition of discrimination on any grounds at all, such as religious belief or lack of belief, or sexual preference . Likewise, I look forward to the early implementation of the Women's Emergency Services Program by the Federal Government which will include heavily increased funding for women's refuges and crisis centres.
The great English socialist, R. H. Tawney, said:
Freedom, to be complete, must carry with it not merely the absence of repression, but also the opportunity of self-organisation.

The programs I have referred to and which the Australian Labor Party is committed to implementing will help my fellow Australians to achieve that goal of self-organisation which must be the basis of a democratic society. Democracy means a great deal more than the right to vote. It means the right to participate in decision making, the right to information, the right to have control over one's own life. Our political opponents always imply that government action is at best a necessary evil. Government action can increase people's freedom by ensuring that all Australians can share in the democratic process in its wider sense.

All of the policies announced by the Governor-General are, of course, irrelevant if we do not succeed in preventing nuclear war. I am proud that my own State of Victoria will shortly be declared a nuclear free State. I remind the Liberal senators that their party supported that Bill in the Victorian Upper House. I hope they will do likewise when the Government carries out its policy of calling for a nuclear free Pacific. It was a great day two months ago when we marched through Melbourne led by the Premier of Victoria, the Lord Mayor and the Anglican Archbishop of Melbourne at the head of the biggest and most broadly- based march since the moratoria during the Vietnam war.

In my adolescence I devoured Shakespeare's tragedies, something which my colleague Senator Colston would probably find significant. I took to myself a quotation from Hamlet which epitomises my personal philosophy:
This above all: to thine own self be true, And it must follow, as the night the day, Thou canst not then be false to any man.

I add: 'Woman'. In conclusion, I state unequivocally that I am a socialist, a unionist and a feminist and that I intend to spend my term in office in the service of the people of Victoria, working towards a society where every individual can live with dignity and security.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition (6.32)

TALK.START.PARA: —I might just briefly detain the Senate. I know it was the intention to suspend the sitting now. As we are observing all of the courtesies, I congratulate those who made their maiden speeches in this place. But I rise merely because Senator Zakharov, in the course of her maiden speech, made an accusation about the previous Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, using the expression 'dole bludger'. It is not the practice in this place to respond to maiden speeches or to make points, but that statement is offensive to the Opposition. I have certainly never heard the former Prime Minister use that expression or, indeed, any other Minister in the previous Goverment use it. I also say that I have never seen any evidence that the previous Prime Minister used that expression. I invite Senator Zakharov, if she has some proof of what I deny, to put it before us. The fact of unemployment is a matter of distress to all honourable senators in this place, not merely to honourable senators from the Government. I do not believe that the debate in this place is advanced-
—Mr President, I take a point of order. Is the Leader of the Opposition seeking leave to speak on this subject?
—Order! There is no point of order. The Leader of the Opposition has not yet spoken in this debate.

—I am quite happy to go on speaking, too, if that is the wish of the Senate. The short point I wish to make is that there was an imputation against the former Prime Minister which, since he is absent from this place, I reject on his behalf. I am sorry that it was part of a maiden speech. I believe it was quite inappropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not spoken either in this debate but I would like to add my contribution by saying that many things were said by maiden speakers on the other side of the chamber but I would not be so base as to criticise them. I consider that my contribution.

That the words proposed to be added (Senator Peter Rae's amendment) be added.

That the Address-in-Reply be presented to His Excellency the Governor-General by the President and such senators as may desire to accompany him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will inform honourable senators when I have ascertained the date on which His Excellency the Governor-General will be pleased to receive the Address-in-Reply to his opening Speech and I will extend an invitation to all honourable senators to accompany me on the occasion of its presentation.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 May, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Peter Baume had moved by way of amendment:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill should not be proceeded with until-
(a) the legal action against the Australian Broadcasting Commission instituted by the Premier of New South Wales is concluded; and
(b) an assurance is given by the Government:
(i) that no action will be taken to alter the existing membership of the Commission until the Bill is again before the Parliament at the conclusion of those legal proceedings, and
(ii) that there will be no Government interference with the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission in its programming policy'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was cut off in my prime when the debate was interrupted so that the adjournment motion could be put.
—You are kidding yourself.
—I had better start again; I am reduced to incompetence by Senator Walters' interjection.
—You may have been in your prime, but it still was not much good.

—I will endeavour to improve on my speech now by referring further to my notes. I was making the point, when I concluded yesterday, about the technical problems that the Australian Broadcasting Commission experienced during the period of the previous Government. I want to make some points about organisational problems that afflict the ABC, particularly the problem of the ratio between people in administrative and clerical positions and those in the creative and talented area of production, programming and monitoring. It seems to me that the ABC is top heavy in administration; it has too many administrative and clerical positions. There is not enough emphasis on the creative side.

SPEECH.PARA: A week or so ago, speaking to a matter of public importance, I dealt at great length with the financial problems with which the ABC was afflicted under the previous Government. This coincided with the period when the ABC was under Sir Henry Bland. At constant prices the allocation to the ABC for operating capital fell from $110m in 1974-75 to $98m in 1976-77. In the following years it fell further to $95m, to $93m, to $91m. In 1980-81 it was $95m. This indicates a deliberate program of starving the ABC of funds, thus stifling it with resultant staff ceilings and all sorts of other ongoing administrative problems and rendering it a somewhat exhausted auntie. The morale of the ABC staff has dropped. This has coincided with the drop in ratings and the quality of programs presented by the Commission. The Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, when it analysed the history of the ABC, made a valuable contribution to community debate. In fact it put its finger on a number of major problems.

What the Government wants to achieve with these Bills is a bipartisan understanding of the role of the ABC-a bipartisan settlement of issues as to how we as a Parliament, not divided by parties but as a Parliament of all parties, see the direction and future development of the ABC. It is to that end that the Bills have been brought forward and remain largely unamended in the sense that they reflect earlier legislation brought on by the previous Government. We have amended these Bills only to improve them in certain areas that are consistent with our policy. The Bills take the ABC out of the Broadcasting and Television Act and at long last give it its own Act, its own identity. The Bills give the Commission a charter to inform, to entertain and to reflect the cultural diversity of Australia. We believe that it provides a balance between the need to provide broad appeal in broadcasting and the need to cater for specialist interests. It is sensitive to the needs of the ABC as an international broadcaster, an educator and an organisation that reflects the cultural diversity of Australia by holding up a mirror to the Australian community.

The legislation establishes State and Territory advisory councils to assist the ABC in fulfilling its role. It enables the ABC to maintain its identity as an independent source of news in the community. Yesterday I made some remarks about the importance of a truly independent news source in an information system dominated by privately owned news media-and conservative news media at that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shouldn't we be eclectic?

—We should be eclectic. But of course the ABC provides the extra dimension of independence so that we are not swamped and stifled in public and community debate by a dominant media of conservative taste and attitude. The legislation provides a mechanism for complaints to be dealt with by the creation of community affairs officers. I believe that that is an important area of change. Certainly it is an improvement on what the previous Government envisaged . The legislation also provides for the ABC to be taken out of the control of the Public Service Board and put in charge of its own industrial affairs. In fact, many of the problems besetting the Commission at present are typical of an organisation that really needs a rebirth. That is what this legislation tries to do. It is the view of the Government that the ABC must be a truly comprehensive organisation. It must serve specialised interests at a high standard, and compete for audiences in mass entertainment of the highest quality. It should present quality programming with good production value in a contemporary way. That is the objective of the Government and that is the purpose of the Bills. I commend them to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHIPP
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats welcome the introduction of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill 1983 and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1983 which are designed to rejuvenate and restructure the Australian Broadcasting Commission. In doing so we commend this Government for the speed with which it has brought in this legislation. However, it would not be fair if, in debating these Bills, we did not also give a warm commendation to the previous Government for the massive amount of work it did in the process of restructuring the ABC, starting with former Minister Staley, Minister Sinclair and finally Minister Neil Brown. These Ministers did an enormous amount of work in getting this legislation essentially in the form in which it now is, with certain important alterations with which the Democrats concur.

SPEECH.PARA: We have strongly and consistently promoted the need for real independence for the ABC. That sounds like someone saying: 'We hate sin and we love motherhood', or even vice versa if that is one's persuasion. What do the words 'independence of the ABC' mean? How important is such independence? Why is it important? I will briefly restate the reasons I gave a week or two ago during the debate on a matter of public importance in this chamber. At present Australia has disturbingly few owners of the media, both electronic and print. By naming Packer, Murdoch, the Melbourne Herald, the Melbourne Age and Fairfax I believe that I have named five groups that essentially control the private media in Australia. I repeat that I believe that in general terms those five groups have served Australia well. Although they have been partisan at times in their editorial comments-I believe that it is the inalienable right of a private organisation to be bipartisan in its editorial column-in my view, in general terms they have been meticulously fair in publishing, printing and broadcasting news items. While that situation exists one could say that democracy or free speech in this country is safe. But what a fine line between the ownership of the media by five groups and ownership contracting to four groups, three groups, two groups and eventually one group. If one group had ownership of the private media in Australia I believe that democracy would be in peril.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be the same with public ownership if it were just one group; just one group would be the problem.

—I acknowledge Senator Peter Baume's interjection. He is correct. Public ownership of the media could also produce bias and unfairness in editorial policy. Therefore, the Democrats strongly support the competition between the public media-namely, the ABC-and the private media. The prospect of the terrible day when Australia has undue concentration of ownership of the private media throws into relief the vital necessity of having an independent ABC. How do we get an independent ABC? I believe that we could go through the motions of hoping that the director, the producer and even the cameraman in a television crew will be independent and fair in the production of a program. Essentially, all those people will have, and I believe should have, some form of internal bias themselves. They would be neuter people and, therefore, unsuitable for bringing provocative and informative news to Australians unless they had a point of view. I believe that the independence and objectivity of the ABC must lie essentially in the Commissioners, as the legislation is now constituted, or with the new Board of Directors, whose responsibility it will be to ensure objectivity, fairness, accuracy and independence.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats' view, which we put forward to this Government and the previous Government-it was rejected by both-was that appointments to the Board should ultimately be subject to the approval of both Houses of Parliament. We believe that once a little clique or elite, similar to a Cabinet, has the final right to say who will be Commissioners, the way is open for political patronage, political bias and a lack of political objectivity. Objectivity will be achieved only when the appointees are approved by the democratically elected members of parliament. We have not succeeded this time, but we serve notice that we will continue to press for that position in the future.

However, I strongly commend this Labor Government and, in particular, the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) and the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, for the way in which they have been receptive to Democrat initiatives in this regard. In particular, I commend those two gentlemen and the Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, for agreeing to our request that all parties should establish a committee comprising six members to recommend and forward to the Government the names of those people who are to be appointed to the Board. Those six people comprise three members of the Government, including the Minister for Communications as chairman; two from the Liberal-National Party coalition; and one Australian Democrat. A variety of names will be put forward by that sort of panel. I hope that the people on that panel will not put forward names simply to represent their points of view. It would be a tragedy if the Australian Labor Party put forward the names of two rampant left wing socialists . Equally, it would be a tragedy if the Liberal-National Party coalition put forward two right wing troglodytes, and the Democrats put forward someone to try to compensate for the other four.

TALK.START.PARA: —A Franklin rafter who breaks his arms.

—I would have thought such a person would be an ideal choice. However, we thank the Government and applaud it for its far-sightedness in trying to achieve true objectivity and independence in the Board, where fairness must finally be enshrined. We would also like to see the idea of the committee enshrined in legislation. For some quaint reason, the Government has not done so . I ask the Minister whether he would be good enough, when he responds to all speakers who contribute to the second reading debate, to put on the record why the Government has not put a provision in the legislation to cover the appointment of this comittee, which will forward names for the board of Directors. If this provision is not contained in the Act, there will be no obligation on any future government-particularly a future government of a different political persuasion from this Government-not to return to the bad old days of appointing its boys to the jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: The all party committee that the Government will establish should ensure the appointment of the best non-executive directors. We note that the Bill does not contain formal provision for a staff elected director, although I understand from Senator Button that there will be a staff elected director. Again, I commend the Government for that concept. We remember that that concept was introduced by the Whitlam Government, removed by the Fraser Government and now it is reintroduced by the Hawke Government. But why has that provision not been put in the Bill? I would have thought that it provided an obvious protection which the Government should have sought. I ask the Minister in his response to place on the record why that provision has not been inserted in this Bill. This legislation for the first time gives the Corporation a charter. We believe that the inclusion of a recognition of the multicultural character of Australian society is essential and, again, to be commended. However, we serve notice that we would not support any moves which might affect the Special Broadcasting Service and its Channel O/28, merely because the ABC is finally moving towards multicultural activities.

The establishment in clause 11 of this Bill of an advisory council and similar organisations in the States, Territories or regions, should provide some worthwhile community based advice to the Commission on programming. Again, this is a very constructive move which the Democrats applaud. In amendments which I now foreshadow the Democrats will move for the advisory council to recommend to the managing director those who should be appointed as community affairs officers-virtually, complaints officers. We believe that the present provision in the Bill, whereby the managing director has total responsibility for appointing those community affairs officers, would lead to too much power being centralised in the hands of the managing Director and the Corporation; therefore , we believe that that power should be reduced by names being provided by advisory councils. Independence is essential for a complaints procedure to be effective. I am happy to say that, following discussions with the Minister, the Government will accept the Democrats' amendment to this provision. Although the amendment varies from our proposed amendments in 1982, we believe that it is a suitable compromise, given the competing requirements for independence and the urgency of this Bill.

At this stage I state that the Democrats would have liked to seek the approval of the Senate for a number of other amendments. However, we realised that that would have meant sending this Bill back to the House of Representatives and would have put in jeopardy the chances of having the Bill passed this week when the House of Representatives rises. For the reasons I illustrated last week in my question to the Minister, I believe the early establishment of the Corporation and the appointment of the Directors are vital. I understand that that view is also accepted by the Opposition in this place. It is good to participate in such a history making exercise in which there is a feeling of goodwill and co-operation between the parties represented in this chamber.

However, two provisions of the Government's Bill in relation to the complaints procedure concern us greatly. There is no provision for complaints based on fairness. A complaint can be lodged only if the matter is allegedly untrue, inaccurate or an invasion of privacy. That is fair enough. We concede the enormous difficulty of defining unfairness and bias. I suppose that a program such as Four Corners, This Day Tonight or Insight would not be worth listening to or viewing unless they had some sort of bias or bite. I can imagine the impossible procedures that would be generated if we allowed for bias. But I wonder whether the question of unfairness should not be looked at in the future. I am happy to say that the Government has given me a guarantee that the question of inserting an unfairness provision will be looked at during the inquiry into a fairness code by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I will set up a hypothetical sitution. Let us assume that we have, by accident or design, an extremely right wing or left wing-it does not matter--

TALK.START.PARA: —It does.

—I know where the preferences of the honourable senator from Western Australia would lie. But I seek his agreement that one would be as bad as the other. Let us assume that that ultra right or left wing board of directors had its prejudices filtered down to executive appointments-right down to the lowest level. Let us assume that finally all the people on, say, the Four Corners crew-the producer, director and cameramen; the whole group-were of that twisted right or left wing persuasion. Let us assume that we had a series of broadcasts on the Four Corners program and that every two or three weeks comments were clearly and insidiously inserted that were anti-Semitic, anti- Jewish, anti-Catholic, anti-freemason, anti-women, anti-homosexual or whatever. A very gentle inculcation of prejudice and unfairness could be manifest. Under the present legislation there is no provision to complain about that. We will not press that point because we realise the enormous difficulties involved.

SPEECH.PARA: The second reason we have reservations is that a person must have 'a sufficient interest' in a program before the complaint he lodges needs to be investigated. A young man who works with me is passionate about preserving our rainforests. Let us assume that the ABC puts on a program that is wrong in fact about rainforests. Under this legislation, as I understand it, the community affairs officer need not investigate a complaint lodged by this young man because that community affairs officer might well deem that the young man does not have 'a sufficient interest' in the matter. I think lawyers call this situation locus standi.

Again I realise that if we open this area too wide the complaints procedure of the ABC would be overwhelmed. I am amused and not surprised to hear from officers of the ABC the number of complaints received by the ABC after every current affairs program is broadcast. The complaints number tens of thousands over a year and many of them are frivolous or vexatious. We would thoroughly agree that the work of the complaints officers should not be bogged down unnecessarily. This is a vexed question and, again, to ensure the speedy passage of the Bill we have accepted the Government's concrete assurance that when the report by community affairs officers is made to parliament this provision will be reviewed, and that will be in August 1984.

This Bill closes a major deficiency in the 1982 legislation prohibiting beyond any doubt the possibility of advertising or other gratuities which would undermine the independence of the Commission. We applaud the Government for that . The Minister stated in his second reading speech that the Government was committed to maintaining the ABC's independent news service. To the Democrats this is the most important function of the ABC. However, because the Democrats believe there is some doubt in the character of the ABC and in clause 27 of the Bill that the independence of the ABC news service will be maintained, we propose to move an amendment as a preamble.

As honourable senators know, the Bill allows the ABC to harvest news by agencies such as Australian Associated Press. With this we approve, but there is a danger that the services of agencies could be increased while the services of locally employed ABC personnel could be diminished. Again, I am grateful that the Government has agreed to accept that amendment to ensure that the Corporation shall develop and maintain an independent service for the broadcasting and televising of news and information by the Corporation. I commend the Government for its open-mindedness in receiving such an amendment.

The current Bill deletes the no work as directed, no pay provision of the previous Government's Bill. We support this deletion and regret that we cannot support the Opposition's amendment which would reinstate the relevant clauses. Our view is that it is a provocative industrial relations measure that should not be part of ABC legislation. Statements that such a clause is needed for management authority are, in our view, spurious as there are more than adequate measures available to governments in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act as well as various Public Service Acts. Indeed, in the Bill there is provision for the dismissal of people who will not obey orders.

One of the most disturbing features of the Bill which was in the previous Government's legislation also is that clause 78 gives the Minister a binding power. I invite listeners to take note of this clause because I am sure that if we took a poll of honourable senators in this place we would find that most of them would not even know that this offending clause is in the Bill. If, in the Minister's opinion, some material is not in the public interest this Bill gives the Minister the power to direct the Corporation not to broadcast that material.

TALK.START.PARA: —What clause is that?

—Clause 78. I believe that is a monstrous provision. That is nothing more than an opportunity for blatant censorship by a Minister. I understand that such a provision has been used only twice before in the country. I think it was used in 1944 to prevent the broadcast of starting price betting results and in the 1950s by I think-I hope I am not doing him an injustice-the Honourable Alan Hulme when he banned a program which illustrated in some graphic detail the slaughter of blacks by South Africans. I think they are the only two occasions in the last 30 or 40 years when this power has been used. I am very worried about residual power and about the argument which says: 'It has never been used'.
—Don't they have to report to parliament if they do it?
—Yes.
—That is a protection.
—I do not think they would need to report to parliament.
—Nevertheless they do, don't they?
—If a Minister banned a broadcast--
—The Minister would report afterwards.

—Yes, after the event. If a Minister banned a broadcast I think that would be page one news throughout the country two minutes after that was known. We would not have to wait for a formal report to parliament. But that is not the point. I think the principle is worth looking at. Again, in discussions with the Government we were met with total reasonablness by the Minister. He said he was concerned about the matter, but he pointed out-a bit to my embarrassment-that there was an identical section in the Broadcasting and Television Act which had also gone unnoticed for many years. The Minister has given an undertaking that the Government would be receptive to receiving amendments to delete that clause from both the Broadcasting and Television Act and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act in August. With those remarks I commend the previous Government for its foresight in initiating these reforms and this rejuvenation. I warmly commend the present Government for implementing these provisions through this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My comments will be of a general nature and, with the indulgence of the Senate, of a slightly parochial nature.
—There would be nothing new about that, would there, Senator?

—I thank the honourable senator. I am flattered that he notices what I say from time to time. I will be as brief as I can. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill and the accompanying Australian Broadcasting Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill are, in many respects, the same as the legislation introduced by the previous Government. This legislation arises out of the previous Government's initiative in appointing the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the Government's subsequent response which passed through the House of Representatives last year and was introduced into the Senate on, I think, the last day of the last session of last year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill establishes the national broadcasting network as a corporation operating under its own charter and separate from the legislation which regulates commercial and public broadcasting in Australia. It provides for the establishment of a board of directors which will include a managing director who will have full voting rights and who will be appointed by the board for renewable periods of five years. The Bill also provides for advisory councils to be set up in each State, Territory or region of Australia to advise the board either by way of its own initiative or by way of request of the board. The underlying principle behind the original legislation, which has been carried into the present Bill, was clearly to make the new Australian Broadcasting Corporation more responsive to the community and to the changes occuring within it. The previous Government responded to the comment in the Dix report that the ABC in its present form:

. . . has not only slipped from the forefront of change, but threatens to be eclipsed by it. The ABC has become slow-moving, overgrown, complacent and uncertain of the direction in which it is heading, despite the efforts of many dedicated and talented people who work for it.

The changes outlined in this legislation will at least provide the necessary framework whereby the new Corporation can address itself to these criticisms and can perhaps wrest back from the commercial networks some of the initiatives which have been lost to it in recent years. Under its charter, the new Corporation is charged:
To provide within Australia innovative and comprehensive broadcasting and television services of a high standard . . .
Further, in clause 6 of the legislation the ABC is set up to:
. . . contribute to a sense of national identity and inform and entertain, and reflect the cultural diversity of, the Australian community;
Amongst others, these were high ideals which the previous Government set for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and which have been carried over into the present legislation.

I note that the new Government has added an additional matter in the charter of the Corporation, namely, that the Corporation shall also take account of 'the multicultural character of the Australian community'. That matter is currently charged to the Special Broadcasting Service and the 0/28 television network. The implication of the addition of this new clause is that the Labor Government may in the long term be planning to incorporate ethnic broadcasting services within the framework of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Notwithstanding that it would represent yet another broken promise by the Government which made a firm commitment to the ethnic communities, it would also divert the new Corporation from its fundamental objective, namely, to respond in a positive way to the challenges outlined in the Dix report. I trust that is not the Government 's objective in adding that clause.

Nevertheless, in most respects this legislation has my support, subject to some significant exceptions to which I will refer a little later. It sets up the framework through which the high ideals of the Corporation's charter can be achieved. There are several areas to which the new board of directors of the Corporation might profitably turn its attention-indeed, to which its attention might well be drawn by the new advisory body foreshadowed in the Bill. I am referring here specifically to country areas where frequently people do not have a choice between the ABC and commercial services, especially in terms of television. The new Corporation has an obligation to do its utmost to service these people. It will have the power to attend to one of the matters which was originally raised by the previous Government in its initial response to the Dix report, namely, the rationalisation of the regional break-up of the ABC's transmission areas.

At the moment in the northern part of Western Australia, that is to say, the Pilbara and Kimberley regions, the ABC runs one service. I accept that these areas are relatively sparsely populated and that the ABC operates under some financial strictures. Nevertheless, there is a strong case to be argued that, as the main electronic media service covering both radio and television, the ABC should recognise the fact that the Pilbara and the Kimberleys are separate regions largely based on different industries, and, therefore, interested quite often in different issues. At present the regional news service emanates from Port Hedland which even by air is 800 kilometres from Wyndham. The ABC's news service in the region is compiled by Pilbara-based journalists who-and this is not intended in any way to be a reflection upon their professional competence- naturally gravitate towards issues which are of primary interest to the people of the Pilbara. Iron ore mines, in many senses the lifeblood of the Pilbara, do not exist further north in the mainly pastoral Kimberleys region. Agricultural issues generated by the ongoing success of the Ord River region have little relevance in the Pilbara. As I said, there is a strong case for establishing a regional office in Wyndham or elsewhere in the Kimberleys if technical considerations so dictate, not only to tap this source of history but also to give the people of that region a service which caters more directly for their needs than has previously been possible.

Another matter of interest to country people about which the Dix report made some constructive comments is sports broadcasting. This is a very difficult area for the ABC which, by covering sport to the extent it does, can leave itself open to criticism that it carries either too much or too little sport. I accept that there is a dilemma. It is really no more than a reflection of the diverse audience that the ABC serves, especially where no other network is available. In the first instance, it is important that the ABC is able to strike a balance in its sporting programs and, to do that, it will require, of course, extensive audience research. Arising out of that, the Board will have to ensure that the Corporation covers sporting events which have the widest possible community appeal. In Western Australia-I imagine it is the case in other States as well- the ABC carries a direct broadcast of the league football match of the day throughout the country network, and last year the ABC also--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there rugby in Western Australia?

—Rugby in Western Australia hardly rates as one of the more significant sports, though it is not without some material consequence. Last year the ABC telecast the World Cup soccer finals in Spain which, despite the fact that they were broadcast very early in the morning, were very popular. It is imperative, in my view, that the ABC ensures that it retains a role in such major sporting events. I acknowledge that there are, of course, difficulties in this regard. As the Dix Committee pointed out, because of the growing tendency towards corporate sponsorship of major sporting events and the sale of exclusive rights at prices which are very often beyond the capacity of the ABC to bid, the ABC may often find itself increasingly excluded from these areas. I find that most regrettable; yet I accept that, because of the large financial inputs which commercial networks and their sponsors make to sport, it would not be desirable to prevent such organisations obtaining exclusive broadcasting rights, certainly in the major metropolitan areas. Further, I do not believe it is proper that the ABC should concentrate only on minor sports because they are the only ones it is able to attract and pick up at an economic level.
