SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, I believe there is a solution which should prove acceptable to the commercial networks and which at the same time will serve to underline the great emphasis which, I trust, the new Board of the ABC will place on fulfilling community requirements and needs. Therefore, as part of the increased responsiveness to community requirements which the new Board will instil into the ABC, I urge the ABC not to look to the so-called less popular sports but to look to filling in the gaps in coverage which inevitably arise when commercial networks broadcast a major event. I suspect that that should not be too difficult to achieve since, by catering for areas not covered by the commercial networks, the ABC is not competing with a commercial network which has acquired sole rights. If, within the bounds of reasonable commercial terms, some financial consideration is involved to recompense the commercial network for its initial outlay, that should be considered in the interests of people in more isolated parts of the country. In other words, if the ABC is to look at what I might term community requirements, it should act accordingly.

I have addressed myself so far in this debate mainly to the question of the ABC in country areas, not because I believe the ABC has necessarily been inadequate in the past but because I believe the opportunity will present itself for it to improve further its services in these areas as time goes on. The Dix report made a range of recommendations with a view to improving the responsiveness of the ABC to audience needs. I believe the ABC will meet these challenges. As I said, I believe the Bill provides a framework to ensure that it does exactly that. However, there are in this Bill, where the new Government has changed elements of the previous Government's legislation, areas of concern with which regrettably I can find no satisfaction. I have already referred briefly to ethnic broadcasting, and I do not propose to canvass that again. However, when it is taken into consideration that the thrust of the Dix report and the thrust of the previous Government's Bill was to give the maximum possible independence to the ABC, it is important to note that in some ways that principle is already being eroded.

One important aspect of independence is the ability of the Board and the managing director to allocate resources in the most effective and efficient manner possible. Under the previous Government's legislation, the ABC would have been afforded that right by being allowed for the first time to use independent news agencies. That right has now been largely undermined. According to clause 27 of the Bill, the ABC may still:
. . . procure news and information relating to current events from such news agencies and other sources . . . as the Board thinks fit.

But that is now to be only under the limitation that an 'adequate number of persons, both within and without Australia' are employed by the ABC in news gathering. That does not give the Board, in my view, complete freedom in the commitment of resources, both financial and in terms of personnel. It will place more strictures on the Board in the news and current affairs area and will deny it the complete flexibility that it may have been assured under the previous Government's interpretation. By attempting to stipulate the levels of staffs to be maintained in this area-even as imprecisely as has been done in the wording of the Bill-the Government has taken away some of the flexibility in the new organisation. It may well have also provided incitement for future industrial unrest in the ABC over the unclear definition, as I have said, of an 'adequate number'. It is an unnecessary intrusion on the Government's part and it could well be interpreted in the light of recent events as an indication that the Government is not so committed to the independence of the national broadcaster as its statements in opposition might indicate. In that respect, the discussion since this Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives about the appointment of the Board leads me, frankly, to a similar conclusion.

I point out that the actual wording of the relevant clause of the Bill has not been altered from that which the previous Government introduced last year. How that clause is to be put into practice is important. In opposition, the Labor Party expressed fears that the Government could make appointments to the Board of persons sympathetic to it. It therefore opposed appointments to the Board by the Governor-General purely on the advice of the government of the day. Yet in government the Labor Party does not appear to have the same qualms about government-appointed Board members. As I understand it, the Government has now conceded that and is prepared to consult with the Opposition and the Australian Democrats on the appointments it makes. I commend the Government for that move under the circumstances. I understand that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is now suggesting that a committee be set up to make the appointments.

Notwithstanding that, I remain opposed to the concept of a parliamentary committee to appoint the Board because I believe that the bargaining and trading that will inevitably go on will result in a board that is less likely to be non- political than it was ever conceived to be. A situation could develop where in the horse trading of that committee one party conceded one position on the basis that one of its candidates would also subsequently be appointed. I believe it is better that the Government chooses its own servants, while accepting the advice or suggestions from the Opposition and other parties in the Parliament. In the final analysis it is the Government which is responsible for the actions of its servants. If it is seen to have chosen its servants badly, it will be brought to account by the people through the ballot box.

One other very disappointing aspect of the revised legislation is the deletion of Division 3 of the original Bill-the no work as directed, no pay provisions. Those provisions underlie what should be, in my view, a fundamental right of an employer in either private practice or the public sector-that where employees are not prepared to carry out the full responsibilities and duties of their position, they ought not at the same time receive the pay which that position carries with it. The provisions as they were included in the previous Government 's legislation were clear and non-discriminatory. Where an employee refused to carry out an instruction given by a person in authority to give such a direction , and where the direction would normally form part of the employee's duties, the provisions were, of course, to apply.

In the public sector where the duties attached to any position are detailed in written form, the guarantee against any form of discriminatory action is clear, and it gives the employee the assurance of knowing what his or her duties are. The employer has the right, in my view, to expect that once those duties are known and once they are acknowledged by the employee, they will be carried out for a remuneration that is also clearly defined. The relationship between the two is such that logically the withdrawal of the service or part of the service which would normally be rendered by the employee should not occur without a corresponding loss of pay. The Government has weakened the new Corporation's position as an employer and it has discarded one of the most effective deterrents against unnecessary industrial action that is available to it. I very much regret that the ALP for whatever reasons, has chosen that course of action.

However, the worst feature of the revised legislation is undoubtedly the complaints procedure. One of the most serious and recurring complaints which have come to my attention and presumably to that of most honourable senators is that when one makes a complaint to the ABC invariably one is appealing from Caesar unto Caesar-no action is taken and no redress is available. That is perfectly human and perfectly normal. One has learnt to live with it with the ABC. Furthermore, there is no independent authority to deal with the complaint or to which a complainant can appeal. In amendments which the previous Government was contemplating to its own Bill last year, and copies of which I understand have been circulated in the last few minutes, an independent complaints commission would have been established along the lines of a similar commission in Britain. It would have provided for a community affairs officer, who was an employee of the Corporation, and who would have acted as the first tier in the complaints structure. That officer would deal with complaints in the first instance. However, above the community affairs officer, it was planned to have a three to five-man commission independent of the ABC to which a complainant could appeal if he felt that his case had not been satisfactorily dealt with.

As with the British complaints commission on which the ABC complaints commission was modelled, would it report separately to the Parliament as a completely separate government instrumentality. It was a requirement that any person appointed not be a member of the ABC Board or an employee of the Corporation. On the other hand, the Labor Government, in its legislation has decided that community affairs officers directly employed by the ABC, reporting to the managing director of the ABC, will serve the same function. It has given these officers almost the same discretionary powers not to entertain a complaint -to make judgments about whether a complainant is vexatious, frivolous, not acting in good faith, or simply not sufficiently interested in the subject of the complaint-as did the independent commission which the previous Government proposed.

It is one thing for an independent commission to make such judgments, but it is quite another for an employee of the Commission to be placed in such a position. The complaints against the ABC are serious matters reflecting on the integrity, the impartiality and perhaps the competence or the incompetence of Australia's national broadcaster. The ABC, in order to preserve its reputation, at least deserves exoneration by an independent authority so there can be no doubt as to whether the complaint is justified. In order that a complainant is given a fair hearing, in my view, it is essential that he is given an independent hearing. The principle of appealing from Caesar unto Caesar, which the Government is applying in this case has no place in twentieth century Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very useful proposition.

—I know that it is a very enlightened observation from a conservative Liberal. I thought it might appeal to the Australian Labor Party's better sense of judgment. In every respect we now have an opportunity to create a new national broadcaster to meet the challenges of the future modelled, where appropriate, on the best examples that the world has to offer.

SPEECH.PARA: The British Complaints Commission is such a model. It is very unfortunate that this Government has failed to recognise that fact. For the most part, however, it does not alter the structure that would have been established by the previous Government's legislation, and the Government is to be commended for that and for recognising the valuable work and the reasoned conclusions to which the Dix Committee was able to come. I only trust that, having had the common sense to recognise the value and the virtue of the Dix Committee, the good sense which the previous Government had in seeking to implement those recommendations in the legislation, the Government will also accommodate appropriate, sensible and intelligent amendments which fulfil the ambitions of the great majority of the people and reflect more precisely and more accurately the recommendations and the wishes of the Dix Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was some 50 years ago last year that the Australian Broadcasting Commission was established under statute. That organisation has grown from a very small organisation to the massive organisation that it is today. I do not, of course, recall the establishment of the ABC; I was not born then. But I do recall living in the country and benefiting from the fact that the ABC was the only broadcasting station that we could hear with some degree of clarity and, more importantly, that it used to broadcast the England v. Australia test cricket matches-albeit there was some contrived situations in the studio to create atmosphere through some interesting sound effects.

SPEECH.PARA: Much has been said in this debate about the genesis of this legislation which proposes to change the Commission to a corporation and give it a revised structure and a revised charter. I do not intend in this debate to canvass those points that have been adequately made in the debate, but rather I shall focus on some of the inadequacies in the legislation. In saying 'inadequacies in the legislation', I am not so sure that the Senate has before it the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill that is proposed by the Government. We heard from the Australian Democrats that amendments to this Bill are to be submitted by the Government. Unless my eyesight is very gravely impaired, those amendments are not in front of me.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I refer to the problem in this legislation which was similar to the problem in the previous legislation; that is, the fact that this legislation, as was the case with its predecessor, does not facilitate the examination by an independent, authoritative body of complaints made by members of the public about program standards. That is a grave inadequacy. I believe that is a matter about which the listening public will be most concerned. Senator Chipp referred to that matter; he virtually agreed that that was an inadequacy, but he indicated that he would not go along with any amendments to the Bill because the Bill would have to go back to the House of Representatives, and the House of Representatives will rise this week. Well, so what? The House of Representatives will finish tomorrow night, as I understand it. The members might not get out of Canberra tomorrow night but will finish tomorrow night, and we are likely to conclude the third reading of this Bill tonight. There is plenty of time for the House of Representatives to consider any amendments that we may put forward.

My basic criticism of this legislation concerns something that most directly affects the ordinary person. Clause 82 of the Bill provides for the appointment of a Principal Community Affairs Officer and other complaints officers in each State and Territory. The first thing to be said about that clause is that those people are servants of the proposed Corporation. In other words, there will be an appeal from Caesar to Caesar. But in any event, these officers will be required to examine written complaints about errors of fact or invasions of privacy. Clause 82 (2) (b) states that they can decide:
. . . the complainant does not have a sufficient interest in the subject matter of the complaint.

They can ignore the complaint on that ground. Is that fair? Is that reasonable? We all know what sufficient interest is. I am very surprised that the Labor Government has imposed that sufficient interest hurdle before the complaint by an ordinary person can be heard by the complaints officer. The legal interpretation of 'sufficient interest' by and large depends on the hip pocket test; that is, whether it has affected someone in the hip pocket. To me that is not an adequate response to the very real need which is expressed quite frequently to all members of parliament by the ordinary citizen that he or she has the right to complain about broadcasting and television programs.

Clause 82 places one further unnecessary hurdle in front of the viewer; that is , that the complaint must be limited to errors of fact and invasions of privacy. My concern-I believe this concern is widespread in the community-based on a study of similar provisions in the United Kingdom legislation, is that these provisions will be interpreted to mean that the complaints officers are not obliged to consider complaints about program standards. I would like to know whether the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) agrees with me that that would be the interpretation. Certainly an examination of the United Kingdom report and a study of the United Kingdom legislation has led me to believe that, on the criteria in this Bill, complaints officers cannot receive complaints about program standards.

I will give honourable senators an example of something that actually occurred on ABC television in Tasmania last year. This is only one example. There are numerous similar examples. In the middle of the 7 p.m. television news, a scene was shown depicting vivid and graphic bloodshed in an overseas war. There was no warning. The item was shown whether or not one liked it, whether or not one's children were sitting in front of the television set. Let us apply the tests that are supposed to be applied under this legislation. Was that an error of fact? Well, who knows? Was it an invasion of privacy? Well, of course it was in the general sense, but not in the terms of the interpretation which I am sure will be given to this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—Senator Button says: 'That's right'. That is why the legislation needs to be rectified. Did the viewer who might complain about the absence of a warning have, in terms of the legislation, a sufficient interest in the subject matter? Under the terms of the legislation, again although that viewer may be the mother of the children sitting in front of that television set -let Government honourable senators and the Australian Democrats understand this -she would not have sufficient interest to sustain the complaint. Under this legislation it would be the requirement of the complaints officer to reject the complaint out of hand.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government quite rightly, along with a lot of other people over recent years, has demanded and has obtained easier access by members of the public to information. The freedom of information legislation attests to that fact. It has been claimed that the barriers preventing the public from making inquiries, not just about files relating to themselves personally but also about policy formulation and Executive decisions have been dismantled. In my veiw, and I believe it is a view that is widespread throughout the whole community, it is time that the barriers were broken down to ensure that complaints by viewers and listeners are effectively handled. All sorts of reasons have been advanced as to why this should not be done or cannot be done. Nobody says it should not be done . The Democrats said it should be done, but that we will wait till 1984, and late in 1984 at that, in the forlorn hope that when the report of the complaints commissioners come in the Government will introduce such provisions. We have no guarantee that the Government will introduce the provisions. If the Democrats are serious about wanting the public to have freedom of access and freedom of complaint and to have complaints properly dealt with, let them support my amendment, which is very simple.

At the Committee stage, I will be proposing an amendment to the Oppositions amendment but if the Opposition's amendment is defeated, I propose to move amendments to the Government's legislation in the Committee of the Whole. They will be quite simple amendments. They propose that a complaint can be mounted under clause 82 of the Bill for the reasons set out in the Bill. I will be supporting the establishment of positions of community affairs officers. Under my proposed amendment, clause 82 (1) will state:
Where a written complaint is made to the Corporation alleging-
(a) that an error of fact has occurred in a program, announcement or other matter broadcast or televised by the Corporation; or
(b) that an invasion of privacy has occurred in, or in connection with the preparation of, a program, announcement or other matter broadcast or televised by the Corporation,
(c) that a program was inaccurate, unfair or biased;
(d) that a program was otherwise offensive.
the complaint shall be referred as soon as practicable to a Community Affairs Officer appointed in accordance with this section.

I cannot see, nor have I heard, any reasons against that. What are the new aspects of it-that a program was inaccurate? That is already in the clause. An error of fact is covered in paragraph (a). But in relation to whether a program was unfair or biased, the Government has said in another place that it is not possible to define 'unfair' or 'biased'. That is an excuse for the occasion because in the legislation itself the requirement of the Board is established in clause 8 (c). It states:
To ensure that the gathering and presentation by the Corporation of news and information is accurate and impartial . . .

What is the definition of the word 'impartial'-the opposite to unfair and biased ? If the Government is saying that the words 'unfair' or 'biased' cannot be defined, honourable senators should look at the power that it gives to the community affairs officer to reject complaints if the community affairs officer says that the complaint is frivolous or vexatious. What is the definition of the words 'frivolous' and 'vexatious'?

TALK.START.PARA: —You told us the legal definition before; you can perhaps do it again.

—I am putting forward the straw man that the Government has put up in the House of Representatives in opposition to the very real need to have complaints relate to, including other matters, unfairness and bias. The final paragraph relates to a program being otherwise offensive. What is wrong with that? If honourable senators ask me for a definition of the word 'offensive ' I can reply that there are a great number of legal precedents, as the Minister would know, as to the test of the word 'offensive'-the reasonable man test.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that what I am proposing would, on reflection, be supported by the vast number of ordinary viewers and listeners. It may be said that what we are trying to do to the ABC is not available in respect of other television stations . The Senate has heard me speak on this matter before. I am concerned about the fact that the Broadcast Information Office, as an example, was not restructured so as to provide it with some muscle.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was abolished. It was not a question of being restructured. It was abolished by the previous Government.

—Indeed. It was starved of funds, I think. But at the end of the road licences for commercial television and broadcasting stations must be renewed. However, here we have a piece of legislation where the Australian Broadcasting Corporation will not be subject to renewals of licences. So, other safeguards must be placed in the legislation here and now. I believe that those people who agree with the proposition that if a program is biased, unfair or otherwise offensive now is the time to act and not some time in 1984, putting it on the long finger.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I reiterate that the ABC has, over many years, substantially contributed to the information and, indeed, the entertainment of Australians. In my opening statement I recalled that it is now over 50 years since the establishment of the Commission. It is now being re-established with a new name and a new charter. I sincerely hope that the Government appointees to the Corporation will ensure that this charter is carried through and that they will do so with independence and integrity. That is an issue, of course, which is very important for a national broadcaster such as the ABC. I believe that the most recent events, where the independence of the national broadcaster has been called into question, is a matter of some concern and some question as to whether in the appointments this independence will be maintained.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the honourable senators who have contributed to the debate for their general support of the legislation and, indeed, for some of the constructive comments which have been made. I do not want to reply at any great length, but there are a few matters with which I would like to deal. First, I comment on the speech made by Senator Chipp, who commended the general approach of the legislation and expressed some concern about a number of matters. I correct Senator Chipp on one matter. I do not want to be in dispute with him about this. I am glad to hear in the course of the debate that it was the idea of the Australian Democrats that nominations for the board of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation should be submitted to a committee. There was no proprietary right in that. It has been a policy of the Australian Labor Party for some time. As honourable senators know, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wrote to party leaders in accordance with that proposal a few days ago. Of course there has been debate about the mechanisms for securing the greatest degree of impartiality in the appointments to the board of the Corporation. I believe that the Democrats were earlier concerned to have appointments by the parliamentary process, which seemed to me to have some defects.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Government is trying to encourage here is a more civilised view than has existed in this country in the past about the political impartiality of the ABC and the need for this Parliament to behave in an impartial, non-partisan manner towards the Australian Broadcasting Commission. We are trying to establish in this country some of the civilised approach which exists in relation to appointments of the Governors of the Board of the British Broadcasting Corporation, for example, which are always matters of discussion between the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition in Britain. We think that that tradition could well be encouraged here. I remind the Senate that criteria are laid down in the Bill for the sorts of people who should be appointed to the board of the Corporation, general criteria which stem, I think, from the report of the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission.

Senator Chipp says that there are deficiencies in the Bill. I agree with that. The Government will be quite prepared to examine some of those deficiencies and take steps at a later stage, if necessary, to rectify some of them. Senator Chipp raised the question of the staff elected board member. It is the intention of the Government that there be a staff elected board member. Senator Chipp was concerned, I think, that that proposal should be enshrined in the legislation. It may be a matter that could be looked at in a review of the legislation but in the current parliamentary program it was not possible to amend the legislation to devise what would be very complex procedures for the choosing of a staff elected board member, but it is the Government's intention that it should be done.

Senator Chipp made a concession in relation to the question of the difficulty of defining unfairness and bias when talking about the complaints procedure. I remind them again that the Government is committed to an inquiry by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal with a view to establishing a fairness code in relation to broadcasting which will apply not only to the ABC but also to the commercial stations. In that context we hope that when that inquiry reports we may be able to take some legislative action on a bipartisan basis in relation to those proposals. Senator Chipp also drew attention to the provisions of clause 78 which require the Corporation not to broadcast certain matters, on the direction of the Minister, in the public interest. The government will be examining that proposal with a view to changing it, as it will in connection with the similar provision which exists in the Broadcasting and Television Act. I do not think it is any comfort, as Senator Peter Baume said by way of interjection, that at some stage if the Minister acts in that way he is required to report to this Parliament. I do not think that is a sufficient safeguard.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been an effective sanction over the years.

—I do not think it is an effective sanction at all. I do not think that Senator Peter Baume will find in any of the legislation establishing great national broadcasting institutions around the world, a similar provision. Of course it is a war time provision which has lingered on in the Australian Broadcasting Commission legislation and, now, into this new legislation. I regard it as a defect.
—Are you certain that there is not going to be another war?
—No, but I am certain of one thing: If there is another war I hope that this Parliament would have the wit, if necessary, to insert a provision of that kind into the legislation.
—The powers are already in the Constitution, in the event of a national emergency, for the Minister to take over broadcasting.
—Yes. I do not want to comment in detail on Senator Chipp's speech. I just thank him for his constructive suggestions regarding the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne also applauded the general concept of the Bill and took up a number of issues which perhaps more appropriately could be dealt with at the Committee stage. He was concerned about the deletion of the no work no pay provision. He was concerned about the complaints procedure. He introduced into the debate the expression 'appealing from Caesar unto Caesar' which has become the golden thread of speeches in the course of discussions in the Senate tonight . He is to be congratulated on introducing that expression into the debate. It portrays his literary lineage, if I can put it that way.

I want to comment generally about the complaints procedure because it is a matter to which Senator Harradine has devoted a lot of time. As Senator Harradine reminded us in the course of his speech, the Australian Broadcasting Commission has existed for 50 years and there have been no complaints procedures at all in that period. The fact that a complaints procedure is being inserted now against the wishes of some people is, in my view, a considerable improvement . The real question is whether there might be a better complaints procedure than the procedure which has been suggested or whether there might be some variations of it. The complaints procedure which is in the Bill is, in a sense, modelled on the suggestions that were initially made in the Dix Committee of Inquiry report on some reference to the law Reform Comission's proposals for the reform of defamation law in Australia. In some ways, of course, it has regard to the procedure which pertains in relation to the British Broadcasting Corporation.

In referring to the complaints procedure, I remind those honourable senators who have commented on it about the structure of this Bill. The complaints procedure is not an exclusive procedural mechanism for making complaints. The complaints procedure is designed for an aggrieved individual who has a complaint that his or her privacy was invaded or that the ABC has published material about him or her which is untrue. The legislation is designed to provide a mechanism of speedy rectification of that sort of complaint. For example, if I say something on an ABC program about Senator Peter Baume and he complains to the ABC that what I said was untrue-a situation which I would find unbelievable coming from Senator Peter Baume-he has his remedy very quickly because the complaints officer can order the ABC to retract or correct the untruth which has been uttered about Senator Peter Baume. Therefore, the legislation provides a mechanism of speedy rectification.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does Senator Baume's best friend have sufficient interest to complain?

—I am coming to that point. With respect, the argument that Senator Chipp has advanced about interest in the complaints procedure is really far wider than Senator Peter Baume's best friend in the context of what he put. The burden of Senator Harradine's complaint-I use that expression advisedly-is that the complaints procedure should be widened greatly to include complaints about program standards. I remind the Senate of the general charter of the Corporation as it will be. I refer first of all to clause 6 (1) of the Bill which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The functions of the Corporation are-
(a) to provide within Australia innovative and comprehensive broadcasting and television services of a high standard . . .
(b) to transmit to countries outside Australia broadcasting programs and television programs of news, current affairs, entertainment and cultural enrichment that will-
(i) encourage awareness of Australia and an international understanding of Australian attitudes on world affairs . . .
Sub-clause (2) of the Bill states:
In the provision by the Corporation of its broadcasting and television services within Australia-
(a) the Corporation shall take account of-
(ii) the standards from time to time approved by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in respect of broadcasting and television services;

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not mean to say it will do that.
—No but I will come to that point in a minute. I refer next to sub-paragraph (iii). It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (iii) the responsibility of the Corporation as the provider of an independent national broadcasting and television service to provide a balance between broadcasting programs and television programs of wide appeal and specialised broadcasting programs and television programs;
Clause 8 (1) states:
It is the duty of the Board-
(c) to ensure that the gathering and presentation by the Corporation of news and information is accurate and impartial according to the recognised standards of objective journalism . . .

That is the charter of the Corporation; that is its function. That is what it is enjoined to do. Those are its duties. The complaints procedure is by no means exclusive of the capacity of citizens to complain to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation just as, in the past, when there has been no complaints procedure at all, any complaints of any kind have gone to the Commission.

Senator Harradine gave an example of the way the complaints procedure jurisdiction should be widened to include program standards. He quoted the example of a vivid and graphic bloodshed scene in an overseas war shown on ABC television news six or nine months ago. I make the point that of course this scene was shown on all commercial television stations too. I am not disagreeing with the honourable senator about whether that is desirable material in the community context to be screened. That is a matter of debate in respect of which we all have subjective views. We all have different views about the degrees of violence which are portrayed on television of one kind or another. Of course all television stations, whether they be national broadcasting stations or commercial television stations can be described by some of us as being guilty of showing programs which we might regard as too violent. Senator Harradine took the example of a hypothetical mother of six who was offended by such a program. Firstly, I ask Senator Harradine whether the mother or any citizen could complain that the portrayal of such a program could be described as being biased or unfair. Of course it could not be described as being biased or unfair. Those are the criteria which the Opposition seeks to add to the complaints procedure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going further.
—I know that the honourable senator is going further. The honourable senator refers to biased, unfair or offensive--
—Otherwise offensive.

—Or otherwise offensive. The honourable senator is absolutely right. The honourable senator says that there are legal definitions of the word 'offensive'. Of course in Australia there are 14 million definitions of the word 'offensive'. Each citizen has a subjective view about what is offensive to him or her. We cannot make an objective judgment about whether a particular program is offensive. Whether a program is offensive or not is a matter which is peculiarly subject to a subjective judgment.
—The reasonable man test.

—With the greatest respect, I am sure that it would be a better world if we could apply the reasonable man test to determine what is offensive. A survey in the United States of America recently showed that the greatest purchasers of obscene video tapes were--
—Reasonable men.

—Were reasonable men and adherents of the major protestant churches in the United States. By far the greatest group of purchasers of obscene videotapes were reasonable men who went to protestant churches every Sunday.
—How could that survey be accurate? Why would such people admit it?
—Of course they would not. There is no doubt that that survey may not be accurate; that is precisely the point.
—You know the definition of 'reasonable man' and 'otherwise offensive'. What you are saying is nonsense.

—With the greatest respect to the honourable senator, he is talking old law, as they say-about 1900, I would think. The point I seek to make is that there is no objective test of what is offensive in relation to television programs. No other country would attempt to define it in this way, with the possible exception of one republic whose name I decline to mention.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine also dealt with questions of law, as he put it, in dealing with who had a sufficient interest to make a complaint. Of course, if honourable senators look at the jurisdiction of the complaints tribunal described in the Bill they will see that the jurisdiction is confined, firstly, to complaints about untruth concerning a particular person and, secondly, to the invasion of privacy. In a sense that is very relevant to the question of who has standing to make a complaint. One has to look at the two provisions together. Senator Harradine said that sufficient interest is always defined. The legal interpretation of it is what he called hip pocket interest. With the greatest respect, that is not the legal interpretation of sufficient interest and has not been for a very long time. Since the law has developed in respect of class actions and matters of that kind, particularly in the United States of America and the United Kingdom, that sort of definition of sufficient interest has not really held sway at all.

In connection with the complaints procedure we would argue that one has to look at the structure of the Bill, the function of the Corporation and the functions and duties of the Board to realise that the complaints procedure in itself is not an exclusive arena for complaints. One can make complaints, if one wants to do so, if one is a vexatious complainant. If one wants to make complaints about program standards, as they have been called in the course of this debate, there is not much point in making them in retrospect to a complaints officer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?

—Let me answer the question asked by Senator Sir John Carrick because this will really illustrate the point. Let us take Senator Harradine's example. He sees, together with the mother to whom he referred, a violent scene on television to which he objects. He then makes a complaint about it and describes it as offensive. The community affairs officer might well agree with him and say: 'Yes, that program was offensive'. How has Senator Harradine advanced in one way by having made that complaint? In that situation Senator Harradine should make a complaint to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation about its program standards, which do not specifically affect him but, he would say, affect community standards. He should make a complaint to the Corporation and say: 'I do not like violence on television, You are not carrying out your charter. I saw these bad examples of violence on television and you should not show that sort of thing again'. That complaint would go to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
—It is Caesar unto Caesar.

—Would you be quiet for a minute? That complaint would go to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation as the maker of the program. That is the point. There are differences between the types of complaints.
—It is Caesar unto Caesar.

—It is of no use Senator Walters coming into this chamber and picking up the rhetoric of Senator Crichton-Browne at this stage of the evening. It has been said that a complaints officer is not independent of the ABC in the sense that it is an appeal from Caesar unto Caesar. I think the Australian Democrats have moved a very important amendment in relation to this matter, which the Government will accept-that is, to provide that the complaints officer is not appointed by the Board of the Corporation but is appointed by the General Manager on the recommendation of the Advisory Council. I think that is very important. When we talk about the independence of the complaints officer I think the Opposition really should have a look at its amendment. In the Opposition's amendment by whom is the complaints officer to be appointed? The Government. What an extraordinary provision for an Opposition, which is so concerned about the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, to bring up an amendment in which the complaints officer will be appointed by the government of the day. I cannot think of anything more outrageous in terms of a party which purports to be concerned about the independence of the ABC.
—Who appoints the Advisory Council? The ABC.

—So what. I want now to deal with other matters which have been raised in the course of debate by Senate Baume and others. Firstly, on behalf of the Government I would like to pay tribute to the work of the Dix Committee of Review of the ABC. As far as the present Government is concerned, the Dix Committee did not necessarily provide the best solutions in all circumstances to the problems of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, but it provided a very good analysis of those problems. It is to be much commended for its report which was brought down under the chairmanship of Mr Alex Dix. Secondly, I would like to congratulate the Minister of the time, Mr Tony Staley, who appointed the Dix Committee. It is a great tragedy for this Parliament and for the Liberal Party that people in the Opposition today do not always share the Liberal-minded, independent sort of view of the role of the ABC which Mr Tony Staley had as Minister. It is a great tragedy that many of the appointments that he suggested for the Board of the ABC were not accepted by the Government of the time. I pay tribute both to the Dix Committee and to Mr Staley.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has moved an amendment in relation to this matter which suggests , firstly, that this Bill should be delayed until legal action against the ABC by Premier Wran is completed. Secondly, the amendment seeks this assurance:
That there will be no Government interference with the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission in its programming policy.

The amendment contains a number of other matters but I just want to deal with those two that I have mentioned. This is the most shabby little amendment that any Opposition could ever bring into this place. The Opposition is using the Australian Broadcasting Commission as I am afraid the worst elements in the Liberal Party have always done, as a political football. It is really saying that the ABC's action with Premier Wran should be disposed of before this Bill is passed by the Senate. I could not see how anybody in this country who has any concern for the Australian Broadcasting Commission and who understands its current plight-I believe that there are plenty of honourable senators on the Opposition side who do-could vote for that amendment. There is nothing more urgent for the ABC than getting this legislation passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you talking for so long if the Bill is so urgent?

—I am surprised that Opposition senators, such as Senator Walters who interjects, do not feel the same concern about it. Last year they described this legislation as urgent legislation. Mr Neil Brown, the then Minister for Communications, campaigned throughout the election on the basis, as he put it, that the then Opposition had delayed the urgent ABC legislation in the Senate. The present Opposition now comes up, in the context of May 1983, with this sordid little amendment which attempts to use the ABC as a political football. I think it is absolutely extraordinary that this amendment could be countenanced as some sort of cheap political ploy.

SPEECH.PARA: What does this amendment mean, for example, to Senator Durack? Senator Durack has a libel action against the ABC. Should we amend the Opposition's motion to include a provision that the legislation should not be passed until Senator Durack's libel action against the ABC is disposed of? Does Senator Durack approve of that course of action? Does he think that it would be a good idea? I do not think so. That is precisely what he, as Deputy Leader of the Opposition, and his party have moved in this place by way of this cheap little amendment to the legislation. I find that quite extraordinary.

Senator Peter Baume made a number of other quite constructive comments about the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I know that in many respects there is a shared point of view about the importance of this legislation. I say exactly the same about Senator Sir John Carrick's speech with the exception, of course, of some of the observations which he made about the complaints procedure. I remind the Senate again that last year the previous Government introduced this legislation, containing a complaints procedure which the Chairman of the British Broadcasting Corporation, Mr Howard, described as outrageous. He said it would not be tolerated by any national broadcasting corporation throughout the world. He said: 'If I worked in the ABC and the Parliament passed this legislation containing complaints procedure providing for penalties against journalists and inquisitorial methods for finding out how programs were made, I would down tools and walk out'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that?

—That was Mr Howard, the Chairman of the BBC, who was visiting Australia last year. That is what he said about the previous Government's complaints procedure. Of course, the Opposition introduced this amendment which purports to be modelled on the BBC's complaints procedure. It is not a BBC complaints procedure. It is a broadcasting complaints procedure which applies to all of the commercial networks in Great Britain, as well as the BBC. It is not a BBC complaints procedure. The Opposition's amendment argues that the complaints tribunal should be appointed by the government of the day. That seems to us to be an extraordinary interference with the process of a great national broadcasting organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is very concerned that this legislation should pass in the best possible form and looks forward to the reinvigoration of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation under a new board and a great future for it consistent with the great past which it has had-a past whose standards have in a sense deteriorated a great deal. I say that in a bipartisan way. It needs a great new stride forward to reinvigorate this important body. The Government commends the Bill to the Senate.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 10-by leave-taken together and agreed to.
Clause 11 (Advisory Councils and committees).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHIPP
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 7, clause 11, lines 12 to 15, leave out sub-clause (3), substitute the following sub-clause:
'(3) The functions of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Advisory Council are-
(a) either on its own initiative or at the request of the Board, to furnish advice to the Board on matters relating to broadcasting programs and television programs of the Corporation; and
(b) either on its own initiative or at the request of the Managing Director, to make recommendations to the Managing Director in accordance with sub-section 82 (3).'
(2) Page 7, clause 11, lines 16 to 21, leave out sub-clause (4), substitute the following sub-clause:
'(4) The function of an Advisory Council established under sub-section (2) are-

(a) in the case of an Advisory Council established in relation to a State, Territory or region-either on its own initiative or at the request of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Advisory Council, to furnish advice to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Advisory Council on matters relating to broadcasting programs and television programs of the Corporation in that State, Territory or region, as the case may be; and

(b) in the case of an Advisory Council established in relation to a State or Territory-either on its own initiative or at the request of the Managing Director, to make recommendations to the Managing Director with respect to the appointment of Community Affairs Officers in relation to that State or Territory .'.

These amendments would allow the advisory councils to make recommendations to the Managing Director on the appointment of the community affairs officers. I would agree very quickly with the interjections of Senator Walters, Senator Baume and Senator Harradine that if one goes back to see who appointed the advisory councils, one has to admit that they are appointed by the Board of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. I concede that this is not the most desirable of situations. If the Board appoints the advisory councils and if the advisory councils make the recommendation of the appointment of the community affairs officers, a direct link can be detected between the Board and the community affairs officers. This is not desirable but it does not altogether deserve the criticism of Caesar appealing unto Caesar. However, that sort of interjection can well be levelled in spirit. I remind the Opposition what the way it would have had it would have been worse. The Opposition wanted a compaints commissioner not appointed by the Board but appointed by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —We still do.
—And the Opposition still does because it wants to retain this precious principle--
—It is an honest difference of views.

—I am not saying that it is not. I am saying that it is the principle that the Executive should have powers over these matters. The Australian Democrats are old fashioned enough to believe that Parliament should have powers over the Executive. Would the Opposition allow an Executive or a Cabinet to appoint without restriction the members of the Board and the complaints commissioner? I believe you have a neat and naked situation of Caesar appealing unto Caesar. The Democrats wanted the appointment of the community affairs officers to be made by the Parliament. It was pointed out to us that at this stage at least that would be unwieldy.

SPEECH.PARA: The next move we made was to try to have the community affairs officers and the advisory councils appointed by an all-party committee of the Parliament, just as the Board is being appointed from the names submitted by an all-party committee of the Parliament. At least we thought that that would have taken away the direct link between the advisory councils and the Board. Clause 11 (6) of the Bill specifies that:

In making appointments to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Advisory Council, the Board shall have regard to the desirability of including in the membership of that Advisory Council a broad representation of the Australian community.

That is fair enough. I would have thought that the Government would have enshrined that principle at least by having an all-party committee recommmending the membership of that Advisory Council. But at this stage the Government has declined to accept that proposition although it did accept the proposition relating to the appointment of the Board. So at this stage we rely on the fact that at least the members of the Board who appoint the Advisory Council and the community affairs officers will come from the names nominated by the all-party committee. At least that is some protection--

TALK.START.PARA: —But in the case of the BBC didn't the Government appoint the community affairs officers?

—I think Senator Walters' interjection is worth while and I would like the Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications (Senator Button) to answer it in detail. My understanding is that the two situations, that of the British Broadcasting Corporation and our Corporation, are not comparable, as was stated by the former Chairman of the BBC when he visited Australia.
—I think he was commenting on the very early one.

—I would be interested to hear the Minister reply to Senator Walters' interjection. Whilst the Democrats and I agree that this is not the perfect situation, we believe it is better than the proposition put by the Liberals, that the Government should appoint the complaints commissioner and that that be the end of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will accept the two amendments moved by Senator Chipp. It does so largely for the reasons outlined by Senator Chipp in the sense that we believe the amendments inprove the legislation. We also believe that they do not make the legislation perfect. In terms of obtaining a greater independence for the complaints officer from the Board of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, it may well be that that matter could receive further consideration in subsequent legislation. However, we do think that the amendments are a vast improvement. The role of the Board in connection with the Advisory Council is to appoint, in a sense, a community interest group. That community interest group would make a recommendation to the General Manager regarding the appointment of the community affairs officer.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say by way of dealing with Senator Walters' interjection that in relation to the British Broadcasting Corporation there have been two models of complaints procedures. The first was set up by the BBC in October 1971 to consider complaints from the public of what was called unfair treatment in radio and television programs. That procedure operated until 1981. That first body was set up by the British Broadcasting Corporation itself. In 1981 that body was abolished and the Government, by legislation, set up a statutory broadcasting complaints commission. Of course, it does not apply only to the BBC. It applies to the independent commercial networks and to independent commercial radio-to the whole spectrum of broadcasting activities in the United Kingdom.

TALK.START.PARA: —It still applies to the BBC.

—It is a vastly different situation from what is being contemplated here. Had I heard a lot of enthusiasm from Senator Walters in the past about setting up a complaints procedure with regard to commercial broadcasters, I would have been delighted. But of course I did not.
—They lose their licence.

—Come on! They do not lose their licences; don't be silly! The important point is that, in dealing with this legislation which relates to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, we set up the best procedure available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is interested to hear that the Government accepts these two amendments. The Opposition likewise would have wanted to support what Senator Chipp is doing. There is a difference between seeking advice from the Parliament and going down the American road of ' advise and consent'. There is a big difference. Part of the difference between us in discussions was that Senator Chipp was looking for 'advise and consent'; in other words, the Parliament having a power of veto. Unless I misunderstand the import of Senator Chipp's amendments--
—Is that not the Westminster system?

—The honourable senator might care to tell the Committee. I suspect that what he is doing here is establishing a mechanism by which advice can come from the bodies mentioned in his two amendments in relation to certain appointments.
—It says 'on recommendation'. That is a different thing.
—It says 'to make recommendations'. Paragraph (b) has been added to clause 11. That reads:

SPEECH.PARA: either on its own initiative or at the request of the Managing Director, to make recommendations to the Managing Director in accordance with sub-section 82 (3).

That does not give a power to determine exclusively from whom appointments may be made. It gives a power to make some recommendations. I take it that they are not the only recommendations that can be made. I think it is quite proper that that power should be there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at my amendment No. 4. That answers your question, although I was not allowed to move it.

—I am making the point in relation to the first two. I make it clear that the proposition that an advisory function should be there is not a proposition with which the Opposition would disagree. I make that quite clear and I note that the Government has accepted the two amendments.

—I must answer the comments made by Senator Button a few minutes ago when he said that the situation with regard to the British Broadcasting Corporation is totally different because it covers both commercial stations and the BBC whereas this situation covers only the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. The situation here is that the commercial stations have to defend their licences each year which the ABC does not have to do. As a consequence, there is that difference.
—Thank you very much, Senator!

—The honourable senator chose to ignore the situation. I felt that it needed clarifying. Mr Howard of the BBC was very critical of the original Bill brought forward by the previous Government but not of the subsequent Bill which was altered considerably. Because Senator Chipp showed some interest in Senator Button's statement, I ask Senator Button whether the British Government appoints the complaints commissioner for the BBC who, we are all well aware, encompasses the commercial stations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I had already dealt with that point. I have made the point that there is no British Broadcasting Corporation complaints commission. It was abolished in 1981. If I have to say it half a dozen more times, I will. But there is no BBC complaints commissioner.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 12 (Membership of Board).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHIPP
TALKER.ROLE: Leader Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the very brief point that the Australian Democrats would have preferred to have had written into the legislation the specification that a staff member should be appointed a part time director. We would also have preferred that the all-party committee which recommends part time members of the Board be enshrined in the legislation. I just make in passing that point which I made in my second reading speech and which Senator Button answered in his second reading speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 13 to 26-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not an area in which we intend to move amendments, but I seek a little clarification from Senator Button on some matters relating to clause 25 which deals with the general powers of the Corporation. I refer the honourable senator to sub-clause (3) which says:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to sub-section (5), the Corporation does not have power to accept any payment or other consideration for the broadcasting or televising of any announcement, program or other matter.

Will the honourable senator clarify to the Committee the capacities of the new Corporation with regard to co-productions and what it might accept by way of remuneration in this area? I refer him to sub-clause (4) where it is stated that the Corporation does not have power to do certain things 'where it is likely that the independence or integrity of the Corporation would be affected'. What effect would this have on advertising at, say, a sporting fixture which the Australian Broadcasting Commission might wish to televise? How much billboard advertising would be permissible? To what extent would the question of peripheral advertising relate to this clause? A number of people in the community are concerned about the extent to which there is involuntary exposure of advertising matter. Senator Elstob is smiling at me. He anticipates what I might be about to say. A lot of it is to do with the promotion of cigarette smoking.

TALK.START.PARA: —And alcohol.
—And alcohol. This seems to be the clause of the Bill in which these matters are raised. I would appreciate Senator Button giving us some clarification on some of these matters.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 25 (3) of the Bill does not, in the Government's view, have any effect on the capacity of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to enter into co-production activities. The clause is directed to the question of whether the Corporation, in respect of material shown on its television screen, for example, accepts a payment in respect of the showing or broadcasting of that material. The answer to that question is no, sub-clause (3) does not have any effect on the Corporation's capacity to jointly produce programs as distinct from accepting money for programs shown on its screen. That is the point of the clause.
—Does it limit the way by which it might be paid for doing a co-production?

—No. With regard to the second part of the question, I follow Senator Peter Baume's point. I would not think that public concern about, as it were, the vicarious showing of advertisements on television screens is likely in any way to effect the independence or integrity of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. The examples which Senator Peter Baume gave are in a sense inadvertent showings and not showings for gain. This whole clause is directed to establishing that the Corporation shall not do these things for gain.

—I thank Senator Button. Some of us are concerned, nevertheless, by a series of promotional practices which have arisen whereby those who sponsor certain sporting events can count upon the fact that they will get, inadvertently, television exposure for their products. This seems to be the proper point at which to mention the matter. The British Broadcasting Corporation has a stricter set of rules in relation to what it will allow by way of peripheral advertising of certain products. I understand that the BBC has a rule that, if certain kinds of advertising occur at a sporting event, that event simply is not televised. I put it to Senator Button that it would be helpful to know the ways in which we differ from the BBC in the practices and standards we adopt in relation to this kind of peripheral advertising and the capacity of promoters to force, as it were, their products upon the people by way of what Senator Button called, I think, inadvertent exposure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make an observation in respect of that matter. I put the proposition earlier that, because of the enormous amount of sponsors' funds involved, it was necessary for commercial reasons that there be exclusive rights for commercial television stations to televise certain sporting activities. I further put the proposition that in those areas where the commercial television stations do not have facilities, such as the north west of Western Australia where one gets on the Australian Broadcasting Commission the Children's Hour three times a day whether one likes it or not, if Channel 9, Channel 0 or Channel 10--
—What's wrong with the Children's Hour?
—There is nothing wrong with the Children's Hour if one is 21 or under. There are those occasions--
—Or unless you are a senator.

—I must say that the level of debate is often much higher. There are those occasions when, say, Channel 9 has bought the rights to televise a major cricket match. The sponsors of that match are shown on the score board. The sponsors' products are clearly identified around the arena. If we were to eliminate the prospect of the ABC having any such sponsorship exposed on its screens in very large doses, people in those isolated areas would just not have access to those sporting occasions. I think we must be very careful, in balance, to ensure that they are not denied that opportunity simply because of this provision.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 27 (News services).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHIPP
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 16, clause 27, before sub-clause (1), insert the following sub-clause:
'(1A) The Corporation shall develop and maintain an independent service for the broadcasting and televising of news and information by the Corporation pursuant to this section.'.

Sub-clause (1) of clause 27 is the sub-clause of the Bill that gives the Australian Broadcasting Corporation the rights and responsibilities of collecting news. Probably one of the most important and vital functions of the ABC is an independent news service. The Australian Democrats want inserted as a preamble the following words:
The Corporation shall develop and maintain an independent service for the broadcasting and televising of news and information by the Corporation pursuant to this section.
We have proposed this amendment-I am grateful that the Government is prepared to accept it-because of the wording of existing clause 27, sub-sections (1), (2) and (3). Sub-clause (2) states, in part:

The Managing Director shall ensure that the officers and temporary employees of the Corporation include an adequate number of persons . . . for the purpose of collecting the news and information . . .
I repeat the words 'an adequate number of persons'. The Bill does not specify what is adequate; of course, it cannot. Sub-clause (3) states:

Without affecting the obligations of the Managing Director under sub-section (2 ), the Corporation may also procure news and information relating to current events from such news agencies and other sources, whether . . . as the Board thinks fit.

That means, in lay language, that the new Board will have the power to get news from the Australian Associated Press, the American Associated Press, Reuters and anywhere it pleases. We have no objection to that. Good luck to the Corporation if it gets the news from the widest possible sources, but it is remotely possible that the management could well say that an adequate number of persons is 10-I am being ridiculous now-and that the ABC will get all its news from AAP, Reuters or wherever. If our amendment-our preamble-is carried, it will make the right and the responsibility of the Corporation absolutely beyond question. It will ensure that:
The Corporation shall . . . maintain an independent service for the broadcasting and televising of news and information . . .

We believe that it would be an improvement to the Bill. We understand from discussions with staff members of the ABC that there is some concern in the ABC that this could happen somewhere along the track. We commend the amendment to the Committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government accepts the amendment. We are not sure that it will make anything more than a marginal improvement but we appreciate the point that Senator Chipp has advanced.

—It may well be that this is a cosmetic amendment. Senator Chipp referred to some of the words in sub-clauses ( 2) and (3) of clause 27. I would have thought that the clause as drafted probably provided the kinds of safeguards that the honourable senator was seeking. The words 'an adequate number' in sub-clause (2) and the word 'also' at line 35 in sub-clause (3) ensure that the Corporation is required to have its own news service. I note that the Government has accepted the amendment which has been moved and I imagine that it will therefore have support from all around the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to this amendment. It is rather close to my own heart, as I worked as a journalist and foreign correspondent for the Australian Broadcasting Commission news for a considerable time. I only make the point to Senator Peter Baume and possibly to Senator Button that the Bill prior to our amendment describes that situation of the ABC news in the years just after World War II when in fact it was run by a shoestring staff who pasted together bits of newspaper and took stuff from the wire service. The big bite which the honourable senators, as it was so long ago, may not now recall, was to make sure that the ABC news was an independent news service. As a result of that it has developed over the last three decades a representation of overseas officers which gives this country an independent viewpoint on world events, especially in South East Asia and Asia generally, which is unparalleled and which has attracted praise from all over the world. The Australian Democrats felt that it was very important to make this amendment, which is not cosmetic. I think the proposition that we should have sufficient staff merely to collect the news and information reveals a lack of appreciation of the journalistic process and expertise and the fight that has gone on over these decades to provide and maintain an independent news service in the ABC which has been of enormous value to this country. I note that the Government has accepted the amendment, and the Opposition apparently does not oppose it. But I think it is worth reiterating, in view of the comments of Senator Button and Senator Peter Baume, that this is a much more basic matter than they appear to understand and that it has been a matter of representations of some seriousness from both the staff of the ABC news and the Australian Journalists Association.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 28 to 45-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 31 actually concerns advertisements. Perhaps this is the point at which I should have raised the problem to which I drew attention earlier. I have before me a note the subject of which I did not raise and which I wish now to raise with Senator Button. It concerns part of the problem with perimeter advertising. I will not go over the problem again; we discussed it a few moments ago. Am I correct in understanding that a perimeter advertisement clearly is an advertisement but is not regarded as an advertisement in terms of this clause and of the requirements on the Australian Broadcasting Commission? Apparently it is not regarded as an advertisement because the ABC is not paid for it. I would like to ask the honourable senator to clarify for me whether that is the case.
—When is an advertisement not an advertisement?

—And why is it not an advertisement? Common sense tells us that it is an advertisement. A cricket club in South Australia decided to have nothing to do with tobacco promotion. That cricket club was ostracised; it was treated rather harshly by its own cricket association. A number of honourable senators are members of the supporters' club of that district cricket club.

SPEECH.PARA: Consideration interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That cricket club has had to fight for its existence and has had to fight in public because it elected not to accept tobacco sponsorship. It is quite clear that the tobacco companies are moving towards taking over sport in Australia. That is another question. Why are perimeter advertisements not picked up within the purview of this clause which, on the surface, looks quite clear? If they are not picked up, I ask the Government to take under study now they might be picked up because I think it really baffles logic that they are not included.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHIPP
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support what Senator Baume said. He does not want an answer tonight. I do not think there is an answer. I vigorously support what Senator Baume said about undesirable advertisements being flashed on to the television screen inadvertently or accidentally on purpose when filming a cricket match, a hockey match or whatever. I also take up Senator Crichton-Browne's point that a great number of sporting events are sponsored by manufacturers of undesirable products . What will the Australian Broadcasting Commission do if it televises an event featuring the visiting English cricket team in some rural part of Western Australia and there happens to be a cigarette advertisement nearby? Will it black it out? All I think Senator Baume and I, and indeed Senator Crichton- Browne, want tonight is for the Minister to put the matter under study over, say , 12 months and, as Senator Baume suggested, to consider the way in which the British Broadcasting Corporation handles this problem so that we can look at this matter when next revising the Act.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no hostility to the suggestion made by Senator Baume and Senator Chipp. In a sense the technical answer is that the expressions 'broadcast' and 'televise' are not defined in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill. They are defined in the Broadcasting and Television Act, as I recall it. What it means is to disseminate advertisements through the mechanism available to the Australian Broadcasting Commission, whether it be a television screen or a radio receiver. I am quite happy to investigate the matter that Senator Baume raised. We share his view in general terms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator. I shall pick up something which Senator Chipp said. I am not suggesting in any way that the companies which make these products are not acting properly or that they should not sell their products. This question is confined to a very narrow compass; that is, the way in which they should be advertised. I wish to put that matter on the public record. It may have sounded in my earlier remarks as though I was attacking the companies concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Proposed new Division 2A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 28, after clause 45, insert the following Division:
'Division 2A-Failure to work as directed
No work as directed-no pay.

45A. (1) Where an officer or temporary employee refuses or fails to comply with a direction given by a person having authority to give the direction, being a lawful direction with respect to work that he is performing or is to perform, the Managing Director may declare that the officer or employee is not to be paid salary.
(2) A declaration under sub-section (1) in relation to the refusal or failure of an officer or temporary employee to comply with a direction-

(a) shall specify the time (which may be a time before the declaration is made but not earlier than the time when the officer or employee refused or failed, or first refused or first failed, to comply with the direction) from which the declaration is to have effect, or is to be deemed to have had effect; and
(b) has effect and shall be deemed to have had effect, according to its tenor, from the time so specified until it is revoked in accordance with this section.

(3) An officer or temporary employee is not entitled to be paid salary in respect of any period in respect of which a declaration under sub-section (1) has effect, or is to be deemed to have had effect, in relation to him.
(4) The Managing Director-
(a) may, at any time, vary or revoke a declaration in force under sub-section ( 1) either wholly or in relation to a specified officer or temporary employee; and

(b) shall, upon becoming satisfied that an officer or temporary employee in respect of whom a declaration under sub-section (1) is in force has been complying, or will comply, from a particular time, with all relevant directions with respect to the work that he is performing, or is to perform, given by persons having authority to give those directions, revoke, as from that time, that declaration, or that declaration in its application to that officer or employee, as the case requires.

(5) A declaration made under sub-section (1) in respect of a refusal or failure of an officer or temporary employee to comply with a particular direction, or with particular directions, has effect in accordance with sub-section (2) notwithstanding that, at any time while it is in force, the officer or employee-
(a) attends for duty and performs work other than work to which that direction, or any of those directions, as the case requires, relates; or
(b) attends for duty and, in the performance of his work, complies with that direction, or with some or all of those directions, as the case requires, in part only.
(6) A declaration under sub-section (1), and a variation or revocation of such a declaration-
(a) shall be made in writing; and
(b) shall be signed-
(i) by the Managing Director; or
(ii) by a person to whom the Managing Director has delegated his powers under this section.

(7) Subject to sub-sections (8) and (9), the powers conferred on the Managing Director by this section are in addition to, and not in substitution for, any other powers conferred by or under this Act on the Corporation, on the Board, on the Managing Director or on any other person in relation to an officer or temporary employee.

(8) While a declaration under sub-section (1) is in force in respect of the refusal or failure of an officer or temporary employee to comply with a direction, or with 2 or more directions, proceedings shall not be taken against the officer or employee under section 64 in respect of any refusal or failure of the officer or employee in respect of which that declaration was made.
