SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 49, after clause 77, insert the following new Part:
'PART VIIA-COMPLAINTS ABOUT PROGRAMS
Division 1-Preliminary
Interpretation
77A. In this Part, unless the contrary intention appears-
'Commission' means the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Complaints Commission;
'Commissioner' means a member of the Commission;
'complaint', in relation to a program means a complaint as to any one or more of the following matters:
(a) that the program was unjust or unfair;
(b) that an unwarranted intrusion into the privacy of a person took place in the course of obtaining matter for inclusion in the program;
(c) that the program constituted an unwarranted intrusion into the privacy of a person;
'person affected', in relation to a complaint, means the person by whom, or on whose behalf, as the case may be, the complaint is made;
'program' means a broadcasting or television program of the Corporation broadcast or televised, as the case may be, after the commencement of this Part.
Division 2-Establishment, Functions and Powers of Australian Broadcasting Corporation Complaints Commission
Establishment of Commission
77B. For the purposes of this Act there shall be an Australian Broadcasting Corporation Complaints Commission.
Functions of Commission
77C. The functions of the Commission are to consider and adjudicate upon complaints with respect to programs.
Making of complaints
77D. (1) A complaint made to the Commission shall be in writing and shall identify the person affected.
(2) Subject to sub-section (3), a complaint shall not be entertained by the Commission unless made by the person affected or by a person authorized by him to make the complaint.

(3) Where the person affected is a deceased person or is a natural person who for any reason is both unable to make a complaint himself and unable to authorize another person to do so for him, a complaint may be made by the personal representative of the person affected, or by a member of his family, or by some other person or body closely connected with him.
Entertainment of complaints
77E. (1) The Commission is not required to entertain a complaint if, in the opinion of the Commission-
(a) the complaint is with respect to the broadcasting or televising of the relevant program on an occasion more than 5 years after the death of the person affected;
(b) the subject matter of the complaint is the subject of proceedings in any court;

(c) the subject matter of the complaint is a matter in respect of which the person affected has a remedy by way of proceedings in any court, and in the particular circumstances it is not appropriate for the Commission to consider the complaint;
(d) the complaint is frivolous or vexatious, or was not made in good faith;
(e) the person affected does not have a sufficient interest in the subject matter of the complaint;

(f) in the case of a complaint made under sub-section 77D (3) by a person other than the person affected or a person authorized by him the complainant's connection with the person affected is not sufficiently close; or
(g) the complaint has not been made within a reasonable time.

(2) Where the Commission does not, for any of the reasons specified in sub- section (1), entertain a complaint, it shall, as soon as practicable and in such manner as it thinks fit, inform the complainant and the Corporation of the Commission's decision and of the reasons for the decision.

(3) Where the Commission does not entertain a matter that is the subject of several complaints, sub-section (2) does not require it to notify each of the complainants if the Commission is of the opinion that, having regard to the number of complainants, it would be unduly burdensome to do so.
Consideration of complaints
77F. (1) Subject to section 77E before proceeding to consider a complaint, the Commission shall send a copy of the complaint to the Corporation.

(2) A complaint may be considered by the Commission at a hearing or without a hearing, as the Commission thinks fit, and, at a hearing, the Commission is not bound by the rules of evidence and may inform itself on any matter in such manner as it thinks fit.
(3) A hearing under this section shall be held in private, and each of the following persons shall be given the opportunity to attend and be heard:
(a) the complainant;
(b) the Managing Director or an officer of the Corporation authorized by him in writing for the purpose;
(c) any other person who, in the opinion of the Commission, is responsible for the making or provision of the program concerned.
(4) Where the Corporation receives from the Commission a copy of a complaint, the Managing Director shall, if so required by the Commission:

(a) make suitable arrangements for enabling the complainant and any Commissioner or member of the staff referred to in sub-section 77K (1) to view or hear the relevant program, or any specified part of it, if and so far as the Corporation has in its possession a visual or sound record of it;

(b) provide the Commission and the complainant with a transcript of so much of the relevant program, or of any specified part of it, as consisted of speech, if and so far as the Corporation is able to do so;

(c) provide the Commission and the complainant with copies of any documents in the possession of the Corporation, being the originals or copies of any correspondence between the Corporation and the person affected or the complainant in connection with the complaint; and
(d) furnish to the Commission and the complainant a written statement in answer to the complaint.

(5) Where the Commission proposes to consider a complaint, the Corporation shall, if so required by the Commission, arrange for one or more of the Directors, officers or employees of the Corporation to attend and assist the Commission in its consideration of the complaint.
Reports by Commission
77G. (1) Where the Commission has considered and adjudicated upon a complaint, the Commission shall furnish a report on the complaint to-
(a) the complainant or, if there is more than one complainant, each of the complainants; and
(b) the Corporation.

(2) Where the Commission has considered and adjudicated upon a matter that is the subject of several complaints, sub-section (1) does not require it to notify each of the complainants if the Commission is of the opinion that, having regard to the number of complainants, it would be unduly burdensome to do so.

(3) Where the Commission furnishes a report to the Corporation under sub- section (1), it may require the Corporation to publish, in a manner specified by the Commission, a summary of, and of its findings on, the subject matter of the complaint and may, if it thinks fit, require the summary to be in a form prepared or approved by the Commission.
(4) The Corporation shall comply with any requirements made of it by the Commission under sub-section (3).
Duty to publicize Commission and its functions

77H. The Corporation shall make (by means of broadcasting or television or otherwise) regular announcements publicizing the Commission and its functions of considering and adjudicating upon complaints.
Delegation by Commission

77J. (1) The Commission may, by resolution, either generally or as otherwise provided by the resolution, delegate to a Commissioner or to a member of the staff referred to in sub-section 77K (1) all or any of its powers under this Part (other than this power of delegation and its powers to consider and adjudicate upon complaints and to furnish reports upon complaints).
(2) A power so delegated, when exercised by the delegate, shall, for the purposes of this Part, be deemed to have been exercised by the Commission.
(3) A delegation of a power under this section-
(a) may be revoked by resolution of the Commission (whether or not constituted by the persons constituting the Commission at the time the power was delegated);
(b) does not prevent the exercise of the power by the Commission; and
(c) continues in force notwithstanding a change in the membership of the Commission.
(4) Section 34A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 applies in relation to a delegation under this section as if the Commission were a person.

(5) A certificate purporting to bear the signature, or a facsimile of the signature, of the Chairman and stating any matter with respect to a delegation of a power under this section is, upon mere production, prima facie evidence of that matter.
Staff
77K. (1) The staff required for the purposes of this Part shall be persons appointed or employed under the Public Service Act 1922.

(2) The Chairman has all the powers of, or exercisable by, a Permanent Head under the Public Service Act 1922 so far as those powers relate to the branch of the Public Service comprising the staff referred to in sub-section (1) as if that branch were a separate Department of the Public Service.
(3) For the purposes of sub-sections 25 (5) and (6) of the Public Service Act 1922, the Chairman shall be deemed to be a Permanent Head.
Division 3-Constitution and Meetings of Australian Broadcasting Corporation Complaints Commission
Membership of Commission
77L. (1) The Commission shall consist of not less than 3 nor more than 5 Commissioners.

(2) A Commissioner shall be appointed by the Governor-General on a part-time basis for such period, not exceeding 5 years, as it specified in the instrument of his appointment, but is eligible for re-appointment.
(3) The Governor-General shall appoint one commissioner to be the Chairman of the Commission and another to be the Deputy Chairman of the Commission.

(4) The performance of the functions or the exercise of the powers of the Commission is not affected by reason that there is no Chairman or Deputy Chairman or by reason of the number of Commissioners falling below 3 for not longer than 6 months.
Remuneration and allowances

77M. (a) A Commissioner shall be paid such remuneration as is determined by the Remuneration Tribunal but, if no determination of that remuneration by the Tribunal is in operation, he shall be paid such remuneration as is prescribed by the regulations.
(2) A Commissioner shall be paid such allowances as are prescribed by the regulations.
(3) This section has effect subject to the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973.
Leave of absence
77N. (1) The Minister may grant leave to the Chairman to be absent from a meeting of the Commission upon such conditions as to remuneration or otherwise as the Minister thinks fit.
(2) The Chairman may grant leave to any other Commissioner to be absent from a meeting of the Commission upon such conditions as to remuneration or otherwise as the Chairman thinks fit.
(3) References in sub-sections (1) and (2) to the Chairman shall, if a Commissioner is acting as Chairman, be construed as references to the Commissioner so acting.
Resignation of Commissioners
770. A Commissioner may resign his office by writing signed by him delivered to the Governor-General.
Disclosure of interests
77P. (1) Where a Commissioner has or acquires any interest, pecuniary or otherwise, that could conflict with the proper performance of his functions in relation to a complaint made to the Commission-
(a) he shall disclose the interest to the parties; and
(b) except with the consent of the parties, he shall not take part in any deliberation or decision of the Commission with respect to the complaint.
(2) Where the Chairman becomes aware that a Commissioner has, in relation to a complaint, such an interest as is mentioned in sub-section (1)-

(a) if the Chairman considers that the Commissioner should not take part, or continue to take part, in any deliberation or decision of the Commission with respect to the complaint-he shall give a direction accordingly; or
(b) in any other case-he shall cause the interest to be disclosed to the parties.
(3) In this section, 'party', in relation to a complaint, means the complainant or the Corporation.
(4) References in this section to a Commissioner shall, if a person is acting as a Commissioner, be construed as including references to the person so acting.
Termination of appointment of Commissioners
77Q. (1) The Governor-General may terminate the appointment of a Commissioner for misbehaviour or physical or mental incapacity.'.

I will discuss what we are trying to achieve. In my speech at the second reading stage of the debate I referred only very briefly to a complaints commission. Some of my colleagues have taken up some of the points. I will explain why we are persisting with these amendments which we believe are appropriate. I accept the comments which have been made by Senator Button that what we are copying is a commission which is used in the United Kingdom to apply to something wider than just the British Broadcasting Corporation. That is not a matter of great relevance. We are trying to bring in an appropriate means of dealing with complaints. Senator Chipp has indicated that he would rather go down a different route. If we had been able to agree on his advise and consent provisions we might have had some meeting of the minds.

It is a fair criticism of our position that last year we proposed what in retrospect was an unsatisfactory complaints mechanism. That may be so. However, that is really irrelevant to the consideration of what we are putting up now. Our 1982 proposals were drawn up on our instructions by the Department of Communications on the basis that the powers and functions of the complaints commissioner, which we were seeking, should be like those contained in other legislation which protects the public from government action. This protection from government action is an approach which has been enshrined in quite a few pieces of legislation. On that basis and on our instructions last year the Department based the provisions. I think it was done in the Ombudsman Act, a provision which we brought forward last year. Of course, it was widely criticised. We looked at the criticism. We examined and accepted it. It is a controversial area. When we in the Opposition were in government we learned as we went. At the end of the last year we issued new instructions establishing a complaints commission process along the lines of that which is operating in the United Kingdom, and it is that provision which we bring forward today. It is interesting that last year the Australian Democrats, when faced with our original proposition, came up with their amendments. Their amendments were at that stage very similar to those which we are moving now. The Democrat amendments regarding a complaints commissioner-

TALK.START.PARA: —You opposed them, if I recall.
—I did not get to that stage.
—But you would have.

—Senator Georges said that we would have opposed them. I think the honourable senator is punting. The fact is that there was no confrontation. The Democrats proposal at that stage was that there should be a statutory body consisting of no fewer than three members and modelled along the British commission. The Democrats proposed that it should be entitled the Broadcasting Complaints Commission. At that stage the Democrats recommended that the appointment of members should be with the concurrence of both Houses of Parliament. They brought down a number or definitions of complaints and brought out some procedures. They looked at the provision for the entertainment of complaints. The Democrats in the Press release stated that it reflected the British model. There were those in government who looked very carefully at whether we had taken a wrong turn, but the Australian Democrats were impressed by what had come up. We have come up now with something which is based upon the British model. I have not heard criticism of what we have proposed in terms of the way we want to move. Whether it is the British Corporation or whether it is for all broadcasting in Britain does not matter. We have proposed a model for the handling of complaints to which the public can go. As the Democrats wanted last year, it will be a statutory body and independent.
—Appointed by the Government?

—Let us accept that that is a point of difference, but let no one pretend that what we are proposing is either outlandish or unreasonable. It is a very good way of handling complaints. It is one that the British have taken up. It provides something apart from the ABC. I do not care how independent any of the officers appointed under the legislation are. They are still seen as being internal people employed within the organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: The public has worried about the matter. People have talked. Senator Harradine talked about appealing from Caesar to Caesar. That is how the commission will be seen. There is no way in which the police in my State or in any other State can really investigate their own members and not be criticised in public. It simply does not work. Where there are occasions on which we have to entertain complaints against government action we believe there is a very strong case for this complaints procedure to be separate and independent and to be seen to be independent. We believe there is a need for the public to be able to seek redress against unfair or unjust treatment or against unwarranted infringement with privacy in relation to radio and television programs which are broadcast to the public. The mechanism which we have proposed will perform some of these functions and protect the people.

The recent history of this country shows that we have had no hesitation in enacting legislation to protect the public against the Acts of government in a large number of areas. I refer to the Ombudsman Act, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act and the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act, which are examples of legislation which give the public a right to appeal against different kinds of administrative action. We are not seeking that kind of thing here. We are seeking equally an independent mechanism by which members of the public can appeal and by which a sense of fair play can not only occur but also be seen to occur.

Last year the Australian Democrats proposed a move towards the British model. We were impressed by the arguments. We, as the then Government, did some work on it. We considered the matter and we prepared the amendments which we are moving tonight. We think that proposition was appropriate and correct. I ask the Senate to give consideration to the merits in this procedure. There is no effort on our part to try to scapegoat or bad mouth the Australian Broadcasting Commission. That is not our purpose. We have indicated all the way through this legislation our support for it and the Australian Broadcasting Commission. What we are looking at is a matter within a very narrow compass.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody said you had.

—The honourable senator has not. The legislation has a very narrow compass. It is about how members of the public will be seen to get fair play. We do not believe that the internal mechanism, no matter how independent honourable senators say the officers are, will be sufficient. Because of that, we think there is still a need for an independent statutory body. I could go back and read the Australian Democrats Press releases from last October and November. They set out why an independent statutory body is what is needed. It is still what is needed and we believe--
—But not appointed by the Government.
—I understand what the honourable senator is saying. We still believe that our amendment is appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Peter Baume 's remarks and address myself in particular to the question of the appointment of a chairman by the Government. I notice that recently the Government appointed Mr Justice Hope as chairman of the Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence Agencies. Nobody suggested that that was Caesar investigating Caesar. Nobody suggested that that was a subjective appointment.
—It would have been highly improper to suggest that, would it not ?

—It would have been improper just as it would have been improper for Senator Button to suggest that the appointment of the former Lord Chief Justice in Britain as the chairman of the Complaints Commission in Britain by the British Government was Caesar sitting in judgment on Caesar. I put it to the Government and I put it fairly and squarely to the Australian Democrats that we are talking about somebody of judicial status. Over goes the dolly once one starts to suggest that a government appointment of a judicial or semi-judicial fashion is in fact an appointment of influence but not of independence. Honourable senators should bear in mind that that was the model of the British Broadcasting Commission. In fact, that is the only argument that has been raised so far against what the Opposition has said.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Opposition has said is quite clear. We have said that, if a corporation is set up and it is to be given independence and has to prove that it has integrity and is operating under its charter, every citizen ought to have the right-I understand Senator Harradine's argument on the question of interest and of citizens' interests-to complain. If a citizen can make a complaint only through an internal mechanism, that is Caesar sitting in judgment on Caesar. Allowing an advisory body which has been appointed by the ABC to appoint such a person will not suffice. In the end that person is paid and maintained by the management of the ABC and is responsible to that corporation for his or her salary, terms and conditions and permanency. Quite clearly, the inference would be that such a person would bring about subjective judgments. That claim may be very unfair to an individual but nowhere, in a sense of objectivity of justice, would anyone tolerate that internal auditing of public complaints.

There has been an admission that something different is needed. Quite clearly, the Australian Democrats had said before that there was no need for an internal mechanism for complaints. The Democrats very validly argued that one could not have that internal mechanism and that one would need to have an external, independent body. That is the principle at which we are really looking now. That is the principle underlying this provision as to whether we have an internal body or an external body sitting in judgment. There are other matters to which I will refer later regarding the rights of people to complain. We have a ridiculous situation in which electors of this country are denied the right to complain about some aspects of a statutory corporation. The crazy situation is that people tend to forget that the ABC exists to serve objectively every Australian citizen. It is the servant of the 15 million Australian people. Each of those people has the absolute right to intervene and to criticise if he or she thinks that there is a valid ground for criticism. I wish only to add that, if honourable senators say that there should be an independent external body, what is wrong with the Government appointing a judge? How can honorable senators condemn the appointment of a judge? How can anyone condemn the British Broadcasting Commission standard? That is the real nub of this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I seek leave to move my amendments (1) to (10) together, which seek to amend the Opposition amendments before the Committee.
—Is leave granted?
—Mr Chairman, I seek your guidance on a point of procedure. Senator Harradine is proposing to move amendments to the Opposition's amendments . How do you propose to deal with those amendments?
—If Senator Harradine moves all 10 amendments together, I will put all 10 amendments. If they are all carried, they will become part of the Opposition's amendment and will then be put to the chamber.

—Mr Chairman, I take a point of order. Senator Harradine is seeking to move 10 amendments. The sheet of paper that has been given to me purporting to containing those amendments proposed by Senator Harradine has only nine amendments.
—I have 10 amendments.

—I have before me one document which has nine amendments and another which has three amendments. Could the Opposition be given copies of the correct documents before we proceed further as we may be talking about amendment (2) but we may be holding amendments different from the amendments held by other honourable senators.
—I will ask the Clerk to consult with Senator Harradine in order to determine the amendments that he proposes to seek leave to move.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier I yielded to Senator Harradine because he wished to move amendments. I am not seeking to prolong the time in which we are debating this legislation tonight because it is already extremely late. However, I refrained from speaking during the second reading debate because the matter that concerned me related specifically to the complaints procedure. I deferred speaking at all to the legislation until now. I support the amendment moved by Senator Peter Baume. I would have liked to have heard, first, the case that Senator Harradine would have put forward in moving his amendments. I will not speak again but will just make up my mind as we go along. This matter of the complaints commission is something that I consider to be terribly important. A point has been made during the debate about the need for independent appointment or approval by Parliament and that would be unsatisfactory if the complaints procedure was under the control of the Government because of appointments it had made.

SPEECH.PARA: I find that argument quite unpersuasive, unless those who proposed it are prepared to say that the Government should, for example, appoint an ombudsman. The introduction of the ombudsman into the Westminster system of government, including the Australian parliamentary system and other parliamentary systems such as New Zealand and the United Kingdom, was a matter of some controversy at the time, because it was claimed to be foreign to the Westminster system of government. In fact, the system was found to work very well. The appointment of that person by government-that is, by the Executive-has worked very well because the purpose of the appointment and of the office is clear. So long as governments appoint who is of great integrity, the system works well. Briefly, I indicate that, when the Queensland Government moved to appoint the first ombudsman in Queensland, that appointment was a matter of some controversy because the appointee was a former Chairman of the Public Service Board. In fact , the appointee, David Longland, was an excellent ombudsman. Nobody ever criticised his reports or his actions. He established that office in Queensland in a totally respected way. Whilst there was disquiet in advance, it was found that he was a good person for the job. So the fact that a government appoints someone does not necessarily take away from that person's value. The issue of an appointment by parliament would be an entirely new issue.

The general issue regarding this Commission is important. I would have thought that many Australian Labor Party senators appreciated it. The fact is that if people feel they have been dealt with unjustly or unfairly-in some cases, in a quite extreme way-by an organisation as powerful as the Australian Broadcasting Commission, they have very few alternatives as to how they can act. If they believe they have been defamed, they may take legal action. Our amendment indicates that the Commission is not required to entertain a complaint if, in the opinion of the Commission, the subject matter of the complaint is a matter in respect of which the person affected has a remedy by way of procedings in any court. Having been through defamation proceedings myself, as have a number of honourable senators, I have some knowledge of the difficulty of the procedure. I have no complaint on that score because my procedure was successful. However, I realise that it is one that would have limited application.

The Australian Broadcasting Commission is a division of the public media which is enormously powerful and which can do great damage to people without their necessarily having a legal remedy. I will instance a case of which I am aware. It is not a public issue so I cannot use names. Mr Chairman, I overheard a very loud conversation in which there was some suggestion of a filibuster.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, there is none.

—Thank you. I reiterate that I do not want to mention names because I am not trying to raise a specific issue. The case that was drawn to my attention was very important. I have no doubt as to the facts of the matter. Honourable senators will have to take my word for that-that I am not making a wild allegation. It concerns a person featured on a Nationwide program. The person was very badly hurt, in his opinion, by the way he was treated by Nationwide. The substance of his complaint is that he made available quite readily to Nationwide certain documents. They were not used because the usage of those documents would not have supported the general thrust of the image that this Nationwide program was trying to present. It is interesting that a subsequent program of Four Corners did make some reference to some part of those documents. This means there was no doubt at all that the ABC had them. It had chosen not to use them on the Nationwide program because that would have damaged the thesis that Nationwide was trying to present. The ABC had them. Four Corners had not approached this individual for the documents. It could have obtained them only via Nationwide. So the ABC had them. Additional to the documents made available to Nationwide, other public records were available, and known to be available, to Nationwide. They were not used because they would have affected the presentation of the program. I refer to such public documents as Hansard and debates in the Parliament which had been reported in the Press. Since that program, certain facts have been placed before the Australian Broadcasting Commission in detail by the person who has been, I would feel, very severely hurt by the program. The ABC has chosen not to respond. It is a matter of choice of the individual as to whether he should sue the ABC. I will not judge or give legal advice. Having some background knowledge, I can see there are difficulties with defamation actions in regard to programs. Under Queensland law in relation to defamation actions, one of the things that must be proved is actual damage. It is quite possible that in this case that could not be proved. Nevertheless, extremely unfair and inaccurate things were said about this person on the Nationwide program. A substantial complaint has been made to the ABC. It has been totally ignored. There has not even been a letter of acknowledgment of the material forwarded to the ABC.

SPEECH.PARA: I make one final point on this matter. The individual involved was not the principal target of the program. The principal target of the program was the Queensland Government. So this person did not create any misdemeanour about which it was important that the public knew. He was used as a device to give an impression about the Queensland Government. He was used as a 'for instance' for another target. Because of what could be seen as a glancing blow for the purpose of making a point about something else, this person has been severely embarrassed and utterly unfairly dealt with. This person has the right to a remedy. The Australian Broadcasting Commission is an extremely powerful organisation. That program has been beamed at least Queensland-wide. It has gone into many homes in which no television channel is available. It was quite spectacular in its presentation. Even if it were not, the issue remains the same . In the minds of everybody who saw that program there would be a belief about the individual concerned. The belief would be that he had received favours from the Queensland Government, which were extraordinary, but they were not. It is a matter of public record that that is not true; that he had contributed some money to a political party in Queensland that had resulted in favours. He has not contributed any such money. There was a suggestion that certain people who contributed money might receive this sort of favour. The belief would be that he has been able to manipulate a situation whereby the State Government stood over a statutory corporation, which is untrue. It is defamatory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't he sue them, Senator?

—While Senator Button was chatting with other people I explained the position. I will explain it briefly again. Under Queensland defamation law, one must prove actual damage. I can understand that in this case-I do not know; he has not told me why he has not taken such action, but I have some experience with Queensland defamation laws-it is possible that he might find it very difficult to prove. On the facts that have been put to me, if I were in his shoes I might find it difficult to prove. It is not for me to say. I point out that under our amendment, if the Commission belived that the individual in question could sue for defamation, it would not entertain the complaint. That would be the end of it.
—And under ours, of course, under the Bill as proposed--

—I appreciate Senator Button's lively interest in what I am saying. I was trying to be brief. I shall try to conclude my remarks in a few seconds. Senator Button can then answer because he will have ample opportunity to speak. To protect himself when resources are unequal-and they are-an individual facing this sort of highly uncertain situation of whether, under law, he would be successful has to engage in extremely expensive legal procedures. It may be that if the ABC knew that the matter could be more simply resolved it would be less inclined to use someone and his situation as a tool for another purpose, as was the case in this situation. I look forward to Senator Button's response. He may be able to alleviate the worry of this person who wrote to the ABC a month ago and who, I reiterate for Senator Button's benefit, has never had a response. It may be that the Bill does cover this matter.
—Did you receive an acknowledgement?

—Not an acknowledgement-nothing. It may be that Senator Button is of the opinion that his Bill covers this case, in which case I would appreciate his taking up the case and seeing whether he can resolve it satisfactorily. He could at least indicate to the person involved that the complaint has been received.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Harradine) put:
That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report progress.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Department of Foreign Affairs
Motion (by Senator Button) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that the norm is that I pick the wrong night of the year to speak in the adjournment debate. I thank honourable senators for their presence. Since I last referred to the matter about which I wish to speak tonight there has been quite a change of personnel in this chamber. Many honourable senators have gone and many new honourable senators have taken their places. Because of that I am reminded of the old adage that politicians come and politicians go but the Public Service and the bureaucrats seem to go on forever. Whilst in many respects there has been an orderly handover of business from one political party to another, as is the Westminster tradition, no doubt there are areas in which we will see more innovations because of the philosophical differences between the two major parties in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, public servants and the Public Service stay on; they seem to go on ad infinitum. Because of that, I raise again the question of the Tehran Embassy embezzlement and related matters which are now over 12 months old. It seems to me that, regardless of which form of government rules this country or which political party is at the helm, serious elements of corruption go on-again ad infinitum. While some of these matters are in many respects 10 years old, the change of government seems to have made no difference and the people concerned seem to have been sufficiently bold to proceed full steam ahead with their nefarious activities confident that the contacts they maintain with the bureaucracy will protect them from exposure or at least punishment.

I recognise that the vast majority of public servants are honest and loyally support whichever government is in power. But it seems to me that a small number of bad eggs, some of them knights of the realm, whose corrupt activities I exposed as recently as 14 December last year have used the long parliamentary shut down, thanks to Mr Fraser's miscalculations, to continue their corrupt activities-I respect that; to continue their corrupt activities-in preying on the public purse, covering up for their mates and persecuting and harassing those honest officers who have had the courage to stand up to them and who enjoy the protection and support of their unions. I refer, of course, principally to the Department of Foreign Affairs.

Last year I and other honourable senators spoke at some length in this place in an effort to expose and remedy a range of corrupt practices which first came to light in the Tehran Embassy affair involving a cover-up by the departmental head , Mr Henderson, of an ingenious range of financial abuses perpetrated by his boyhood friend Ivor Bowden while serving as Ambassador in Tehran from 1974 to 1978. A few examples of that corruption were: The nanny's fare, phantom servants , snow-clearing payment to his sons, false representations in relation to adult children's incomes, false entertainment allowance claims and other false certificates, totalling around $15,000. That was in 1974. That sum would probably be equivalent to $30,000 today. Later I drew the Senate's attention to other irregularities involving Mr Bowden and cases involving other ambassadors ripping off the taxpayer, including phoney medical retirements.

Throughout all of this Mr Street and Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle proved totally inadequate in controlling their corrupt officials who boldly organised a cover-up involving Foreign Affairs, Department of Finance officials and police officers. Witnesses were intimidated and evidence distorted. One key witness was successfully nobbled and I believe that false information was skilfully fed to one of the then shadow Ministers. I shall not name those involved today. But fortunately enough honest people were around to enable the Senate to monitor and expose this dishonest mess. Inquiries by the Ombudsman are continuing and I hope that in due course these matters will be dealt with by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. No malefactor has yet been punished, although one has been promoted. Mr Henderson and his colleagues may think that they have successfully weathered the storm. I remain determined that all of this disgraceful conduct will be examined fully and the guilty punished.

Let sleeping dogs lie, some politicians and journalists suggest-and 'lie', I believe, is the operative word. These men are, in my view, professional liars. They lied to Mr Street. I tender Mr Henderson's original note of 4 March 1982, Mr President, and seek leave for the incorporation of that note in Hansard. It has just become available under the Freedom of Information Act.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
FOREIGN AFFAIRS
4 March 1982 FOR THE MINISTERQUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE: SENATOR PRIMMER

Last week we discussed Senator Primmer's question regarding a possible embezzlement of $35,000 from the Australian Embassy in Tehran. I indicated at the time that we had no knowledge of any such incident and added that the post's accounting records were being re-examined in case something has been overlooked.

I can now say that this re-examination, covering monthly transactions back beyond the past three years, has been completed without a sign of any accounting irregularities. Further, the post conducted a check of its cash advances as recently as 26 February and subsequently reported that all cash on hand has been accounted for.

Curiously enough, an amount of about $35,000 was at one time (late 1978) held in cash by the post as an emergency advance to cover any necessary cash expenditure in the event of an emergency evacuation. This amount has been accounted for in our reconciliations of the post's accounting transactions. It is possible that the existence of this advance has prompted someone to speculate as to its propriety or possible 'misuse'. Any such speculation would appear to be unfounded.
I attach for your consideration and signature a response to Senator Primmer.
(P. G. F. Henderson) Secretary

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. These men, as I have said, lied to Mr Street, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and Mr Newman, who believed them or pretended to believe them. The Senate and another place were conveniently and systematically misled in this way. They lied to the media, and honourable senators will recall that Mr Henderson himself lied to Senate Estimates Committee D on 10 September 1982 in an unsuccessful attempt to blacken the names of the several honest officers who had gathered the mass of evidence against Mr Bowden. This disgraceful performance was subsequently covered by Senators Sibraa , McIntosh, Georges and me, but nothing seems to have happened to Mr Henderson on that account. Yes, Mr President, 'lie' is the operative word.

SPEECH.PARA: But while these men have certainly been lying, they have not been sleeping. On the contrary, they have been very active indeed. Since the last sitting, they have moved to retrieve from the Ombudsman the file containing financial irregularities concerning Mr Bowden's piano and other furniture. The mind boggles at the lies they must have told Mr Street to get him, contrary to his solemn undertaking to the honest officers, to ask the Ombudsman to have the file transferred to the police. Furthermore, they have continued to use security and/ or police action against honest departmental officers, to enable the cover-up to stick. Again, during the time we have been in recess, the retirement swindles involving Henderson and Sir Nicholas Parkinson have moved one step forward with Parkinson's invalidity retirement on 11 March 1983. This murky affair, which involves a six figure sum, or a quarter of a million dollars, demonstrates Henderson ready and willing to 'buy' the top job by giving his colleague a massive series of golden handshakes, at the expense of the taxpayer. Another matter of concern is rumoured ambassadorial appointments for people whose reputations have rightly been damaged by the Tehran exposures.

I have placed on the Notice Paper a series of questions designed to get at the truth of all these matters and to illustrate the cover-up that continued during the parliamentary recess. Some of my questions are those that Mr Street found unanswerable last year. Others are based on new information which, as I demonstrated last year, is always becoming available from sources dismayed at and angered by the dishonest performance of these senior public servants. I urge any public servant, any journalist-indeed, any public spirited person at all-who may possess information regarding these matters to pass it on to me. I can assure them that I shall strain every nerve to protect anyone fearful of pressure or retribution as a result. Mr President, I believe that I would have the support of the vast majority of honourable senators in this.

But that is not all. I was just recently reliably informed of two instances of corrupt behaviour by very senior officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs which have not yet come to the knowledge of the Parliament. I believe that this information is now available to the Minister who, of course, is fully aware of the sorts of views that I have been expressing on these issues for the past 13 months. Given that the ball is in Mr Hayden's court and that I have great confidence in his judgment and ability, I do not propose to expose the officers concerned, other than to say that I know that each has also been up to his neck in the Tehran cover-up. Should it emerge that Ministers need the overt support of Parliament to deal severely with the men concerned, I am prepared to raise pertinent questions in the chamber or on the Notice Paper, as may be required. I believe, as I have told Mr Hayden, that the majority of honourable senators would support me in this.

I will not rest, Mr President, while the people of Australia continue to be ' represented' by a Department of Foreign Affairs run by a small group of people who could not be trusted with the petty cash, and who would sell their grandmothers, let alone the East Timorese, to get a promotion. I believe that the nation and the vast majority of honest and competent Foreign Affairs staff deserve better, and I expect that with the new Labor Government in control success is just around the corner. The small number of senior camp followers of the Fraser Government must be dealt with as the law allows.

On one or two of my trips abroad as part of delegations I have been extremely disturbed-I suppose that is the only way to put it-at the attitudes of, thankfully, only one or two junior staff officers at some of our posts. These young men have expressed attitudes towards people in the host country that to me leave much to be desired. Their education and training suggest to me that they are the product of schools and/or homes which lead them to see themselves as superior to everyone else. That brings me to a comment on the series of questions that I have placed on the Notice Paper as shown on page 297. I refer to the appearance that the method of selecting recruits may hang more on the old boy network than on the prescribed rules. If such were the case it would be quite possible for toffee-nosed upstarts to get into and work their way up through the system and, in my view, become the sort of personnel we should not be sending abroad as our representatives.

I believe that a Mr Adam Smith has been employed within the Department. I understand that he is a relative of the First Assistant Secretary, Management and Foreign Service Division, in the Department. It is feasible to me that the system may well have been bypassed in Mr Adam Smith's accession to that position . I say that it may well be the case; I am not accusing Mr Adam Smith of being a toffee-nosed upstart but it seems to me that if this is going on within the Department a form of nepotism may well be emerging or have been around for quite some time.

I conclude briefly with the following remarks. I suppose that some of us in this chamber saw the Four Corners program entitled 'The Whistle Blowers'. I certainly saw it. That program, from memory, showed four cases of honest public servants who told the truth, were forthright and stuck to their guns. One of them finished up a broken man as a result. Those who saw the program grained an insight into just how the bureacracy can work when it has a vested interest in hiding something brought to light by honest public servants. It showed how an officer-in that case, a particular officer-all too often becomes the accused rather than the accuser in the eyes of department heads and even Ministers. It also showed that the type of stories that are put around about an honest person suggest that such a person is not well and give all sorts of veiled hints about his health, personality and work capability. This is exactly what has happened in the Department of Foreign Affairs in relation to this issue. The honest have been made to appear dishonest and the dishonest are shown as paragons of virtue. I do not intend to release this matter until I believe that justice has been seen to be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise simply because Senator Primmer, I think on some three or four occasions in the Senate, has raised matters relating to the Department of Foreign Affairs and has now raised such a matter when he is part of a Government. I refer to only one matter raised by him ; that of Sir Nicholas Parkinson. I believe that gross injustice has been done to this man and I am willing to believe, until it is proven otherwise, that a gross injustice is being done to many others, including Mr Peter Henderson, who, until it is proven otherwise to me-I invite all honourable senators to agree with me-is a man of not only immense ability but also high integrity. I say this with no pleasure at all because, as I think Senator Primmer knows, I have a high regard for him. I respect his contribution to this chamber and his general attitude as an honourable senator and I find it hard to reconcile what he is saying now with that view. I do not doubt his sincerity. Let me test this matter .

SPEECH.PARA: Whereas when Senator Primmer was in opposition he may have had difficulty in pursuing the matter, instead of coming here tonight and making public accusations against people, he could have gone to his Government and got it to make the investigations and pursue them in the way in which all investigations should be pursued. He should have started off with the onus of proof so as to prove other than innocence. Let me test this. It has been suggested several times now-I must say it has caused great grief to the persons concerned-that certain persons have been dishonest in what they have done, notably Sir Nicholas Parkinson. Some honourable senators may know that Sir Nicholas Parkinson was one of our most distinguished senior public servants. All of us who were close to him have known that his personal tragedy has been that in recent years his eyesight has been failing steadily, to a point where it has threatened his very vision and certainly endangered his capacity to do his job. To suggest that there was reason other total genuine medical grounds for his retirement is in defiance of the medical evidence, and medical evidence there is in plenty. But why should the honourable senator have to do that? Just as the rules here say that none of us can accuse other honourable senators of being liars, we should use such words with the greatest of care when we talk about our fellow men. Just because the Standing Orders do not protect others does not mean that we do not have that obligation. I say this with sincerity to Senator Primmer. I repeat that in general, I respect his approach to matters. But we have no right at all here to condemn people without their having been given a fair chance.

I make it perfectly clear that I personally know that Sir Nicholas Parkinson had medical difficulties with his vision to such an extent that he was forced, unwillingly, to terminate his service. That can easily be proven. There is medical evidence in abundance. But why should we need to refer to that? Anybody who knew the man, who knew the problems of his sight, who looked at the spectacles that he wore, who observed his approach to reading or to ordinary sight, would have known his limitations. It was as though he were wearing optical crutches. Therefore, to make the suggestions which were made is, I think , grossly offensive. In any case whether we mention Peter Henderson-the man has been of immense service to this country-or any other public servant, I accept that all those people are people of integrity and honesty unless it can be proven otherwise. I rose to commend to Senator Primmer-I am very sad that this matter has been raised-that if he has any other allegations, he should go to his Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and ask his Government to hold a proper investigation into those allegations, incuding the ones he made tonight. His suggestion is that, apparently, a proper investigation was not carried out by the Fraser Government. My understanding is that there was a thorough investigation. In any case it is competent upon the Hawke Government and Mr Hayden to carry out such an investigation. I simply rise to say, first of all, that of my own public knowledge at least one person has had his reputation unfairly damaged. I invite the normal process of justice in this place to be followed.
Thursday, 26 May 1983

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the Senate very long. I adopt the remarks of Senator Sir John Carrick and thank him for making them. I merely wish to add that there were some rather lesser lights in the Department of Foreign Affairs mentioned in Senator Primmer's speech. It struck me that on the fact of what the honourable senator had to say tonight, he was prepared to introduce names on the basis, to use his words, that it might be feasible that there was something untoward. He followed words to that effect with words like: 'I am not accusing a particular person of being a toffee-nosed upstart'. I merely wish to add to what Senator Sir John Carrick said that on the face of what Senator Primmer said tonight there was inadequate basis for some of the comments made about somebody obviously relatively junior in the Department. I believe that people in relatively junior positions might also have the assumption that Senator Sir John Carrick outlined- that is, the assumption of innocence-as appyling to those officers who are personally known to him. I have heard Senator Primmer on a number of occasions from the Opposition benches raise this matter. I agree that he now has a Government which he has supported and helped to bring to power. He might have taken his complaint to it, but I think this has been a very doubtful use of the privileges which are afforded to this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the representative of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in this place, I feel it incumbent on behalf of the Government at least to make some response to the very serious allegations that Senator Primmer has once again made here tonight and, in doing so, to indicate that Senator Primmer has in fact to my knowledge raised these matters with Mr Hayden, the Foreign Minister. I will endeavour in what I say in the moment to reflect what I understand to be Mr Hayden's current thinking on the matter. Senator Primmer stated tonight in summary form a series of allegations that he has made in more detail on previous occasions during the Autumn and Budget sittings of the Parliament last year against a number of present and former officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs, which allegations are furthermore embodied in the substance of a series of questions on notice which lapsed on the proroguing of the Parliament and which now reappear with, it appears, further additions.

SPEECH.PARA: Among Senator Primmer's allegations are claims that a substantial sum of money had been embezzled from the Australian Embassy in Tehran and that a miscellany of other wrongful actions had been committed by a former Ambassador in Tehran, Mr Bowden; and that an officer of the Department, Mr Witheford, who appears to be the primary source of Senator Primmer's allegations, had been withdrawn from the Embassy in Tehran in connection with the matters I have just mentioned, had been victimised by the Department. There are allegations repeated again tonight that the Secretary to the Department, Mr Henderson, had covered up these and other wrongdoings by officers of the Department and that there have been other wrongful acts committed by officers of the Department, apart from those in Tehran, involving a former Ambassador to Germany, Sir Nicholas Parkinson, who is the subject of-

TALK.START.PARA: —Sir Nicholas Parkinson was Ambassador to the United States-
—I am sorry, Senator! I am saying there was a former Ambassador to Germany, Sir Nicholas Parkinson, a former Ambassador to the United States-
—Don't be too testy. You are allowed to be corrected-
—For God's sake, Senator! I am endeavouring, if you will listen and curb your approach to these matters, to accommodate the points you are making and many of the sentiments, which I happen to share.
—You are repeating the allegations.
—Order! I suggest that the Attorney-General address his remarks through the Chair.

—I am mentioning no other names in my comments now than those mentioned by Senator Primmer. I am simply summarising for Senator Sir John Carrick's edification-if he is interested in being edified on this or any other occasion-the matters that have been alleged as a prelude to indicating what action has been taken and the response of the present Government to those allegations. Those allegations have concerned, as I said, the gentlemen I have mentioned, Sir Nicholas Parkinson and Mr Henderson, and other officers of the Department, including officers named for the first time tonight and named in circumstances which I would agree are somewhat unhappy, given the fact that their mention was not substantiated by anything more than mere suggestions of possible impropriety.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the action that has been taken in this matter, I simply state what is in large measure known to be the case. First, the allegations against Mr Bowden in respect of Tehran were examined by officers of the Department of Finance and by the Australian Federal Police, as a result of which a statement was made to the House of Representatives by Mr Street, the former Minister for Foreign Affairs. The investigating officers concluded that they were satisfied on the evidence available that there was no basis for action to be taken against Mr Bowden by the Commonwealth in respect of the financial matters examined.

Then there was an investigation by the Commonwealth Ombudsman into allegations by Mr Witheford that the Australian Federal Police were guilty of misconduct during their investigation into Mr Witheford's original allegations. That investigation by the Ombudsman, which I believe and am advised was a thorough and exhaustive one, has not yet been completed but is being actively pursued at the moment. Subsequent allegations were made by Senator Primmer that have been further investigated by the Australian Federal Police, relating again to allegations based specifically on information from Mr Witheford. The Australian Federal Police investigation, of which I have seen a summary of the report, dated quite recently-in August last year I think; there is another report since then-found no evidence that would substantiate any criminal offence against any person named in Senator Primmer's allegations.

Finally, there was the claim by Mr Witheford that he had been unfairly treated by the Department of Foreign Affairs, which claim is under examination at present by the Public Service Board. I am advised that that inquiry now being conducted by the Public Service Board is a major inquiry. It is conducting its investigations into all aspects of these matters in the most thorough and exhaustive fashion. It is continuing to be conducted in a thorough and exhaustive fashion.

I simply repeat the view of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden. He has had an opportunity to engage in discussions with Senator Primmer on this matter. He has given me tonight a note briefing me as to his present reaction to these matters. I say, quite carefully, that Mr Hayden is someone who has no axe to grind in these matters. He is someone who is no one's fool when it comes to evaluating investigations conducted by law enforcement agencies for the obvious reason that he has a history of prior personal involvement in such an agency in the past. It is Mr Hayden's present judgment that the police report, which he has had particular occasion to scrutinise very thoroughly, is an exhaustive analysis of the situation and demonstrates that many, if not all, of the allegations in question simply do not have a substantial evidentiary foundation or, at least, a foundation that is capable of being presented and expounded in a fashion that would remotely sustain a criminal prosecution. That is Mr Hayden's view of the police report which he has had an opportunity to peruse in some detail.

So we are confronted with the situation that if there is a conspiracy or a cover-up it has been one of the more successful ones in the history of public administration because so far it has succeeded in fooling the Australian Federal Police, the Department of Finance, the Ombudsman, probably the Public Service Board, the previous Government and maybe one Minister in the present Government. It may be that the bureaucracy is capable of working in a fashion that can sustain a cover-up or a conspiracy of that magnitude but the present Government' s inclination, on the present state of the evidence, is to believe that there simply is not a sufficient evidentiary foundation to sustain most, if not all, of the allegations that have been put with all sincerity and a fierce belief in their rightness into the public arena by Senator Primmer. That is the state of play at the moment as perceived by the present Government. I hope that will succeed in keeping Senator Sir John Carrick quiet for the future before leaping to conclusions about these matters in his usual contemptible and half-baked fashion.

I hope, however, I have also said enough to indicate that active investigations are continuing to be pursued by the Ombudsman and the Public Service Board. If there is any skerrick of foundation for the very substantial and very serious allegations that have been made over a long period in regard to this matter, and with complete conviction and sincerity by Senator Primmer, I can assure Senator Primmer and other honourable senators that this matter will be very fiercely and aggressively pursued by this Government. On the present state of play I have to say that it does appear that there simply is not, so far at least on the record, any evidence to support allegations of the gravity that have in fact been made.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 12.11 a.m., Thursday

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian Government received any information that Ana Margarita Gasteazoro Escolan has been in custody since May 1981; if so, when did the Government first obtain such information.
(2) What action has the Government taken to protest at the continued detention of the abovenamed.
(3) Has the Government taken any action; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government has no information about the case of Ana Margarita Gasteazoro Escolan.

(2) and (3) The Australian Embassy in Mexico City has been asked to make enquiries about Ms Gasteazoro's welfare. When the Government has received the results of these enquiries it will consider what further action can be taken.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has been taken subsequent to the former government's decision to introduce multicultural television to Adelaide in 1983-84 to:
(b) include local community participation in the implementation of this decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) the extension of multicultural television is under review in the budgetary context. The Government's priority remains to extend the transmission of multicultural television nationally in stages to the major population centres. Extension of transmission to Adelaide is planned for an early stage of development; and

(b) while the Government is conscious of the desirability of local community participation in multicultural television services, the cost is very high, and the Government's first priority in the development of scarce resources must be to make existing services available to as wide an audience as possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 22 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the document, 'Defence Force Aid to Civil Power-Situations other than Counter Terrorist Operations-Policy and Procedures' OPS B/4/78 dated 22 September 1978 and tabled in the Senate on 22 April 1983, incorporate lessons learnt from Cyclone Tracey.
(2) Will that document now be amended to incorporate lessons learnt from the flight by Royal Australian Air Force aircraft over South West Tasmania on 7 and 8 April 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The type of assistance provided by the Defence Force to the people of Darwin after Cyclone Tracey is covered by the document Defence Instruction ( General) OPS 05-1-Policy and Procedures for Defence Force Assistance to the Civil Community, dated 29 August 1979. The document which the honourable senator mentioned covers Defence Force aid to the Commonwealth and/or State governments and their civil authorities in their performance of law enforcement tasks. Lessons learnt from Cyclone Tracey are incorporated in Defence Instruction ( General) OPS 05-1-Policy and Procedures for Defence Force Assistance to the Civil Community and in Plan Emperor which is the Defence Force plan for assistance to the civil community in the event of a disaster.
(2) The RAAF aircraft flights over South West Tasmania on 7 and 8 April 1983 will be taken into consideration during the current review of both documents.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, upon notice , on 3 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the gross cost of producing programs for the Canberra School of Music Wind Series at the High Court of Australia 1983.
(3) By whom were the copies printed.
(4) What was the revenue from the advertisement for the Canberra International Motor Inn on the programs.
(5) Did the School of Music approach the Canberra International Motor Inn or an advertising agency to place the advertisement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) The Canberra International Motor Inn met the total cost ($200) of producing 800 copies of the program.
No additional revenue in respect of advertising was received by the School of Music.
The programs were printed by the Canberra Publishing and Printing Company, Fyshwick, Australian Capital Territory.
(5) The placement of the advertisement was negotiated between the Canberra School of Music and the Canberra International Motor Inn.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the airstrip at the Royal Australian Air Force base at Tindal near Katherine in the Northern Territory breaking up?
(2) Did loose stones on the airstrip last week cause damage to an F111; if so, what was the cost of damage to the F111?
(3) Will the Government be re-building the airstrip so as to make it operationally safe; if so, what is the estimated cost involved in repairing the airstrip?
(4) When will the environmental impact study of Tindal be complete?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no problem with the strength of the airfield pavement at Tindal. Normal aging of the bituminous surface however eventually permits aggregate to be dislodged.
(2) An F111 aircraft engine was damaged by ingestion of a foreign body, believed to be a small metal object. The cost to repair the engine has been estimated at $10,000.

(3) The Department of Housing and Construction is inspecting the runway and will advise on the extent to which routine maintenance needs to be brought forward. Until the inspection is completed an estimate is unavailable.

(4) Planning for the formulation of proposals for Government consideration, regarding the development of Tindal, provides for the circulation of a draft environmental impact statement for public comment in the latter half of 1983.
